headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you for standing by and welcome to WestRock's Fiscal 2016 First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. This call will be an hour in duration. [Operator Instructions] This call is being recorded. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this time
componenttext: Thank you for standing by and welcome to WestRock's Fiscal 2016 First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. This call will be an hour in duration. [Operator Instructions] This call is being recorded. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this time. I'd now like to turn the call over to Mr. Steve Voorhees. Sir, you may begin.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Welcome to our conference call. I'm Steve Voorhees, Chief Executive Officer. I'm joined this morning by Ward Dickson, Chief Financial Officer; Jim Porter, President of our Paper Solutions business; and Bob Beckler, President of our Packaging
componenttext:
Good morning. Welcome to our conference call. I'm Steve Voorhees, Chief Executive Officer. I'm joined this morning by Ward Dickson, Chief Financial Officer; Jim Porter, President of our Paper Solutions business; and Bob Beckler, President of our Packaging Solutions business. During the course of the call, we will make forward-looking statements involving our plans, expectations, estimates and beliefs related to future events. Statements may involve a number of risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those that we discuss during the call. We describe these risks and uncertainties in our filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including our 10-K for the fiscal year ending September 30, 2015. We'll refer to non-GAAP financial measures during the call. We've provided direct reconciliations of these non-GAAP measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measures in the appendix of the slide presentation, which is available on our website. 
Before we share the details about the quarter, I'd like to comment on a lot of the questions I've get asked most frequently these days, which is how the merger integration going. Pleased to report the merger integration is going extremely well. I believe, even more strongly today than strategic rationales of the merger than I did when we announced the merger 1 year ago. We have the first or second waiting positions in attractive global packaging markets and we're aggressively working to maximize the opportunities of the merger while improving operational efficiencies across our organization. We're executing on and making meaningful progress when realizing our $1 billion in synergy and performance improvement opportunities. 
is building an outstanding WestRock team that's aligned and focused on building the premier global packaging company. 
Our customers are very interested in using innovation to increase their sales and reducing their cost to increase their profitability. WestRock's suite of paper packaging and merchandising products and services across a multinational platform is enabling us to engage with customers in ways that no other company can. We're an integrated, global packaging solutions provider, and this is resonating with our customers. We're executing on our strategy and we're working well together while doing so. We're taking advantage of the opportunities to improve our business through our investment in people, assets and acquisitions. 
WestRock is a compelling value creation opportunity. We're well positioned to deliver value for stockholders. We're strong believers in managing the business to generate cash, we've aligned our strategies and to do just that. During our first 6 months of operation, we generated $609 million or $2.33 per share. And free cash flow after adding back after-tax cash, merger and integration-related restructuring costs. For this fiscal year, we expect to generate in the range of $950 million to $1 billion free cash flow, or approximately $3.75 per share based on our current share count. 
We've demonstrated our commitment to returning capital to stockholders. We've repurchased 9.5 million shares over the past 7 months and are paying in annual dividend of about $400 million. We intend to maintain our dividend after the spinoff Specialty Chemicals. At yesterday's closing stock price, our current yield of 4.7% would increase over 5% after completion of the spin. 
Let's turn to the financial results for the quarter. WestRock sales for the quarter were $3.7 billion and adjusted earnings per share were $0.59. Our last 12 months credit agreement EBITDA margin was 16.9%. These returns are largely in line with expectations. Our Corrugated Packaging business performed well, with strong growth in box sales in the United States. We've managed our supply with our customer demand, and as a result, we've permanently closed 3 mills: Coshocton, MeadWestvaco and Uncasville, with total annual capacity of 675,000 tons. 
Our Brazilian Corrugated Packaging operations continued to perform exceptionally well. This business is providing great current returns and also providing attractive investment opportunities to improve our returns over the next several years. 
We've added SP Fiber and some bale packaging businesses to our platform. We expect to complete our joint venture with Grupo Gondi during the first half of calendar year 2016. All 3 transactions add to the strength of our business. 
We've repurchased 4.1 million shares of our common stock since November. To date, we've bought back 9.5 million shares under our $40 million share repurchase authorization. We reassessed our valuation for Specialty Chemicals business and lack of changing market conditions and financial performance and lower comparative market valuations for their peer group. We reduced the estimated enterprise value for Specialty Chemicals business and the purchase accounting value recorded last July to approximately $1.6 billion. As a result, we've recorded a noncash goodwill impairment charge of $478 million. 
We're making progress on of Ingevity. Earlier this month, we received a private letter internal revenue services to positively address each issue we need to have addressed for the spin, including the removal of additional limitations on WestRock stock repurchases. We anticipate completion of the spin by early May, later than previously announced due to the inherent complexities of the separation process. 
The Corrugated Packaging team delivered outstanding results across our North American box business, with box shipments up 2.9% on a per day basis. Box prices were stable sequentially. All regions of the United States did well, although we did have a slight decline in the west, principally due to a decline in produce volumes. 
We have particularly strong performance in e-commerce. We shipped 530,000 tons to domestic and export markets, including approximately 280,000 tons to domestic markets and 250,000 tons to export markets. Without SP Fiber, domestic shipments were 86,000 tons less than last year, and our prices were essentially flat sequentially. Export channels continue to be price competitive. Overall export pricing was down $9 per ton on a sequential-quarter basis. 
We actively manage our system to meet our customer demand and took 264,000 tons of economic and maintenance downtime in the quarter. The incremental cost of economic downtime was $11 million year-over-year. The closure of the Uncasville and Coshocton mills will reduce our annual operating cost by $25 million. 
The cumulative impact of these actions has balanced our containerboards system. We made solid gains in productivity with incremental contribution to pretax income of $36 million over last year. 
Brazil continued to perform very well, both individually and compared to the rest of the Brazilian market, with EBITDA margins of 24.8%. The [indiscernible] mill in our virgin fiber supply are competitive advantage in this market. WestRock's stock shipments increased 1% compared to the prior year. This is significantly more than the overall market in Brazil, which declined by 5%. 
Turning to the Consumer Packaging segment. Our adjusted EBITDA margin of 14.2% grew by 160 basis points over last year. This is driven by strong performance in our packaging businesses, overall stable consumer mill volumes, productivity gains and energy deflation. Price and mix were stable for the quarter. External SBS volumes from our mill systems were modestly down, largely related to the loss of a customer last year. 
Otherwise we're seeing good growth in premium applications including tobacco, commercial print and services cup. While the SBS market is challenged by slow demand and process food applications, we're continuing to perform well across the diversified mix of end markets that we serve. We've seen a small amount of foreign competition in more commodity portions of the market, such as food service plate and general markets. This has not have an appreciable impact on our business. 
In addition to external SBS sales, we're making good progress internalizing approximately 100,000 tons of incremental SBS production into our converting system, the opportunities identified during the merger, the recent acquisitions of packaging businesses. 
Also in the quarter, we continued the integration of more than 150,000 tons of the Carolina commercial print business that we acquired last year. This production transitioned fully to our SBS system earlier this month. The net result of the gains in internal converting in the Carolina acquisition increased the loading and production efficiencies for our SBS mill system. The combined and beverage packaging businesses delivered a good quarter, as modest growth in global beer markets offset declines in carbonated sort soft drink volumes, particularly in North America. 
Our mills operated well during the quarter, and executed and $50 per ton price increase announced less summer. With the Cenveo Packaging acquisition, we will internalize an additional 5,000 tons of into our system. 
Our folding carton converting business continues to perform well. Volumes exceeded of the overall market. Pricing was slightly down as contract renewals were competitive and some food customers experience declining volumes. had a very good quarter with strong European volumes more than offsetting some weakness in North America. Margin continues to improve with good mix, cost management and productivity. 
Merchandising display sales declined due to lower commodity activity with key customers. The core business remains attractive, and we're continuing to optimize the fixed cost structure of this business to improve profitability. 
Turning to Specialty Chemicals. The oil prices has reduced demand for oilfield chemicals and industry products. This has made competing petroleum-based chemistries more economical. 
Total sales during the quarter declined by $31 million compared to last year. Segment EBITDA of $32 million was a little more than half of last year's quarter. Segment profitability also reflected $8.5 million in outage in China start up expenses. The December quarter is seasonally the softest quarter for this business. 
Ingevity's annual revenue is running at more than $900 million and adjusted EBITDA is now at an annual rate of approximately $200 million. The oilfield services business is now less than 10% of annual revenue at approximately $80 million. This business is relatively smaller compared to the total business. We achieved record quarterly sales for activated carbon and asphalt additive products. We have good growth engines in the asphalt additives and carbon, including the new automotive carbon plant that's starting up in China. We have a strong profitable business, a very strong management team and the scale with which to operate as a successful public company. The long-term fundamentals of the business are sound and will make for compelling growth equity story. Post spin, Ingevity will have reasonable leverage at about 2.5x EBITDA. This will provide an immediate cash inflow of approximately $400 million to WestRock at the time of the spin, plus funding an additional $80 million of security for a capital lease retained by WestRock. 
Our land business results reflected purchase price accounting step up with the assets to fair market value as of July 1 merger closing. The step up effectively removes what the anticipated development profit was at that time. This has no effect on cash flow, only on reported earnings. 
Most important thing to know about this segment is that we're operating in Charlestown, one of the healthiest real estate markets in the country. We're looking at ways to monetize our portfolio faster than the normal development process would allow. We've already make some progress on certain projects and we expect to do more on this front. 
Over the last several months, we completed the SP Fiber and Cenveo Packaging acquisitions with a total investment of approximately $400 million. with SP Fiber and Cenveo Packaging are great strategic fits with our business and strategy. We believe these businesses will generate excellent returns on investment. 
We expect to complete the Grupo Gondi joint venture investment in the next couple of months. Mexico is very important to our customers and to us, due to its proximity to the United States and its strong growth profile. We have been looking for a long time for the right opportunity to grow our capabilities in Mexico, and I believe that the partnership with Grupo Gondi is the best way for WestRock to grow in Mexico. WestRock will contribute $175 million in cash and our 3 Mexican box plants, and Grupo Gondi will contribute their business. Based on current exchange rates in the last 12 months results, the joint venture on a pro forma basis has generated $670 million in sales and $135 million in EBITDA. Our box plants have generated about 10% to 15% of the $135 million. We will have a 25% interest in the joint venture, and the joint venture will have net positive cash on the balance sheet when the joint venture is formed. The cash that we're contributing will be invested by the joint venture to support growth. WestRock will continue to provide the 200,000 that we supplied to our 3 box plants and will have continuing opportunities to supply additional tons if the joint venture grows. We're currently executing on an opportunity to supply 25,000 tons of crop liner to Gondi that we were not supplying 6 months ago. We will have an opportunity to build upon our combined relationships and capabilities to grow in the attractive paper and packaging market in Mexico. Now I'll turn it over to Ward for additional details.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Steve. Total non-allocated expenses were $4.5 million in the current quarter. We reduced corporate expenses by $21 million and this is included as part of our $250 million synergy and productivity performance. Our non-service pension income i
componenttext:
Thank you, Steve. Total non-allocated expenses were $4.5 million in the current quarter. We reduced corporate expenses by $21 million and this is included as part of our $250 million synergy and productivity performance. 
Our non-service pension income is $25 million lower than the $47 million recorded last year. This was principally a result of our pension derisking strategy, which was implemented to protect our overfunded pension plan status. We reallocated our investments to lower return asset categories, which reduced our pension income. Over U.S. qualified plants have $6.4 billion in assets. These are 108% funded and have lost very little value during the recent market disruptions. Our de-risking strategy made a lot of sense last summer and even more now. We are one of the few U.S. companies and the only one of our peers with an overfunded pension plan and we are careful to protect that value. 
We have a very disciplined approach to realizing our synergies and performance improvements across our businesses and functions. We are executing on the opportunities and projects to reach our $1 billion goal and are on track to reach this target by the end of fiscal 2018. Our entire company is critically focused on delivering on and exceeding our goal. Work spans many areas. We are realizing procurement and logistics savings using the power of the expanded size of our company to our advantage and purchasing around the world. We are benefiting from our comprehensive mill system, maximizing our ability to produce the right products in the right locations and in-sourcing paperboard throughout the system. And we are continuing to use best practices from each former company to develop the right models and streamline our businesses and corporate functions across of the company. 
We continue to make capital investments in our mills and converting operations with projects that reduce costs. Based on the strength of these and other initiatives, we exited the quarter at an annualized run rate of more than $250 million and are on track to achieve at least $450 million by the end of fiscal 2016. Adjusted segment EBITDA declined $68 million due primarily to the reductions in Specialty Chemicals, land and development business and the reduction in pension income. Adjusted EBITDA of our core consumer and Corrugated Packaging businesses and corporate expenses, excluding pension income, increased by $15 million. During the quarter, we generated $88 million in productivity, which demonstrates our continued focus and progress in this area. Our productivity more than offsets the negative impact of volume price and other negative market factors. We continue to benefit from deflation in key energy categories. 
Before turning it back to Steve, I want to take a minute to discuss our gas flow outlook and assumptions. We generate significant cash flow, and that is likely the key metric that has not been fully appreciated in this stock market. For fiscal 2016, we are forecasting cash flow provided by operations of between $1.8 billion and $1.825 billion, and capital expenditures in the range of $825 million to $850 million. As Steve reported, our net free cash flow should be in the range of $950 million to $1 billion. 
We are including Ingevity's results in this outlook for the 7-month period that they we will be part of WestRock, and they will be excluded for the remaining 5 months. However, Ingevity's operating cash flow is equal to the forecasted capital expenditures for the period, as they are finishing their growth initiatives in China and Brazil and the winner is their seasonally slower time of the year. Our outlook reflects a view on the impact of recent PPW price changes on our Corrugated Packaging segment. 
Looking into the March quarter, there's a lot to be excited about in our business as we continue to execute on our strategy. From a financial standpoint, there are more seasonal headwinds in the March quarter on a sequential basis. We will have more energy usage due to the winter weather, and we will have some impact from the recent snowstorm that blanketed much of the Northeast. What would be more expensive than in the December quarter. In addition, the labor cost pool also resets with annual salary increases beginning, as well as the new year employment-related taxes. The mill is undergoing a major maintenance outage in March that will have a $10 million impact on income in the quarter. 
In the corrugated business, export pricing will likely continue, with some softening in pricing. Currencies will also have -- like we have some negative impact on the quarter. We will continue to deliver an our productivity and synergy improvement program, which is creating a lot of value. When all of this is taken into account, we expect that the March quarter will be lower on an adjusted EPS as compared to the $0.59 posted in December. I will now turn the call back over to Steve.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mark. Before I open the call for questions, let me summarize by saying, we're very pleased with our solid execution and progress we've made and continue to make building the premier global packaging company. Today, we have leading positions in our
componenttext: Thanks, Mark. Before I open the call for questions, let me summarize by saying, we're very pleased with our solid execution and progress we've made and continue to make building the premier global packaging company. Today, we have leading positions in our markets. We're expanding our customer relationships through our comprehensive offering across a broad geographic footprint. We're realizing the strategic benefits of the merger and remain on track for achieving our productivity improvement targets. We're confident in our ability to successfully execute our growth strategy and generate strong cash flow, enabling us to deliver value for our stockholders and customers. With that, we're pleased to respond your questions.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016

componenttext: My two questions will be, to the extent you can comment around cash flow and EBITDA. And if we assume no changes in prices going forward, because, obviously, you can't do that. When we rework the free cash flow guidance, we would get EBITDA somewhere in the range of about $2.1 billion. Is there a way that you could comment to whether that's a reasonable forecast at this juncture? And if not, can you remind us of any other large cash items we should be thinking about, cash interest, cash taxes, that you didn't show on Slide 14?

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016

componenttext: George, I'm going to have Ward respond to that.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: George, again, what we provided was free cash flow guidance of $950 million to $1 billion. We also included the pension in postretirement funding, working capital assumptions in our books tax rate of 34% to 36%. The other things to consider, the DNA we ha
componenttext: George, again, what we provided was free cash flow guidance of $950 million to $1 billion. We also included the pension in postretirement funding, working capital assumptions in our books tax rate of 34% to 36%. The other things to consider, the DNA we have $294 million of DNA in the quarter. Ingevity's about $7 million to $8 million so we will have the DNA for them through the 7-month period. Cash taxes will be less than booked. Share-based comp will be a source. Equity and income and unconsolidated affiliates would be investment in Gondi will actually be used. These and other balance sheet items over the course of the year should generate between $0 million and $25 million of source for the remainder of the year.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just my other question, because I appreciate all the detail, I'm going to switch to just the outlook. Can you comment at all in terms of how bookings have been thus far in the quarter? Just an overall comment about how the corrugated markets in p
componenttext: And then just my other question, because I appreciate all the detail, I'm going to switch to just the outlook. Can you comment at all in terms of how bookings have been thus far in the quarter? Just an overall comment about how the corrugated markets in particular have been, early in fiscal Q2?

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, George, Jim Porter. First, I'd like to highlight how excited I am about the progress with our corrugated container business has made, just continue to make progress in so many areas. The investments that we've made in our people and processe
componenttext: Good morning, George, Jim Porter. First, I'd like to highlight how excited I am about the progress with our corrugated container business has made, just continue to make progress in so many areas. The investments that we've made in our people and processes and capital equipment improvements have really given us exceptional quality and service for our customers that's being rewarded by increased business. And I'd highlight that with we've had 12 months in a row in which our box shipments have exceeded the FDA industry. So we're quite proud of the progress being made. Just last quarter, we were up 2.9% on a per day basis, and that demand continues to be strong. Now we're, after 12 months of exceptional growth, we're going to be entering a period where the comps are getting tougher. But current demand, as evidenced by our backlogs, continues to be strong. Now as Steve mentioned, we've had some weather events at the start of January to probably put a dent in those numbers, but we expect that by the end of the quarter, we should be flat on a year-over-year basis.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Mr. Mark Weintraub of Buckingham Research.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Mr. Mark Weintraub of Buckingham Research.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I want just to follow-up, Steve, you have mentioned that, that $950 million to $1 billion of free cash flow on a per share basis where the share count today is $375 million. But of course, you do have the share repurchase authorization in place for an add
componenttext: I want just to follow-up, Steve, you have mentioned that, that $950 million to $1 billion of free cash flow on a per share basis where the share count today is $375 million. But of course, you do have the share repurchase authorization in place for an additional 30-plus million shares. And given the free cash flow, given the dividend that comes in from Ingevity, given that you're below your targeted capital rate, presumably, you're in a position to act fairly aggressively and perhaps expeditiously on that share repurchase. I was hoping to get a sense as to what your thought on the timing might be. And just to throw in there a part of the question is when the share purchase program was originally authorized, this talk was north of 60, now it's closer to 30. Were you conceiving of the repurchase as a dollar amount conceptually internally or as a number of shares. And given if the share price were to stay at this bargain basement level, would you potential be in a position to buy back even more over time?

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark, when we announced the merger, we had our balance capital allocation strategy, and we have the authorization for 40 million shares. I feel that we followed through on that very well, with the purchase of 9.5 million shares. When I think about balance
componenttext: Mark, when we announced the merger, we had our balance capital allocation strategy, and we have the authorization for 40 million shares. I feel that we followed through on that very well, with the purchase of 9.5 million shares. When I think about balanced capital allocation, I look at the opportunities that we have to invest in our business, make acquisitions and buy back stock. And I will tell you, based on the current price, the share buyback has risen in attractiveness to us. Just the cash flow that we have, the dividend that we'll pay, it's attractive for us to buy back stock. With respect to aggressive timing, I think we'll just see how the quarter goes. I can't really speak to that, can't comment. But I can tell you buyback was much March active than it was when the price was higher.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016

componenttext: We've considered that. I think as we've gone along and the advice we've gotten is not the most efficient way to buy back stock. We've been able to buy 9.5 million of share repurchase but never say never, when we consider we concluded the  open-market routes then a more efficient way for us to buy back stock.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. The other question I have is on the box's corrugated market. I wonder, Jim Porter, if you can give us kind of an update on kind of global boxboard markets. Across all 3 of your substrates, and I guess we're thinking about new capacity over in Europe
componenttext: Okay. The other question I have is on the box's corrugated market. I wonder, Jim Porter, if you can give us kind of an update on kind of global boxboard markets. Across all 3 of your substrates, and I guess we're thinking about new capacity over in Europe but also what effect all of that to the Chinese capacity is having in global markets around the world? Sounds like we're even seeing some of the that coming into the U.S. now.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, Mark. I'm going to have Bob Beckler take the lead on that and I'll piggyback is necessary.
componenttext: Good morning, Mark. I'm going to have Bob Beckler take the lead on that and I'll piggyback is necessary.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hi, Mark. Let me just do a quick run through, starting with CRB and CNK, where backlogs are up from a year-on-year standpoint. Although sequentially, we have seen some expected easing that's really seasonality. Overall, we're in good balance from a supply
componenttext: Hi, Mark. Let me just do a quick run through, starting with CRB and CNK, where backlogs are up from a year-on-year standpoint. Although sequentially, we have seen some expected easing that's really seasonality. Overall, we're in good balance from a supply/demand standpoint and the markets are generally stable. On SBS, the demand that we're seeing in the higher-end premium markets where we concentrate our efforts has been stable to up slightly. And that's a global statement. Backlogs are stable and pricing is stable. And considering the internalization that Steve mentioned in his opening comments, which came from opportunities to the merger created to the recent acquisition of the Cenveo Packaging business to the acquisition last year of the Carolina commercial print business, this brings a lot of SBS into our system that we are now producing internally. And so in terms of near-term outlook, we'll be up solidly. Now specific to Europe, what we see there is imports are attempting to penetrate, primarily in the more commodity end of the market, such as general markets and food service plate stock where we have less of a position. So in terms of direct impact for us, it's really been 0 out of Europe. And then in terms of Chinese imports, which I believe was your question, again, we're not seeing a significant impact there. The hurdles are fairly high at this stage for competition on that front. We have an advantage cost position. Again, we focus on a very diverse range of higher-end markets. We have quality advantage. And not to mention, there's a very high hurdle rate around the very complex supply chain that exists. It's a very complicated market to serve with very demanding customers and service requirements that we are well positioned. So net-net, not much effect that we're seeing from an import standpoint.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016

componenttext: Yes, Mark, that was one specific customer in our liquid packaging sector that occurred 7 or 8 months ago. Just to add to the comment, we're obviously, offsetting that with the moves that I outlined earlier and continued modest growth in the premium sectors that we focus on such as tobacco, food service, stock and commercial print.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just want to go back for a minute to the SP Fiber acquisition because since then, you've posted about 675,000 tons of capacity and you have a couple of key comments here in the presentation on the rationale for the acquisition. But can you just maybe go
componenttext: I just want to go back for a minute to the SP Fiber acquisition because since then, you've posted about 675,000 tons of capacity and you have a couple of key comments here in the presentation on the rationale for the acquisition. But can you just maybe go a little bit deeper on what exactly SP Fiber provides maybe as -- from a product portfolio perspective that you didn't have before, or couldn't get by investing in your own system?

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Jim.
componenttext: Sure, Jim.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, I'll take that, Steve. First of all, we are really excited about the opportunity to have acquired SP assets, specifically the Dublin Georgia mill. And I think the proposition goes back to how we look at our markets and our quest to improve the cost
componenttext: Sure, I'll take that, Steve. First of all, we are really excited about the opportunity to have acquired SP assets, specifically the Dublin Georgia mill. And I think the proposition goes back to how we look at our markets and our quest to improve the cost of the system. But you've seen us behave consistently in the way that we've matched our supply with demand. And over the last number of quarters, we've tried to balance our system through a combination of temporary shutdowns, slowbacks and permanent closures to try to get our system in just the right balance with our demand. The acquisition of SP Fiber in October gave us the capability to add 575,000 tons of really excellent quality low-cost, lightweight packaging grade papers in the center of our neural network of supply chain. And so that gave us the ability to build a very granular plan in order to improve the cost structure and service capability of our system. And so that allowed us to first permanently close the Coshocton mill in November. Secondly, to close permanently the Newberg news plant and packaging grade mill at November. And the latest move to close Uncasville medium mills, which will be permanently shut by January 31. So this acquisition has given us the ability to provide very good quality market demand substrates in a lower costs, both fixed and operating, and has allowed us to balance supply and demand in a much more efficient way, taking 675,000 tons out of the market. So I hope that gets to

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's great. Steve, just following up on that. Since you've done the merger, you did the 2 acquisitions, SP Fiber, Cenveo, and then also the JV. Obviously, acquisition have been a key part of the WestRock going back to RockTenn story, historically. Do yo
componenttext: That's great. Steve, just following up on that. Since you've done the merger, you did the 2 acquisitions, SP Fiber, Cenveo, and then also the JV. Obviously, acquisition have been a key part of the WestRock going back to RockTenn story, historically. Do you see that continuing going forward, or are you reaching sort of a maximum capacity as far as, obviously, not from the leverage perspective, but from a management bandwidth perspective to keep these smaller bolt-on acquisitions or should we see them continue at this pace going forward?

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: This a great question, Scott. I don't think it's a function of management bandwidth. I could say a function of priorities. And if you look at the opportunities that we have, we have an incredible opportunity to operate our businesses while even better tha
componenttext: This a great question, Scott. I don't think it's a function of management bandwidth. I could say a function of priorities. And if you look at the opportunities that we have, we have an incredible opportunity to operate our businesses while even better than they have. We have a very, let's say, a lot of opportunity to be more money to the bottom line through the focus on business. And so when I look at our priorities, I think acquisitions probably less of a relative priority than it might have been in the past because it is the opportunities we have to combine our organizations and go-to-market and operating even more efficiently. So I think internal focus is  probably relatively greater priority than it would have been to me previously. Now having said that, the acquisitions that we've made I think have been strategic, have been helpful to our business. So we'll continue to look at them. I just don't see them as, in response your questions, high priority like they might have been in the past.

componenttext: Good morning, Chip. I'd have to say, yes, we were very surprised to say, specifically, linerboard and white top linerboard published down by $15. We simply have not seen version containerboard down in the market. We have seen and heard of customers discounting some of the smaller recycled, principally medium volume in the market. However, our linerboard and light top has not been dropped. Those factor really supported by the fact that our domestic containerboard prices, excluding the addition of the recent SP mill, which we're fitting into our system has been flat year-over-year and flat sequentially. So we're just simply not seeing that priced off, particularly in the grade so we were very surprised by that.

componenttext: Inventories are something we very granularity manage for the on-time delivery and service required both by our internal and external customers to meet their demands. We haven't seen over the past couple of years that we are benefited by generally increasing our standard levels of inventory. That save big dividends in our ability to serve our corrugated box customers. As we think about inventories, particularly with downtime season, we do build volume. And while we have just gone through a sequential decline in our internal inventories, you will see us building somewhere in the 90,000-ton range over the next couple of months, which will then be absorbed by our annual shutdown schedule and then you get to the end of the fiscal year, we should be back at par with our standard inventory level. So that's how we look at our system.

componenttext: I'm glad you asked that question because we've gone through I think a fair amount of thinking about that question ourselves. I think I'd start with we're a paper and packaging company. We have put in place, I think, a very strong management team and the business is going to perform better on it's own than it would be as part of WestRock. I think can go through the alternatives, and I think this spin makes the most sense. You can say well, maybe I could look at some other attractive because, frankly, this is for the shareholders and for WestRock, it's the most effective force to be. I think going to May, I think it's going to help team get off to a good start and they are going to be able to put together, I think a very compelling story for investors in the value of Ingevity.

componenttext: Steve, this is Bob Beckler, great question. And its just one of the benefits of the merger that we're continuing to realize and gain momentum. Within the largest customers of WestRock, there is overlap between our packaging lines of business and, in some cases, packaging and paperboard. And it's substantial. The number I think we included in one of our Slides is that our top $2 billion of customers participate in multiple product lines. If you just take those customers with the upside that we see from addressable market standpoint, we could send additional $1 billion of opportunity just in that customer set. So it's still a work in progress, but customers are definitely recognizing the benefits of, you call it a one-stop shop but it's really unique in the global industry to have this many capabilities under one roof.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you for standing by, and welcome to the WestRock's Fiscal 2016 First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. This call will be an hour in duration. [Operator Instructions] This call is being recorded. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this
componenttext:
Thank you for standing by, and welcome to the WestRock's Fiscal 2016 First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. This call will be an hour in duration. [Operator Instructions] This call is being recorded. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this time. 
I'd now like to turn the call over to Mr. Steve Voorhees. Sir, you may begin.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Welcome to our conference call. I'm Steve Voorhees, Chief Executive Officer. I'm joined this morning by Ward Dickson, Chief Financial Officer; Jim Porter, President of our Paper Solutions business; and Bob Beckler, President of our Packaging
componenttext:
Good morning. Welcome to our conference call. I'm Steve Voorhees, Chief Executive Officer. I'm joined this morning by Ward Dickson, Chief Financial Officer; Jim Porter, President of our Paper Solutions business; and Bob Beckler, President of our Packaging Solutions business. 
During the course of the call, we will make forward-looking statements involving our plans, expectations, estimates and beliefs related to future events. Statements may involve a number of risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those that we discuss during the call. We describe these risks and uncertainties in our filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including our 10-K for the fiscal year ending September 30, 2015. We'll refer to non-GAAP financial measures during the call. We've provided reconciliations of these non-GAAP measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measures in the Appendix of the slide presentation, which is available on our website. 
Before we share the details about the quarter, I'd like to comment on one of the questions I get asked most frequently these days, which is how the merger integration going. Pleased to report the merger integration is going extremely well, I believe, even more strongly today than the strategic rationale of the merger than I did when we announced the merger one year ago. We have the first or second leading positions in attractive global packaging markets, and we're aggressively working to maximize the opportunities of the merger while improving operational efficiency across our organization. We've executing on and making meaningful progress with realizing our $1 billion in synergy and performance improvement opportunities.
Culturally, we're building an outstanding WestRock team that's aligned and focused on building the premier global packaging company. 
Our customers are very interested in using innovation to increase their sales and reducing their cost to increase their profitability. WestRock's suite of paper packaging and merchandising products and services, across a multinational platform, is enabling us to engage with customers in ways that no other company can. We're an integrated, global packaging solutions provider, and this is resonating with our customers. We're executing on our strategy, and we're working well together while doing so. We're taking advantage of the opportunities to improve our business through our investment in people, assets and acquisitions.
WestRock is a compelling value creation opportunity. We're well positioned to deliver value for stockholders. We're strong believers in managing the business to generate cash, we've aligned our strategy and to do just that. During our first 6 months of operation, we generated $609 million or $2.33 per share and free cash flow after adding back after-tax cash, merger and integration-related restructuring cost. For this fiscal year, we expect to generate in the range of $950 million to $1 billion free cash flow or approximately $3.75 per share based on our current share count. 
We've demonstrated our commitment to returning capital to stockholders. We've repurchased 9.5 million shares over the past 7 months and are paying an annual dividend of about $400 million. We intend to maintain our dividend after the spin of Specialty Chemicals. At yesterday's closing stock price, our current yield of 4.7% would increase to over 5% after completion of the spin.
Let's turn to the financial results for the quarter. WestRock sales for the quarter were $3.7 billion, and adjusted earnings per share were $0.59. Our last 12 months credit agreement EBITDA margin was 16.9%. These returns are largely in line with expectations. 
Our Corrugated Packaging business has performed well, with strong growth in box sales in the United States. We've managed our supply with our customer demand, and as a result, we've permanently closed 3 mills: Coshocton, MeadWestvaco and Uncasville with total annual capacity of 675,000 tons.
Our Brazilian Corrugated Packaging operations continued to perform exceptionally well. This business is providing great current returns and also providing attractive investment opportunities to improve our returns over the next several years.
We've added SP Fiber and some bale packaging businesses to our platform. We expect to complete our joint venture with Grupo Gondi during the first half of calendar year 2016. All 3 transactions add to the strength of our business. 
We've repurchased 4.1 million shares of our common stock since November. To date, we've bought back 9.5 million shares under our $40 million share repurchase authorization. We've reassessed our valuation for Specialty Chemicals business in light of changing market conditions and financial performance and lower comparative market valuations for their peer group. We've reduced the estimated enterprise value for Specialty Chemicals business and the purchase accounting value recorded last July to approximately $1.6 billion. As a result, we've recorded a noncash goodwill impairment charge of $478 million.
We're making progress on the spin of Ingevity. Earlier this month, we received a private letter ruling from the Internal Revenue Service to positively address each issue. We need this have addressed for the spin, including the removal of additional limitations on WestRock stock repurchases. We anticipate completion of the spin by early May, later than previously announced, due to the inherent complexities of the separation process. 
The Corrugated Packaging team delivered outstanding results across our North American box business, with box shipments up 2.9% on a per day basis. Box prices were stable sequentially. All regions of the United States did well, although we did have a slight decline in the west, principally due to a decline in produce volumes. 
We had particularly strong performance in e-commerce. We shipped 530,000 tons to domestic and export markets, including approximately 280,000 tons to domestic markets and 250,000 tons to export markets.  Without SP Fiber, domestic shipments were 86,000 tons less than last year, and our prices were essentially flat sequentially. Export channels continue to be price competitive. Overall export pricing was down $9 per ton on a sequential-quarter basis. 
We actively managed our system to meet our customer demand and took 264,000 tons of economic and maintenance downtime in the quarter. The incremental cost of the economic downtime was $11 million year-over-year. The closure of the Uncasville and Coshocton mills will reduce our annual operating cost by $25 million. 
The cumulative impact of these actions has balanced our containerboard system. We made solid gains in productivity with incremental contribution to pretax income of $36 million over last year. 
Brazil continued to perform very well, both individually and compared to the rest of the Brazilian market, with EBITDA margins of 24.8%. The trade saw mill in our virgin fiber supply are competitive advantage in this market. WestRock's box shipments increased 1% compared to the prior year. This is significantly more than the overall market in Brazil, which declined by 5%.
Turning to the Consumer Packaging segment. Our adjusted EBITDA margin of 14.2% grew by 160 basis points over last year. This is driven by strong performance in our packaging businesses, overall stable consumer mill volumes, productivity gains and energy deflation. Price and the mix were stable for the quarter. External SBS volumes from our mill system were modestly down, largely related to the loss of a customer last year.  Otherwise, we're seeing good growth in premium applications, including tobacco, commercial print and food service income. While the SBS market is challenged by slow demand and processed food applications, we're continuing to perform well across the diversified mix of end markets that we serve. We've seen a small amount of foreign competition in more commodity portions of the market, such as food service, freight and general markets. But this has not had an appreciable impact on our business.
In addition to external SBS sales, we're making good progress internalizing approximately 100,000 tons of incremental SBS production into our converting system, some opportunities identified during the merger, the recent acquisition of some bales packaging businesses.
Also in the quarter, we continued the integration of more than 150,000 tons of the Carolina commercial print business that we acquired last year. This production transitioned fully to our SBS system earlier this month. The net results of the gains and internal converting them to Carolina acquisition increased the loading and production efficiencies for SBS mill system. The combined CNK and beverage packaging businesses delivered a good quarter, as modest growth in global beer markets offset declines in carbonated soft drink volumes, particularly in North America. 
Our CRB mills operated well during the quarter and was executed on the $50 per ton price increase announced less summer. With the Cenveo Packaging acquisition, we will internalize an additional 5,000 tons of CRB into our system. 
Our folding carton converting business continues to perform well. Volumes exceeded of the overall market. Pricing was slightly down as contract renewals were competitive and some food customers experienced declining volumes. Home, health and beauty had a very good quarter, with strong European volumes more than offsetting some weakness in North America. Margin continues to improve with good mix, cost management and productivity.
Merchandising display sales declined due to lower commercial activity with key customers. The core business remains attractive, and we're continuing to optimize the fixed cost structure of this business to improve the profitability.
Turning to Specialty Chemicals. Depressed oil prices have reduced demand for oilfield chemicals and certain industry products. This has made competing petroleum-based chemistries more economical.
Total sales during the quarter declined by $31 million compared to last year. Segment EBITDA of $32 million was a little more than half of last year's quarter. Segment profitability also reflected $8.5 million in outage in China start-up expenses. The December quarter is seasonally the softest quarter for this business. 
Ingevity's annual revenue is running at more than $900 million, and adjusted EBITDA is now at an annual rate of approximately $200 million. The oilfield services business is now less than 10% of annual revenue at approximately $80 million. This business is relatively smaller compared to the total business. We achieved record quarterly sales for activated carbon and asphalt additive products. We have good growth engines in the asphalt additives and automotive carbon, including the new automotive carbon plant that's starting up in China. We have a strong profitable business, a very strong management team and the scale with which to operate as a successful public company. The long-term fundamentals of the business are sound and will make for a compelling growth equity story. Post spin, Ingevity will have reasonable leverage at about 2.5x EBITDA. This will provide an immediate cash inflow of approximately $400 million to WestRock at the time of the spin, plus funding an additional $80 million of security for a capital lease retained by WestRock. 
Our land business results reflected purchase price accounting step up with the assets to fair market value as of July 1 merger closing. The step up effectively removes what the anticipated development profit was at that time. This has no effect on cash flow, only on reported earnings.
Most important thing to know about this segment is that we're operating in Charlestown, one of the healthiest real estate markets in the country. We're looking at ways to monetize our portfolio faster than the normal development process would allow. We've already make some progress on certain projects, and we expect to do more on this front. 
Over the last several months, we completed the SP Fiber and Cenveo Packaging acquisitions, with a total investment of approximately $400 million. Both SP Fiber and Cenveo Packaging are great strategic fits with our business and strategy. We believe these businesses will generate excellent returns on investment.
We expect to complete the Grupo Gondi joint venture investment in the next couple of months. Mexico is very important to our customers and to us, due to its proximity to the United States and its strong growth profile. We've been looking from a long time for the right opportunity to grow our capabilities in Mexico, and I believe that the partnership with Grupo Gondi is the best way for WestRock to grow in Mexico. WestRock will contribute $175 million in cash in our 3 Mexican box plants, and Grupo Gondi will contribute their business. Based on current exchange rates in the last 12 months results, the joint venture on a pro forma basis has generated $670 million in sales and $135 million in EBITDA. Our box plants have generated about 10% to 15% of the $135 million. We will have a 25% interest in the joint venture, and the joint venture will have net positive cash on its balance sheet when the joint venture is formed. The cash that we're contributing will be invested by the joint venture to support growth. WestRock will continue to provide the 200,000 tons that we supplied to our 3 box plants, and we'll have continuing opportunities to supply additional tons if the joint venture grows. We're currently executing on an opportunity to supply 25,000 tons of kraftliner to Gondi that we were not supplying 6 months ago. We will have an opportunity to build upon our combined relationships and capabilities to grow in the attractive paper and packaging markets of Mexico. 
Now I'll turn it over to Ward for additional details.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Steve. Total non-allocated expenses were $4.5 million in the current quarter. We reduced corporate expenses by $21 million, and this is included as part of our $250 million synergy and productivity performance.Our non-service pension income i
componenttext:
Thank you, Steve. Total non-allocated expenses were $4.5 million in the current quarter. We reduced corporate expenses by $21 million, and this is included as part of our $250 million synergy and productivity performance.
Our non-service pension income is $25 million lower than the $47 million recorded last year. This was principally a result of our pension derisking strategy, which was implemented to protect our overfunded pension plan status. We reallocated our investments to lower return asset categories, which reduced our pension income. Over U.S. qualified plans have $6.4 billion in assets. These are 108% funded and have lost very little value during the recent market disruptions. Our derisking strategy made a lot of sense last summer and even more now. We are one of the few U.S. companies and the only one of our peers with an overfunded pension plan and we are careful to protect that value. 
We have a very disciplined approach to realizing our synergies and performance improvements across our businesses and functions. We are executing on the opportunities and projects to reach our $1 billion goal and are on track to reach this target by the end of fiscal 2018. Our entire company is critically focused on delivering on and exceeding our goal. Work spans many areas. We are realizing procurement and logistics savings using the power of the expanded size of our company to our advantage and purchasing around the world. We are benefiting from our comprehensive mill system, maximizing our ability to produce the right products in the right locations and in-sourcing paperboard throughout the system. And we are continuing to use best practices from each former company to develop the right models and streamline our businesses and corporate functions across of the company.
We continue to make capital investments in our mills and converting operations, with projects that reduce costs. Based on the strength of these and other initiatives, we exited the quarter at an annualized run rate of more than $250 million and are on track to achieve at least $450 million by the end of fiscal 2016. Adjusted segment EBITDA declined $68 million, due primarily to the reductions in Specialty Chemicals, land and development business and the reduction in pension income. Adjusted EBITDA of our core Consumer and Corrugated Packaging businesses and corporate expenses, excluding pension income, increased by $15 million. During the quarter, we generated $88 million in productivity, which demonstrates our continued focus on progress in this area. Our productivity more than offsets the negative impact of volume price and other negative market factors. We continue to benefit from deflation in key energy categories.
Before turning it back to Steve, I want to take a minute to discuss our cash flow outlook and assumptions. We generate significant cash flow, and that is likely the key metric that has not been fully appreciated in this stock market. For fiscal 2016, we are forecasting cash flow provided by operation of between $1.8 billion and $1.825 billion and capital expenditures in the range of $825 million to $850 million. As Steve reported, our net free cash flow should be in the range of $950 million to $1 billion. 
We are including Ingevity's results in this outlook for the 7-month period that they we will be part of WestRock, and they will be excluded the remaining 5 months. However, Ingevity's operating cash flow is equal to the forecasted capital expenditures for the period, as they are finishing their growth initiatives in China and Brazil and the winner is their seasonally slower time of the year. Our outlook reflects a view on the impact of recent PPW price changes on our Corrugated Packaging segment. 
Looking into the March quarter, there's a lot to be excited about in our business as we continue to execute on our strategy. From our financial standpoint, there are more seasonal headwinds in the March quarter on a sequential basis. We will have more energy usage due to the winter weather, and we will have some impact from the recent snowstorm that blanketed much of the Northeast. Wood will be more expensive than in the December quarter. In addition, the labor cost pool also resets with annual salary increases beginning as well as the New Year and employment-related taxes. The Mahrt mill is undergoing a major maintenance outage in March that will have a $10 million impact on income in the quarter. 
In the corrugated business, export pricing will likely continue, with some softening in pricing. Currencies will also have -- likely have some negative impact on the quarter. We will continue to deliver an our productivity and synergy improvement program, which is creating a lot of value. When all of this is taken into account, we expect that the March quarter will be lower on an adjusted EPS as compared to the $0.59 posted in December. 
I will now turn the call back over to Steve.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mark. Before I open the call for questions, let me summarize by saying, we're very pleased with our solid execution and the progress we've made and continue to make building the premier global packaging company. Today, we have leading positions in
componenttext:
Thanks, Mark. Before I open the call for questions, let me summarize by saying, we're very pleased with our solid execution and the progress we've made and continue to make building the premier global packaging company. Today, we have leading positions in our markets. We're expanding our customer relationships through our comprehensive offering across a broad geographic footprint. We're realizing the strategic benefits of the merger and remain on track for achieving our productivity improvement targets. We're confident in our ability to successfully execute our growth strategy and generate strong cash flow, enabling us to deliver value for our stockholders and customers. 
With that, we're pleased to respond to your questions.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question is coming from Mr. George Staphos.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question is coming from Mr. George Staphos.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: My 2 questions will be, to the extent you can comment around cash flow and EBITDA. And if we assume no changes in prices going forward because, obviously, you can't do that. When we rework the free cash flow guidance, we would get EBITDA somewhere in the
componenttext: My 2 questions will be, to the extent you can comment around cash flow and EBITDA. And if we assume no changes in prices going forward because, obviously, you can't do that. When we rework the free cash flow guidance, we would get EBITDA somewhere in the range of about $2.1 billion. Is there a way that you could comment to whether that's a reasonable forecast at this juncture? And if not, can you remind us of any other large cash items we should be thinking about, cash interest, cash taxes, that you didn't show on Slide 14?

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016

componenttext: George, I'm going to have Ward respond to that.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: George, again, on what we provided was free cash flow guidance of $950 million to $1 billion. We also included the pension in postretirement funding, working capital assumptions in our books tax rate of 34% to 36%. The other things to consider is the DNA.
componenttext: George, again, on what we provided was free cash flow guidance of $950 million to $1 billion. We also included the pension in postretirement funding, working capital assumptions in our books tax rate of 34% to 36%. The other things to consider is the DNA. We had $294 million of DNA in the quarter. Ingevity's about $7 million to $8 million a month. So we will have the DNA for them for the remaining 3- to 7-month period. Cash taxes will be less than book. Share-based comp will be a source. Equity and income and unconsolidated affiliates with the investment in Gondi will actually be a use. These and other balance sheet items over the course of the year should generate between $0 million and $25 million of source for the remainder of the year.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016

componenttext: And then I guess my other question because I appreciate all the detail. I'm going to switch to just the outlook. Can you comment at all in terms of how bookings have been thus far in the quarter? Just an overall comment about how the corrugated markets, in particular, have been early in fiscal Q2?

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jim?
componenttext: Jim?

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, George, Jim Porter. First, I'd like to highlight how excited I am about the progress with our corrugated container business has made. It's just continued to make progress in so many areas. The investments that we've made in our people and pr
componenttext: Good morning, George, Jim Porter. First, I'd like to highlight how excited I am about the progress with our corrugated container business has made. It's just continued to make progress in so many areas. The investments that we've made in our people and processes and capital equipment improvements have really given us exceptional quality and service for our customers that's being rewarded by increased business. And I highlight that with -- we've had 12 months in a row in which we've -- our box shipments have exceeded the FBA industry. So we're quite proud of the progress being made. Just last quarter, we were up 2.9% on a per day basis, and that demand continues to be strong. Now we're -- after 12 months of exceptional growth, we're going to be entering a period where the comps are getting tougher. But current demand, as evidenced by our backlogs, continues to be strong. Now as Steve mentioned, we've had some weather events at the start of January that would probably put a dent in those numbers, but we expect that by the end of the quarter, we should be flat on a year-over-year basis.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Mr. Mark Weintraub of Buckingham Research.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Mr. Mark Weintraub of Buckingham Research.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I want just a follow-up. Steve, you had mentioned that, that $950 million to $1 billion of free cash flow on a per share basis where the share count today is $375 million. But of course, you do have the share repurchase authorization in place for an addit
componenttext: I want just a follow-up. Steve, you had mentioned that, that $950 million to $1 billion of free cash flow on a per share basis where the share count today is $375 million. But of course, you do have the share repurchase authorization in place for an additional 30-plus million shares. And given the free cash flow, given the dividend that comes in from Ingevity, given that you're below your targeted that capital rate, presumably, you're in a position to act fairly aggressively and perhaps expeditiously on that share repurchase. And I was hoping to get a sense as to what your thought on the timing might be. And just to throw in there as a part of the question is while -- when the share purchase program was originally authorized, the stock was north of 60, now it's closer to 30. Were you conceiving of the repurchase as a dollar amount conceptually internally or as a number of shares? And given that the if the share price were to stay at this bargain basement level, would you potential be in a position to buy back even more over time?

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark, when we announced the merger, we had our balance capital allocation strategy, and we had the authorization for 40 million shares. I feel like we'd follow through on that very well with the purchase of 9.5 million shares. I think when -- I think abou
componenttext: Mark, when we announced the merger, we had our balance capital allocation strategy, and we had the authorization for 40 million shares. I feel like we'd follow through on that very well with the purchase of 9.5 million shares. I think when -- I think about balance for capital allocation, I look at the opportunities that we have to invest in our business, make acquisitions and buy back stock. And I will tell you, based on the current price, the share buyback has risen in attractiveness to us. Just the cash flow that we have, the dividend that we'll pay, it's attractive for us to buy back stock. With respect to aggressive our timing, I think we'll just -- we'll see how the quarter goes. I can't really speak to exact comment, but I will tell you the buyback is much more attractive than it was when the price was higher.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Mr. Mark Wilde of BMO Capital.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Mr. Mark Wilde of BMO Capital.

componenttext: Just to follow on Mark's question, would you consider an accelerated repurchase program just to take advantage of stock at $31 or $32?

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've considered that. I think as we've gone along and the advice we've gotten is not the most efficient way to buy back stock. We've been able to buy 9.5 million shares without an accelerated share repurchase, but never say never, but when we considered,
componenttext: We've considered that. I think as we've gone along and the advice we've gotten is not the most efficient way to buy back stock. We've been able to buy 9.5 million shares without an accelerated share repurchase, but never say never, but when we considered, we concluded the open-market purchase routes in more efficient way for us to buy back stock.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then the other question I had is just on the boxboard markets. I wondered, Jim Porter, if you can give us kind of an update on kind of global boxboard markets across all 3 of your substrates? And I guess, we're thinking about new capacity over i
componenttext: Okay. And then the other question I had is just on the boxboard markets. I wondered, Jim Porter, if you can give us kind of an update on kind of global boxboard markets across all 3 of your substrates? And I guess, we're thinking about new capacity over in Europe but also what effect all of that Chinese capacity is having in global markets around the world? It sounds like we're even seeing some of the that coming to the U.S. now.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, Mark. I'm going to have Bob Beckler take the lead on that, and I'll piggyback as necessary.
componenttext: Good morning, Mark. I'm going to have Bob Beckler take the lead on that, and I'll piggyback as necessary.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hi, Mark. Let me just do a quick run through, starting with CRB and CNK, where backlogs are up from a year-on-year standpoint, although sequentially, we have seen some expected easing that's really seasonality. Overall, we're in good balance from a supply
componenttext: Hi, Mark. Let me just do a quick run through, starting with CRB and CNK, where backlogs are up from a year-on-year standpoint, although sequentially, we have seen some expected easing that's really seasonality. Overall, we're in good balance from a supply/demand standpoint, and the markets are generally stable. On SBS, the demand that we're seeing in the higher-end premium markets, where we concentrate our efforts, has been stable to up slightly. And that's a global statement. Backlogs are stable, and pricing is stable. And considering the internalization that Steve mentioned in his opening comments, which came from opportunities that the merger created to the recent acquisition of the Cenveo Packaging business to the acquisition last year of the Carolina commercial print business, this brings a lot of SBS into our system that we are now producing internally. And so in terms of near-term outlook, we'll be up solidly. Now specific to Europe, what we see there is imports are attempting to penetrate primarily in the more commodity end of the market, such as general markets and food service plate stock where we have less of a position. So in terms of direct impact for us, it's really been 0 out of Europe. And then in terms of Chinese imports, which I believe was your question, again, we're not seeing a significant impact there. The hurdles are fairly high at this stage for competition on that front. We have an advantage cost position. Again, we focus on a very diverse range of higher-end markets. We have a quality advantage. And not to mention, there's a very high hurdle rate around the very complex supply chain that exists. It's a very complicated market to serve with very demanding customers and service requirements that we are well positioned. So net-net, not much effect that we're seeing from an import standpoint.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016

componenttext: Yes, Mark, that was one specific customer in our liquid packaging sector that occurred about 7 or 8 months ago. We're -- just to add to the comment, we're, obviously, offsetting that with the moves that I outlined earlier and continued modest growth in the premium sectors that we focus on, such as tobacco, food service, cup stock and commercial print.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Mr. Scott Gaffner of Barclays.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Mr. Scott Gaffner of Barclays.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just want to go back for a minute to the SP Fiber acquisition because since then, you've closed about 675,000 tons of capacity and you had a couple of key comments here in the presentation on the rationale for the acquisition. But can you just maybe go
componenttext: I just want to go back for a minute to the SP Fiber acquisition because since then, you've closed about 675,000 tons of capacity and you had a couple of key comments here in the presentation on the rationale for the acquisition. But can you just maybe go a little bit deeper on what exactly SP Fiber provides maybe as from a product portfolio perspective that you didn't have before or couldn't get by investing in your own system?

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Jim.
componenttext: Sure, Jim.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll take that, Steve. First of all, we are really excited about the opportunity to have acquired SP asset, specifically the Dublin, Georgia mill. And I think the proposition goes back to how we look at our markets and our quest to improve the cost o
componenttext: Yes, I'll take that, Steve. First of all, we are really excited about the opportunity to have acquired SP asset, specifically the Dublin, Georgia mill. And I think the proposition goes back to how we look at our markets and our quest to improve the cost of the system. But you've seen us behave consistently in a way that we've matched our supply with demand. And over the last number of quarters, we've tried to balance our system through a combination of temporary shutdowns, slow backs and permanent closures to try to get our system in just the right balance with our demand. The acquisition of SP Fiber in October gave us the capability to add 575,000 tons of really excellent quality, low-cost, lightweight packaging grade papers in the center of our neural network of supply chain. And so that gave us the ability to build a very granular plan in order to improve the cost structure and service capability of our system. And so that allowed us to first permanently close the Coshocton mill in November; secondly, to close permanently the Newberg plant and packaging grade mill at November; and our latest move to close Uncasville medium mills, which will be permanently shut by January 31. So this acquisition has given us the ability to provide very good quality market demand substrates in a lower costs, both fixed and operating, and has allowed us to balance supply with demand in a much more efficient way, taking 675,000 tons out of the market. So I hope that gets already to our mills.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's great. Steve, just following up on that. Since you've done the merger, you did the 2 acquisitions, SP Fiber, Cenveo, and then also the JV. Obviously, acquisitions have been a key part of the WestRock going back to RockTenn story, historically. Do y
componenttext: That's great. Steve, just following up on that. Since you've done the merger, you did the 2 acquisitions, SP Fiber, Cenveo, and then also the JV. Obviously, acquisitions have been a key part of the WestRock going back to RockTenn story, historically. Do you see that continuing going forward? Or are you reaching sort of maximum capacity as far as, I mean, obviously, not from a leverage perspective, but from a management bandwidth perspective that keep these smaller bolt-on acquisitions? Or should we see them continue at this pace going forward?

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: This a great question, Scott. I don't think it's a function of management bandwidth, I could say, function of priorities. And if you look at the opportunities that we have, we have an incredible opportunity to operate our businesses while even better than
componenttext: This a great question, Scott. I don't think it's a function of management bandwidth, I could say, function of priorities. And if you look at the opportunities that we have, we have an incredible opportunity to operate our businesses while even better than they have. We have a very, let's say, a lot of opportunity to bring more money to the bottom line through the focus on our own business. And so when I look at our priorities, I think, acquisition is probably less of a relative priority than it might have been in the past, because the opportunities we have to combine our organization and go to market and operating even more efficiently. So I think internal focus is probably relatively greater priority than it would have been to me previously. Now having said that, the acquisitions that we've made, I think, have been strategic and have been helpful to our business. So we'll continue to look at them. I just don't see them as, in response your questions, high priority as they might have been in the past.
