headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you for standing by, and welcome to the WestRock's Fiscal 2016 First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. This call will be an hour in duration. [Operator Instructions] This call is being recorded. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this
componenttext:
Thank you for standing by, and welcome to the WestRock's Fiscal 2016 First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. This call will be an hour in duration. [Operator Instructions] This call is being recorded. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this time. 
I'd now like to turn the call over to Mr. Steve Voorhees. Sir, you may begin.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Welcome to our conference call. I'm Steve Voorhees, Chief Executive Officer. I'm joined this morning by Ward Dickson, Chief Financial Officer; Jim Porter, President of our Paper Solutions business; and Bob Beckler, President of our Packaging
componenttext:
Good morning. Welcome to our conference call. I'm Steve Voorhees, Chief Executive Officer. I'm joined this morning by Ward Dickson, Chief Financial Officer; Jim Porter, President of our Paper Solutions business; and Bob Beckler, President of our Packaging Solutions business. 
During the course of the call, we will make forward-looking statements involving our plans, expectations, estimates and beliefs related to future events. Statements may involve a number of risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those that we discuss during the call. We describe these risks and uncertainties in our filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including our 10-K for the fiscal year ending September 30, 2015. We'll refer to non-GAAP financial measures during the call. We've provided reconciliations of these non-GAAP measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measures in the appendix of the slide presentation, which is available on our website. 
Before we share the details about the quarter, I'd like to comment on one of the questions I get asked most frequently these days, which is how's the merger integration going. Pleased to report the merger integration is going extremely well, I believe even more strongly today in the strategic rationale of the merger than I did when we announced the merger one year ago. We have the first or second leading positions in attractive global packaging markets, and we're aggressively working to maximize the opportunities of the merger while improving operational efficiency across our organization. We've executing on and making meaningful progress toward realizing our $1 billion in synergy and performance improvement opportunities.
Culturally, we're building an outstanding WestRock team that's aligned and focused on building the premier global packaging company. 
Our customers are very interested in using innovation to increase their sales and reducing their cost to increase their profitability. WestRock's suite of paper packaging and merchandising products and services, across a multinational platform, is enabling us to engage with customers in ways that no other company can. We're an integrated, global packaging solutions provider, and this is resonating with our customers. We're executing on our strategy, and we're working well together while doing so. We're taking advantage of the opportunities to improve our business through our investment in people, assets and acquisitions.
WestRock is a compelling value creation opportunity. We're well positioned to deliver value for stockholders. We're strong believers in managing the business to generate cash, we've aligned our strategy and incentives to do just that. During our first 6 months of operation, we generated $609 million or $2.33 per share in free cash flow after adding back after-tax cash, merger and integration-related restructuring cost. For this fiscal year, we expect to generate in the range of $950 million to $1 billion free cash flow or approximately $3.75 per share based on our current share count. 
We've demonstrated our commitment to returning capital to stockholders. We've repurchased 9.5 million shares over the past 7 months and are paying an annual dividend of about $400 million. We intend to maintain our dividend after the spin of Specialty Chemicals. At yesterday's closing stock price, our current yield of 4.7% would increase to over 5% after completion of the spin.
Let's turn to the financial results for the quarter. WestRock sales for the quarter were $3.7 billion, and adjusted earnings per share were $0.59. Our last 12 months credit agreement EBITDA margin was 16.9%. These returns are largely in line with expectations. 
Our Corrugated Packaging business has performed well, with strong growth in box sales in the United States. We've managed our supply with our customer demand, and as a result, we've permanently closed 3 mills: Coshocton, Newberg and Uncasville with total annual capacity of 675,000 tons.
Our Brazilian Corrugated Packaging operations continued to perform exceptionally well. This business is providing great current returns and also providing attractive investment opportunities to improve our returns over the next several years.
We've added SP Fiber and Cenveo Packaging businesses to our platform. We expect to complete our joint venture with Grupo Gondi during the first half of calendar year 2016. All 3 transactions add to the strength of our business. 
We've repurchased 4.1 million shares of our common stock since November. To date, we've bought back 9.5 million shares under our $40 million share repurchase authorization. We've reassessed our valuation of the Specialty Chemicals business in light of changing market conditions and financial performance and lower comparative market valuations for their peer group. We've reduced the estimated enterprise value for Specialty Chemicals business and the purchase accounting value reported last July to approximately $1.6 billion. As a result, we've recorded a noncash goodwill impairment charge of $478 million.
We're making progress on the spin of Ingevity. Earlier this month, we received a private letter ruling from the Internal Revenue Service to positively address each issue we needed to have addressed for the spin, including the removal of additional limitations on WestRock stock repurchases. We anticipate completion of the spin by early May, later than previously announced, due to the inherent complexities of the separation process. 
The Corrugated Packaging team delivered outstanding results across our North American box business, with box shipments up 2.9% on a per day basis. Box prices were stable sequentially. All regions of the United States did well, although we did have a slight decline in the West, principally due to a decline in produce volumes. 
We had particularly strong performance in e-commerce. We shipped 530,000 tons to domestic and export markets, including approximately 280,000 tons to domestic markets and 250,000 tons to export markets. Without SP Fiber, domestic shipments were 86,000 tons less than last year, and our prices were essentially flat sequentially. Export channels continued to be price competitive. Overall export pricing was down $9 per ton on a sequential-quarter basis. 
We actively managed our system to meet our customer demand and took 264,000 tons of economic and maintenance downtime in the quarter. The incremental cost of the economic downtime was $11 million year-over-year. The closure of the Uncasville and Coshocton mills will reduce our annual operating cost by $25 million. 
The cumulative impact of these actions has balanced our containerboard system. We made solid gains in productivity with incremental contribution to the pretax income of $36 million over last year. 
Brazil continued to perform very well, both individually and compared to the rest of the Brazilian market, with EBITDA margins of 24.8%. The Trs Barras mill and our virgin fiber supply are a competitive advantage in this market. WestRock's box shipments increased 1% compared to the prior year. This is significantly more than the overall market in Brazil, which declined by 5%.
Turning to the Consumer Packaging segment. Our adjusted EBITDA margin of 14.2% grew by 160 basis points over last year. This is driven by strong performance in our packaging businesses, overall stable consumer mill volumes, productivity gains and energy deflation. Price and the mix were stable for the quarter. External SBS volumes from our mill system were modestly down, largely related to the loss of a customer last year. Otherwise, we're seeing good growth in premium applications, including tobacco, commercial print and food service cup. While the SBS market is challenged by slow demand and processed food applications, we're continuing to perform well across the diversified mix of end markets that we serve. We've seen a small amount of foreign competition in more commodity portions of the market, such as food service, plate and general markets. But this has not had an appreciable impact on our business.
In addition to external SBS sales, we're making good progress internalizing approximately 100,000 tons of incremental SBS production into our converting system, some opportunities identified during the merger -- the recent acquisition of Cenveo's packaging businesses.
Also in the quarter, we continued the integration of more than 150,000 tons of the Carolina commercial print business that we acquired last year. This production transitioned fully to our SBS system earlier this month. The net results of the gains and internal converting in the Carolina acquisition increased the loading and production efficiencies for our SBS and mill system. The combined CNK and beverage packaging businesses delivered a good quarter, as modest growth in global beer markets offset declines in carbonated soft drink volumes, particularly in North America. 
Our CRB mills operated well during the quarter and we've executed on the $50 per ton price increase announced last summer. With the Cenveo Packaging acquisition we will internalize an additional 5,000 tons of CRB into our system. 
Our folding carton converting business continues to perform well. Volumes growth exceeded that of the overall market. Pricing was slightly down as contract renewals were competitive and some food customers experienced declining volumes. Home, health and beauty had a very good quarter, with strong European volumes more than offsetting some weakness in North America. Margin continues to improve with good mix, cost management and productivity.
Merchandising display sales declined due to lower commercial activity with key customers. The core business remains attractive, and we're continuing to optimize the fixed cost structure of this business to improve profitability.
Turning to Specialty Chemicals. Depressed oil prices have reduced demand for oilfield chemicals and certain industrial products. This has made competing petroleum-based chemistries more economical.
Total sales during the quarter declined by $31 million compared to last year. Segment EBITDA of $32 million was a little more than half of last year's quarter. Segment profitability also reflected $8.5 million in outage and China start-up expenses. The December quarter is seasonally the softest quarter for this business. 
Ingevity's annual revenue is running at more than $900 million, and adjusted EBITDA is now at an annual rate of approximately $200 million. The oilfield services business is now less than 10% of annual revenue at approximately $80 million. This business is relatively small compared to the total business. We achieved record quarterly sales for activated carbon and asphalt additive products. We have good growth engines in the asphalt additives and automotive carbon, including the new automotive carbon plant that's starting up in China. We have a strong profitable business, a very strong management team and the scale with which to operate as a successful public company. The long-term fundamentals of the business are sound and will make for a compelling growth equity story. Post spin, Ingevity will have reasonable leverage at about 2.5x EBITDA. This will provide an immediate cash inflow of approximately $400 million to WestRock at the time of the spin, plus funding an additional $80 million in security for a capital lease retained by WestRock. 
Our land business results reflect a purchase price accounting step up of the assets to fair market value as of the July 1 merger closing. The step up effectively removes what the anticipated development profit was at the time. This has no effect on cash flow, only on reported earnings.
Most important thing to know about this segment is that we're operating in Charlestown, one of the healthiest real estate markets in the country. We're looking at ways to monetize our portfolio faster than the normal development process would allow. We've already make some progress on certain projects, and we expect to do more on this front. 
Over the last several months, we completed the SP Fiber and Cenveo Packaging acquisitions, with a total investment of approximately $400 million. Both SP Fiber and Cenveo Packaging are great strategic fits with our business and strategy. We believe these businesses will generate excellent returns on investment.
We expect to complete the Grupo Gondi joint venture investment in the next couple of months. Mexico is very important to our customers and to us, due to its proximity to the United States and its strong growth profile. We've been looking for a long time for the right opportunity to grow our capabilities in Mexico, and I believe that the partnership with Grupo Gondi is the best way for WestRock to grow in Mexico. WestRock will contribute $175 million in cash and our 3 Mexican box plants, and Grupo Gondi will contribute their business. Based on current exchange rates and the last 12 months results, the joint venture on a pro forma basis has generated $670 million in sales and $135 million in EBITDA. Our box plants have generated about 10% to 15% of the $135 million. We will have a 25% interest in the joint venture, and the joint venture will have net positive cash on its balance sheet when the joint venture is formed. The cash that we're contributing will be invested by the joint venture to support growth. WestRock will continue to provide the 200,000 tons that we supplied to our 3 box plants, and we'll have continuing opportunities to supply additional tons as the joint venture grows. We're currently executing on an opportunity to supply 25,000 tons of kraftliner to Gondi that we were not supplying 6 months ago. We will have the opportunity to build upon our combined relationships and capabilities to grow in the attractive paper and packaging markets of Mexico. 
Now I'll turn it over to Ward for additional details.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Steve. Total of non-allocated expenses were $4.5 million in the current quarter. We reduced corporate expenses by $21 million, and this is included as part of our $250 million synergy and productivity performance.Our non-service pension incom
componenttext:
Thank you, Steve. Total of non-allocated expenses were $4.5 million in the current quarter. We reduced corporate expenses by $21 million, and this is included as part of our $250 million synergy and productivity performance.
Our non-service pension income is $25 million lower than the $47 million recorded last year. This was principally a result of our pension derisking strategy, which was implemented to protect our overfunded pension plan status. We reallocated our investments to lower return asset categories, which reduced our pension income. Our U.S. qualified plans have $6.4 billion in assets. These are 108% funded and have lost very little value during the recent market disruptions. Our derisking strategy made a lot of sense last summer and even more now. We are one of the few U.S. companies and the only one of our peers with an overfunded pension plan and we are careful to protect that value. 
We have a very disciplined approach to realizing our synergies and performance improvements across our businesses and functions. We are executing on the opportunities and projects to reach our $1 billion goal and are on track to reach this target by the end of fiscal 2018. Our entire company is critically focused on delivering on and exceeding our goal. Work spans many areas. We are realizing procurement and logistics savings using the power of the expanded size of our company to our advantage in purchasing around the world. We are benefiting from our comprehensive mill system, maximizing our ability to produce the right products in the right locations and in-sourcing paperboard throughout the system. And we are continuing to use best practices from each former company to develop the right models and streamline our businesses and corporate functions across the company.
We continue to make capital investments in our mills and converting operations, with projects that reduce cost. Based on the strength of these and other initiatives, we exited the quarter at an annualized run rate of more than $250 million and are on track to achieve at least $450 million by the end of fiscal 2016. Adjusted segment EBITDA declined $68 million, due primarily to the reductions in Specialty Chemicals, the Land and Development business and the reduction in pension income. Adjusted EBITDA of our core Consumer and Corrugated Packaging businesses and corporate expenses, excluding pension income, increased by $15 million. During the quarter, we generated $88 million in productivity, which demonstrates our continued focus on progress in this area. Our productivity more than offsets the negative impact of volume price and other negative market factors. We continue to benefit from deflation in key energy categories.
Before turning it back to Steve, I want to take a minute to discuss our cash flow outlook and assumptions. We generate significant cash flow, and that is likely the key metric that has not been fully appreciated in this stock market. For fiscal 2016, we are forecasting cash flow provided by operations of between $1.8 billion and $1.825 billion and capital expenditures in the range of $825 million to $850 million. As Steve reported, our net free cash flow should be in the range of $950 million to $1 billion. 
We are including Ingevity's results in this outlook for the 7-month period that they we will be part of WestRock, and they will be excluded for the remaining 5 months. However, Ingevity's operating cash flow is equal to the forecasted capital expenditures for the period, as they are finishing their growth initiatives in China and Brazil and the winter is their seasonally slower time of the year. Our outlook reflects a view on the impact of recent PPW price changes on our Corrugated Packaging segment. 
Looking into the March quarter, there's a lot to be excited about in our business as we continue to execute on our strategy. From a financial standpoint, there are more seasonal headwinds in the March quarter on a sequential basis. We will have more energy usage due to the winter weather, and we will have some impact from the recent snowstorm that blanketed much of the Northeast. Wood will be more expensive than in the December quarter. In addition, the labor cost pool also resets with annual salary increases beginning as well as a new year of employment-related taxes. The Mahrt mill is undergoing a major maintenance outage in March that will have a $10 million impact on income in the quarter. 
In the corrugated business, export pricing will likely continue, with some softening in pricing. Currencies will also have -- likely have some negative impact on the quarter. We will continue to deliver on our productivity and synergy improvement program, which is creating a lot of value. When all of this is taken into account, we expect that the March quarter will be lower on an adjusted EPS as compared to the $0.59 posted in December. 
I will now turn the call back over to Steve.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mark. Before I open the call for questions, let me summarize by saying we're very pleased with our solid execution and the progress we've made and continue to make toward building the premier global packaging company. Today, we have leading positi
componenttext:
Thanks, Mark. Before I open the call for questions, let me summarize by saying we're very pleased with our solid execution and the progress we've made and continue to make toward building the premier global packaging company. Today, we have leading positions in our markets. We're expanding our customer relationships through our comprehensive offering across a broad geographic footprint. We're realizing the strategic benefits of the merger and remain on track for achieving our productivity improvement targets. We're confident in our ability to successfully execute our growth strategy and generate strong cash flow, enabling us to deliver value for our stockholders and customers. 
With that, we're pleased to respond to your questions.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016

componenttextpreview: My 2 questions will be, to the extent you can comment around cash flow and EBITDA. And if we assume no changes in prices going forward because, obviously, you can't do that. When we rework the free cash flow guidance, we would get EBITDA somewhere in the
componenttext: My 2 questions will be, to the extent you can comment around cash flow and EBITDA. And if we assume no changes in prices going forward because, obviously, you can't do that. When we rework the free cash flow guidance, we would get EBITDA somewhere in the range of about $2.1 billion. Is there a way that you could comment to whether that's a reasonable forecast at this juncture? And if not, can you remind us of any other large cash items we should be thinking about, cash interest, cash taxes, that you didn't show on Slide 14?

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016

componenttext: George, again, on what we provided was free cash flow guidance of $950 million to $1 billion. We also included the pension and postretirement funding, working capital assumptions and a book tax rate of 34% to 36%. The other things to consider: the DNA. We had $294 million of DNA in the quarter. Ingevity's about $7 million to $8 million a month. So we will have the DNA for them for the remaining -- through the 7-month period. Cash taxes will be less than book. Share-based comp will be a source. Equity and income and unconsolidated affiliates with the investment in Gondi will actually be a use. These and other balance sheet items over the course of the year should generate between $0 and $25 million of source for the remainder of the year.

componenttext: And then I guess my other question because I appreciate all the detail. I'm going to switch to just the outlook. Can you comment at all in terms of how bookings have been thus far in the quarter? Just an overall comment about how the corrugated markets, in particular, have been early in fiscal 2Q?

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jim?
componenttext: Jim?

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, George, Jim Porter. First, I'd like to highlight how excited I am about the progress that our corrugated container business has made. We've just continued to make progress in so many areas. The investments that we've made in our people and p
componenttext: Good morning, George, Jim Porter. First, I'd like to highlight how excited I am about the progress that our corrugated container business has made. We've just continued to make progress in so many areas. The investments that we've made in our people and processes and capital equipment improvements have really given us exceptional quality and service for our customers that's being rewarded by increased business. And I'd highlight that with we've had 12 months in a row in which we've -- our box shipments have exceeded the FBA industry. So we're quite proud of the progress being made. This last quarter we were up 2.9% on a per day basis, and that demand continues to be strong. Now we're -- after 12 months of exceptional growth, we're going to be entering a period where the comps are getting tougher. But current demand, as evidenced by our backlogs, continues to be strong. Now as Steve mentioned, we've had some weather events to January that will probably put a dent in those numbers, but we expect that by the end of the quarter, we should be flat on a year-over-year basis.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Mr. Mark Weintraub of Buckingham Research.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Mr. Mark Weintraub of Buckingham Research.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I want just a follow-up. Steve, you had mentioned that, that $950 million to $1 billion of free cash flow on a per share basis where the share count today is $3.75. But of course, you do have the share repurchase authorization in place for an additional 3
componenttext: I want just a follow-up. Steve, you had mentioned that, that $950 million to $1 billion of free cash flow on a per share basis where the share count today is $3.75. But of course, you do have the share repurchase authorization in place for an additional 30-plus million shares. And given the free cash flow, given the dividend that comes in from Ingevity, given that you're below your targeted debt-to-capital range, presumably, you're in a position to act fairly aggressively and perhaps expeditiously on that share repurchase. And I was hoping to get a sense as to what your thought on the timing might be. And just to throw in there as a part of the question is while -- when the share purchase program was originally authorized, the stock was north of $60, now it's closer to $30. Were you conceiving of the repurchase as a dollar amount conceptually internally or as a number of shares? And given that the -- if the share price were to stay at this bargain basement level, would you potential be in a position to buy back even more over time?

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark, when we announced the merger, we had our balanced capital allocation strategy, and we had the authorization for 40 million shares. I feel like we'd follow through on that very well with the purchase of 9.5 million shares. I think when -- I think abo
componenttext: Mark, when we announced the merger, we had our balanced capital allocation strategy, and we had the authorization for 40 million shares. I feel like we'd follow through on that very well with the purchase of 9.5 million shares. I think when -- I think about balanced capital allocation, I look at the opportunities that we have to invest in our business, make acquisitions and buy back stock. And I will tell you, based on the current price, the share buyback has risen in attractiveness to us. Just the cash flow that we have, the dividend that we pay, it's attractive for us to buy back stock. With respect to aggressive -- our timing, I think we'll just, we'll see how the quarter goes. I can't really speak to exact timing, but I will tell you the buyback is much more attractive than it was when the price was higher.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Mr. Mark Wilde of BMO Capital.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Mr. Mark Wilde of BMO Capital.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just to follow on Mark's question, would you consider an accelerated repurchase program just to take advantage of stock at $31 or $32 here?
componenttext: Just to follow on Mark's question, would you consider an accelerated repurchase program just to take advantage of stock at $31 or $32 here?

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've considered that. I think as we've gone along and the advice we've gotten is not the most efficient way to buy back stock. We've been able to buy 9.5 million shares without an accelerated share repurchase, but never say never, but when we considered
componenttext: We've considered that. I think as we've gone along and the advice we've gotten is not the most efficient way to buy back stock. We've been able to buy 9.5 million shares without an accelerated share repurchase, but never say never, but when we considered it we've concluded the open-market purchase route's been a more efficient way for us to buy back stock.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then the other question I had is just on the boxboard markets. I wondered, Jim Porter, if you can give us kind of an update on kind of global boxboard markets across all 3 of your substrates? And I guess, we're thinking about new capacity over i
componenttext: Okay. And then the other question I had is just on the boxboard markets. I wondered, Jim Porter, if you can give us kind of an update on kind of global boxboard markets across all 3 of your substrates? And I guess, we're thinking about new capacity over in Europe but also what effect all of that Chinese capacity is having in global markets around the world? It sounds like we're even seeing some of that coming to the U.S. now.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, Mark. I'm going to have Bob Beckler take the lead on that, and I'll piggyback as necessary.
componenttext: Good morning, Mark. I'm going to have Bob Beckler take the lead on that, and I'll piggyback as necessary.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hi, Mark. Let me just do a quick run through, starting with CRB and CNK, where backlogs are up from a year-on-year standpoint, although sequentially, we have seen some expected easing that's really seasonality. Overall, we're in good balance from a supply
componenttext: Hi, Mark. Let me just do a quick run through, starting with CRB and CNK, where backlogs are up from a year-on-year standpoint, although sequentially, we have seen some expected easing that's really seasonality. Overall, we're in good balance from a supply and demand standpoint, and the markets are generally stable. On SBS, the demand that we're seeing in the higher-end premium markets, where we concentrate our efforts, has been stable to up slightly. And that's a global statement. Backlogs are stable, and pricing is stable. And considering the internalization that Steve mentioned in his opening comments, which came from opportunities that the merger created to the recent acquisition of the Cenveo Packaging business to the acquisition last year of the Carolina commercial print business, this brings a lot of SBS into our system that we are now producing internally. And so in terms of near-term outlook, we'll be up solidly. Now specific to Europe, what we see there is imports are attempting to penetrate primarily in the more commodity end of the market, such as general markets and food service plate stock where we have less of a position. So in terms of direct impact for us, it's really been 0 out of Europe. And then in terms of Chinese imports, which I believe was your question, again, we're not seeing a significant impact there. The hurdles are fairly high at this stage for competition on that front. We have an advantage cost position. Again, we focus on a very diverse range of higher-end markets. We have a quality advantage. And not to mention, there's a very high hurdle rate around the very complex supply chain that exists. It's a very complicated market to serve with very demanding customers and service requirements that we are well positioned. So net-net, not much effect that we're seeing from an import standpoint.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And is it possible to get any color? You mentioned the loss of a key customer in the third quarter last year. I don't recall hearing about that before. Can you just quantify that for us and give us maybe a little bit of color?
componenttext: Okay. And is it possible to get any color? You mentioned the loss of a key customer in the third quarter last year. I don't recall hearing about that before. Can you just quantify that for us and give us maybe a little bit of color?

componenttextpreview: Yes, Mark, that was one specific customer in our liquid packaging sector that occurred about 7 or 8 months ago. We're -- just to add to the comment, we're, obviously, offsetting that with the moves that I outlined earlier and continued modest growth in th
componenttext: Yes, Mark, that was one specific customer in our liquid packaging sector that occurred about 7 or 8 months ago. We're -- just to add to the comment, we're, obviously, offsetting that with the moves that I outlined earlier and continued modest growth in the premium sectors that we focus on, such as tobacco, food service, cup stock and commercial print.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Mr. Scott Gaffner of Barclays.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Mr. Scott Gaffner of Barclays.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just want to go back for a minute to the SP Fiber acquisition because since then you've closed about 675,000 tons of capacity, and you had a couple of key comments here in the presentation on the rationale for the acquisition. But can you just maybe go
componenttext: I just want to go back for a minute to the SP Fiber acquisition because since then you've closed about 675,000 tons of capacity, and you had a couple of key comments here in the presentation on the rationale for the acquisition. But can you just maybe go a little bit deeper on what exactly SP Fiber provides maybe as -- from a product portfolio perspective that you didn't have before or couldn't get by investing in your own system?

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Jim.
componenttext: Sure, Jim.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll take that, Steve. First of all, we are really excited about the opportunity to have acquired the SP asset, specifically the Dublin, Georgia mill. And I think the proposition goes back to how we look at our markets and our quest to improve the co
componenttext: Yes, I'll take that, Steve. First of all, we are really excited about the opportunity to have acquired the SP asset, specifically the Dublin, Georgia mill. And I think the proposition goes back to how we look at our markets and our quest to improve the cost of the system. But you've seen us behave consistently in a way that we've matched our supply with demand. And over the last number of quarters, we've tried to balance our system through a combination of temporary shutdowns, slow backs and permanent closures to try to get our system in just the right balance with our demand. The acquisition of SP Fiber in October gave us the capability to add 575,000 tons of really excellent quality, low-cost, lightweight packaging grade papers in the center of our neural network of supply chain. And so that gave us the ability to build a very granular plan in order to improve the cost structure and service capability of our system. And so that allowed us to first permanently close the Coshocton mill in November; secondly, to close permanently the Newberg newsprint and packaging grade mill in mid-November; and our latest move to close Uncasville media mill, which will be permanently shut by January 31. So this acquisition has given us the ability to provide very good quality market demand substrates in a lower cost, both fixed and operating, and has allowed us to balance supply with demand in a much more efficient way, taking 675,000 tons out of the market. So I hope that gives clarity to our move.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's great. Steve, just following up on that. Since you've done the merger, you did the 2 acquisitions, SP Fiber, Cenveo, and then also the JV. Obviously, acquisitions have been a key part of the WestRock going back to RockTenn story, historically. Do y
componenttext: That's great. Steve, just following up on that. Since you've done the merger, you did the 2 acquisitions, SP Fiber, Cenveo, and then also the JV. Obviously, acquisitions have been a key part of the WestRock going back to RockTenn story, historically. Do you see that continuing going forward? Or are you reaching sort of maximum capacity as far as, I mean, obviously, not from a leverage perspective, but from a management bandwidth perspective to keep doing these smaller bolt-on acquisitions? Or should we see them continue at this pace going forward?

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a great question, Scott. I don't think it's a function of management bandwidth. I think it's a function of priorities. And if you look at the opportunity set that we have, we have an incredible opportunity to operate our businesses while -- even be
componenttext: That's a great question, Scott. I don't think it's a function of management bandwidth. I think it's a function of priorities. And if you look at the opportunity set that we have, we have an incredible opportunity to operate our businesses while -- even better than they have. We have a very, let's say, a lot of opportunity to bring more money to the bottom line through a focus on our own business. And so when I look at our priorities, I think acquisition is probably less of a relative priority than it might have been in the past, because of the opportunities we have to combine our organization and go to market and operate even more efficiently. So I think internal focus is probably a relatively greater priority than it would have been to me previously. Now having said that, the acquisitions that we've made, I think, have been strategic and been helpful to our business. So we'll continue to look at them. I just don't see them as, in response your question, high priority as they might have been in the past.

componenttext: Okay. I just wanted to clarify that. And I guess, this is either for Jim or Steve. Could you just let us know as you look at your box situation in the United States, I would assume and what I've always been told is that where you do have index contracts, they almost are totally tied to, I guess, the RISI Pulp & Paper Week kraftliner price as opposed to some of the other recycle grade as they track, is that still fair for your company?

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And were you all surprised by the action they took last weekend? What did you think of that?
componenttext: Okay. And were you all surprised by the action they took last weekend? What did you think of that?

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd say, everybody was surprised, including us. So I think Jim is going to comment more on that.
componenttext: I'd say, everybody was surprised, including us. So I think Jim is going to comment more on that.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, Chip. I'd have to say, yes, we were very surprised to see, specifically, linerboard and white top linerboard published down by $15. We simply have not seen virgin containerboard down in the market. We have seen and heard of customers discoun
componenttext: Good morning, Chip. I'd have to say, yes, we were very surprised to see, specifically, linerboard and white top linerboard published down by $15. We simply have not seen virgin containerboard down in the market. We have seen and heard of customers discounting some of the smaller recycled, principally medium volume in the market. However, our linerboard and white top has not been dropped. Those facts are really supported by the fact that our domestic containerboard prices, excluding the addition of the recent SP mill, which we're fitting into our system, has been flat year-over-year and flat sequentially. So we're just simply not seeing that price drop, particularly, in the virgin grade. So we were very surprised by that.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Mr. Anthony Pettinari of Citigroup.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Mr. Anthony Pettinari of Citigroup.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Following the mill closures and the acquisitions, a lot of moving pieces, is it possible to share what your containerboard integration rate is? And is there a rate that you think is sort of an optimal integration level for WestRock? Or is that not how you
componenttext: Following the mill closures and the acquisitions, a lot of moving pieces, is it possible to share what your containerboard integration rate is? And is there a rate that you think is sort of an optimal integration level for WestRock? Or is that not how you think about improving margins? Just if you could give any color there.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're currently in the range of in the high 60s, 67% or 69% integration within our corrugated system. And we certainly do look at that. We think about our round number as 8 million tons of containerboard business through 3 channels. One is our outstanding
componenttext: We're currently in the range of in the high 60s, 67% or 69% integration within our corrugated system. And we certainly do look at that. We think about our round number as 8 million tons of containerboard business through 3 channels. One is our outstanding domestic Corrugated Packaging business, which we've seen growing in their capability to penetrate the market. We then see the North American domestic sales and then the international sales. And so, when we look at how we maximize our portfolio of products and margin through those channels. And the integrated corrugated box segment is one that is attractive to us, and we will look for continued growth through organic means and certainly we look at acquisitions. They've been pretty pricey lately.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just in terms of priority, the best thing we can do for the Corrugated Packaging business is sell more boxes, and that's exactly what we've been doing over the past several years. We've invested in capital, people, processes. I think that team has just do
componenttext: Just in terms of priority, the best thing we can do for the Corrugated Packaging business is sell more boxes, and that's exactly what we've been doing over the past several years. We've invested in capital, people, processes. I think that team has just done, in my view, an outstanding job for a long period of time and it's showing up in the results.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then just with Ingevity, you mentioned complexities that are pushing the spin out a bit. Could you give any color there? I mean, are those legal issues related to the transaction that are taking a little bit more time than you ex
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then just with Ingevity, you mentioned complexities that are pushing the spin out a bit. Could you give any color there? I mean, are those legal issues related to the transaction that are taking a little bit more time than you expected? Or is it kind of choppiness in the capital markets or are they complexities with separating the assets? Just wondering if you can give any color there.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Complexities are by nature are complex. If I had to pick one which was, I guess, a little bit surprising to me it's the -- I guess, the step plan to put everything in place with a number of strong [ph] entities and U.S. entities. I think that has just req
componenttext: Complexities are by nature are complex. If I had to pick one which was, I guess, a little bit surprising to me it's the -- I guess, the step plan to put everything in place with a number of strong [ph] entities and U.S. entities. I think that has just required a lot of thought. There's a lot of tax implications to that, and if I had to pick one, that would be it. But there's several of them.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And maybe just one last one. Regarding the mill closures, do you have to build inventories at sister mills in advance of the closures to give yourself a little buffer? Or how does the closure sort of impact your inventory levels mayb
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And maybe just one last one. Regarding the mill closures, do you have to build inventories at sister mills in advance of the closures to give yourself a little buffer? Or how does the closure sort of impact your inventory levels maybe over the next 3 months?

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Inventories are something we very granularly manage for the on-time delivery and service required by our -- both our internal and external customers to meet their demands. And then we've seen over the past couple of years that we are benefited by generall
componenttext: Inventories are something we very granularly manage for the on-time delivery and service required by our -- both our internal and external customers to meet their demands. And then we've seen over the past couple of years that we are benefited by generally increasing our standard levels of inventory. That's paid big dividends in our ability to serve our corrugated box customers. And it's -- as we think about inventories, particularly with downtime season, we do build volume. And while we have just gone through a sequential decline in our internal inventories, you will see us building somewhere in the 90,000-ton range over the next couple of months, which will then be absorbed by our annual shutdown schedule and then you get to the end of the fiscal year, we should be back at par with our standard inventory level. So that's how we look at our system.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Ms. Deborah Jones of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Ms. Deborah Jones of Deutsche Bank.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to return to Brazil for a second. You have a great asset down there. I think that there's been a lot of focus on your options in the U.S. But could you talk about your strategy going forward there and also just kind of characterize how you see th
componenttext: I wanted to return to Brazil for a second. You have a great asset down there. I think that there's been a lot of focus on your options in the U.S. But could you talk about your strategy going forward there and also just kind of characterize how you see the market?

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm going to start, and then I'll let Jim chime in. I think Brazil is just a tremendous business for us. It shows up in the financial results. We implemented a project a few years ago, which has really put Brazil on a great track. And we have a number of
componenttext: I'm going to start, and then I'll let Jim chime in. I think Brazil is just a tremendous business for us. It shows up in the financial results. We implemented a project a few years ago, which has really put Brazil on a great track. And we have a number of options to be able to improve the business over time through capital investment. And I think we're looking at that, both internally in Brazil to get larger in the box business in Brazil and then we also think we have, depending on the market in Brazil, we have the opportunity to kind of add back to our system, if you will, to serve export markets. Jim?

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Steve, you covered it well. The only thing I'd add is emphasis on the fact that we really have a great business in Brazil, and those investments have really paid off over time. That team is extraordinary in their ability to manage within very difficu
componenttext: Yes, Steve, you covered it well. The only thing I'd add is emphasis on the fact that we really have a great business in Brazil, and those investments have really paid off over time. That team is extraordinary in their ability to manage within very difficult market conditions, but they really have premium assets. Our significant forest resource give us a real competitive advantage in that region. We have one of the most modern virgin containerboard mills in the world at the Trs Barras facility that produces an extraordinary product that gives us a competitive advantage. Our box system is capable of integrating that volume to penetrate the marketplace in a way as we reported that has grown far in excess of the local economy. And because of the currency, you've seen us increasing our export volumes out of that region, which are certainly advantaged in the global markets today. So we're quite bullish on our capability to serve and grow in that region.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016

Certainly over time, as I said earlier, we'd look at channel optimization and our box system's attractive place for our containerboard to flow.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: The second topic I wanted to actually discuss was on the inflation side. So you're running at about a -- you've given us some run rates where you're working through $250 million on a run rate even higher through the end of the year. What do you think infl
componenttext: The second topic I wanted to actually discuss was on the inflation side. So you're running at about a -- you've given us some run rates where you're working through $250 million on a run rate even higher through the end of the year. What do you think inflation looks like this year? I mean, you've got some puts and takes, you have labor obviously moving higher, you had some help on a few of the other input elements, energy, et cetera, but what do you think for fiscal year, what your inflation kind of shakes out at.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Ward. Clearly, we're getting the benefits year-over-year in the first quarter on the decline and primarily the energy-related input costs. The wage inflation is -- wage and benefit inflation is very predictable and will flow as we've laid out
componenttext: Yes, this is Ward. Clearly, we're getting the benefits year-over-year in the first quarter on the decline and primarily the energy-related input costs. The wage inflation is -- wage and benefit inflation is very predictable and will flow as we've laid out, and you've seen the quarterly profile of it. I think as we start to get out into the second half of the year, I think our projections on a year-over-year basis is that they moderate. We don't get as much of a benefit because of the declines that took place in the second half of last year. The one wildcard for us as we look out that far is what do we think the trends will be for OCC and recycled fiber.

There's so many moving parts with 15,000 customers and agreements that we have that I think we're comfortable with our overall cash flow model, but we're not going to speak specifically to pricing and market movements that affect our customers more specifically.

componenttext: In both businesses, I mean, we talked about the fact that we have higher energy costs in the winter periods. headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, you pushed back the timing of Specialty Chemical, but what's the rush? I mean, we've certainly seen another big chemical business spun recently when it was down and the shareholder situation didn't turn out real well. I guess I'm just wondering how
componenttext: Steve, you pushed back the timing of Specialty Chemical, but what's the rush? I mean, we've certainly seen another big chemical business spun recently when it was down and the shareholder situation didn't turn out real well. I guess I'm just wondering how do you figure the balance between the desire to clean up the portfolio quickly and the need to protect shareholders in such an uncertain market?

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm glad you asked that question because we've gone through and done, I think, a fair amount of thinking about that question ourselves. I think I'd start with we're a paper and packaging company. We're not a specialty chemicals business, so the business d
componenttext: I'm glad you asked that question because we've gone through and done, I think, a fair amount of thinking about that question ourselves. I think I'd start with we're a paper and packaging company. We're not a specialty chemicals business, so the business does not really fit with our portfolio. We have put in place, I think, a very strong management team, and the business is going to perform better on its own than it would be as part of WestRock. I think you can go through the alternatives, and I think the spin makes the most sense. You could say, well, maybe I could look at some other alternatives, but we just think this is not for the shareholders. And for WestRock it's the most effective thing for is to do. I think going to May, I think it's going to help team get off to a good start and they are going to be able to put together, I think, a very compelling story for investors on the value of Ingevity.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And just one more question, Steve. Will WestRock significantly realign the product development priorities within the Consumer division? headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016

componenttext: We're going through that now. We have innovations being a primary capability of WestRock. So we'll take the guide from our customers to match with our capabilities and prioritize that way.

componenttext: We have done a fair amount of very granular planning on how we improve the portfolio of our assets. headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: The operational issues are past. I think what we reported as promotional activity is down and promotional activity is, by definition, hard to predict. So we like the display business as part of our portfolio. It provides us a great entree and great capabi
componenttext: The operational issues are past. I think what we reported as promotional activity is down and promotional activity is, by definition, hard to predict. So we like the display business as part of our portfolio. It provides us a great entree and great capability to help us work with our customers. So it's -- I like the business. I'd like to see there being more promotional activity, and I think that will come.

componenttext: Two quick ones. First, I'm wondering how Corrugated & Consumer packaging complement one another? Have you gained new customers on either side from customers looking for a one-stop shop?

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, this is Bob Beckler, great question. And it's just one of the benefits of the merger that we're continuing to realize and gain momentum. Within the largest customers of WestRock, there is overlap between our packaging lines of business and, in some
componenttext: Steve, this is Bob Beckler, great question. And it's just one of the benefits of the merger that we're continuing to realize and gain momentum. Within the largest customers of WestRock, there is overlap between our packaging lines of business and, in some cases, packaging and paperboard. And it's substantial. The number I think we included in one of our slides is that our top $2 billion of customers participate in multiple product lines. And if you just take those customers with the upside that we see from an addressable market standpoint, we could see an additional $1 billion of opportunity just in that customer set. So it's still a work in progress, but customers are definitely recognizing the benefits of -- you call it a one-stop shop but it's really unique in the global industry to have this many capabilities under one roof.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Do they ask for a package deal, no pun intended?
componenttext: Do they ask for a package deal, no pun intended?

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016

componenttext: No. We're really not seeing that as much as opportunities to enter into other product lines that they have. I think if your question is are they trying to leverage that to their advantage? Not so much that versus how can they increase their ease of doing business -- complexity in their own supply chain.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll just add on to this. There's a gradation between corrugated and consumer. The folding carton becomes -- micro fluid becomes preprint and oftentimes the buyers were trying to choose between folding cartons and corrugated. And we're just ideally positi
componenttext: I'll just add on to this. There's a gradation between corrugated and consumer. The folding carton becomes -- micro fluid becomes preprint and oftentimes the buyers were trying to choose between folding cartons and corrugated. And we're just ideally positioned to help them work through those issues because we are just interested in helping our customers be successful. And we can do that more effectively with a broad product line without a bias on 1 substrate, 1 particular type of package.

headline: WestRock Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I think we've completed the hour. So I just want to take the time to thank you for your time and attention. I think we're making great progress in executing our plan to create value. We're growing our business, generating strong cash flow and realiz
componenttext: Okay. I think we've completed the hour. So I just want to take the time to thank you for your time and attention. I think we're making great progress in executing our plan to create value. We're growing our business, generating strong cash flow and realizing our synergies and performance improvements. I like what we're doing by expanding our customer relationships based on the breadth of our product offerings. We are using our capital to grow and invest in our own business and return cash to stockholders. I think WestRock is a compelling value-creating opportunity, and I thank you again for joining us this morning. Thanks.
