headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Not really rising, Mark. It's really a great market for us. We've been able to penetrate the "lightweight bag" market that we all see in a lot of the fast food restaurants. And so it's -- fit that mill perfectly. The mill capacity is just below 600,000 to
componenttext: Not really rising, Mark. It's really a great market for us. We've been able to penetrate the "lightweight bag" market that we all see in a lot of the fast food restaurants. And so it's -- fit that mill perfectly. The mill capacity is just below 600,000 tons. And the beauty is we can swing between lightweight containerboard grades, just liner medium as well as bags. So we have significant flexibility. Currently, that bag has been operating in the 90,000 to 100,000 tons -- about 90,000 tons a quarter. And it's -- again, it remains a good grade for us. And the balance of the Dublin mill is producing linerboard medium.

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And Jim, would you assume, over -- could we assume over time that you'll be able to put more containerboard into that Mexican JV? I think you mentioned it's about 250,000 right now on a run rate basis.
componenttext: Okay. And Jim, would you assume, over -- could we assume over time that you'll be able to put more containerboard into that Mexican JV? I think you mentioned it's about 250,000 right now on a run rate basis.

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Mark. We're really excited about that joint venture. We see the Mexican market as being a very powerful growth engine. And our partners with Gondi could not be better. They have incredible assets and very focused on the beverage and high-graphics mar
componenttext: Yes, Mark. We're really excited about that joint venture. We see the Mexican market as being a very powerful growth engine. And our partners with Gondi could not be better. They have incredible assets and very focused on the beverage and high-graphics markets. Our business down there had been more focused on the agricultural markets. And so together, I think it gives us the ability to penetrate with a lot more capability into the agricultural areas, which is a great pipeline for our virgin containerboard. I think we mentioned also this new Nava plant. I wish you all could see it. It's -- I've been in the industry a lot of years, and I, frankly, have never seen a corrugated facility like this one. It has tremendous upside potential, and we're excited about the pipeline of -- for the future.

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So we -- could we also assume that you might be able to put some CNK and SBS into the JV?
componenttext: Okay. So we -- could we also assume that you might be able to put some CNK and SBS into the JV?

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's correct.
componenttext: That's correct.

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Anthony Pettinari of Citi.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Anthony Pettinari of Citi.

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jim, I was wondering if you could speak to trends in containerboard export pricing maybe late in the quarter or in April. Are you seeing any stabilization there given a weaker dollar? Or is there still some pressure? And I was wondering that given some of
componenttext: Jim, I was wondering if you could speak to trends in containerboard export pricing maybe late in the quarter or in April. Are you seeing any stabilization there given a weaker dollar? Or is there still some pressure? And I was wondering that given some of the price weakness we've seen in export markets -- obviously, your volumes are up year-over-year, is there any situation where you might have to exit some of the markets you participate in on the containerboard side?

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let's start with the fundamentals of our international business, which amounts to about 15% of our total shipments. And first of all, the global demand has been solid. Over the last couple of years, it's averaged 4%. I think, the last quarter, North Ameri
componenttext: Let's start with the fundamentals of our international business, which amounts to about 15% of our total shipments. And first of all, the global demand has been solid. Over the last couple of years, it's averaged 4%. I think, the last quarter, North American exports was up 3.6%. So we can see solid demand principally for virgin containerboard. We've developed a very strong series of relationships across the world that, frankly, value our virgin containerboard on quality, service, supply chain, consistent delivery to them month in and month out. So there's more to it than price. On the other hand, we certainly acknowledge that prices have become incredibly competitive, largely due to a new machine startup in Northern Europe and the Russian and Brazilian economies, which is taking board produced in those countries that aren't being cut up in boxes in those countries. We're seeing that in other parts of the world. And with the currency differential they have over the U.S. dollar, it has put a significant impact on price. So to your question of, is it getting better? We have seen some currency strengthening. So we would expect that to contribute to the pricing scenario. We have, as you know, rightsized our portfolio some, so we are not supplying all the business across the world that we once did. However, we've got an important customer base there, and we're committed to that part of the world. And cycles change, and our products are needed and valued.

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And then switching gears. Steve, I think you indicated you're now selling some cartons to customers that you only sold corrugated to before. And I was wondering if it's -- is it possible to quantify the cross-selling opportunities, e
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then switching gears. Steve, I think you indicated you're now selling some cartons to customers that you only sold corrugated to before. And I was wondering if it's -- is it possible to quantify the cross-selling opportunities, either in terms of sales or maybe the number of large accounts that you're now cross-selling to? And then just maybe generally, when you think about getting your sales organization to a point where they can really leverage all of WestRock's offerings, are you early innings there or is that process kind of completed? Or how should we kind of think about that?

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's early innings. I think you asked about quantification of cross-selling. We're not trying to quantify that, because I don't want to get the organization in a mode to where we're trying to count one sale over the another sale. So we're just like to mar
componenttext: It's early innings. I think you asked about quantification of cross-selling. We're not trying to quantify that, because I don't want to get the organization in a mode to where we're trying to count one sale over the another sale. So we're just like to market our products and services. We do have a much broader product line as WestRock, and that breadth is by product, it's by service, it's by geography. And we're taking the product line and focusing on tailoring solutions for our customers. We're in the process of doing that. I think we've got tremendous enthusiasm across the organization for our ability to -- the opportunity that we have to do that. I think a couple examples, we serve a lot of consumer products companies, and a lot of the consumer products companies use preprint. And so we've been able to take the preprint offering to Brazil and working with a customer that we would serve in North America to add preprint to their packaging. And we think it has the potential to help them sell more product. There is a number of examples about that. I think we are -- the reason I say we're in the early innings is -- while we have a lot of enthusiasm, a lot of connection, I think we can get better at institutionalizing that through the company. I don't often talk about IT projects, but last week, we had a lot of excitement because we went live on a single instance of Salesforce, which is going to allow much better transparency throughout the organization about the relationships that we have across the organization. I think -- through time, I think it's going to grow in the contribution that it makes to the success of WestRock.

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question that we do have comes from the line of Adam Josephson from KeyBanc.
componenttext: The next question that we do have comes from the line of Adam Josephson from KeyBanc.

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ward, one just on the guidance. I think you mentioned excluding Ingevity, you did $0.53, in the second quarter you'd be up sequentially from that. Can you be any more specific than that?
componenttext: Ward, one just on the guidance. I think you mentioned excluding Ingevity, you did $0.53, in the second quarter you'd be up sequentially from that. Can you be any more specific than that?

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I -- what we're doing is we're reaffirming our full year cash flow guidance. And what I can say in that full year cash flow guidance is we've taken into consideration all the PPW changes, both in corrugated and on the consumer grades. We've reflected
componenttext: No, I -- what we're doing is we're reaffirming our full year cash flow guidance. And what I can say in that full year cash flow guidance is we've taken into consideration all the PPW changes, both in corrugated and on the consumer grades. We've reflected what we think our latest achievement of synergies and productivity are going to be. We've gone through the entire -- the balance sheet assumptions, capital expenditures, and we feel good about our opportunities to still achieve the $950 million to $1 billion. And again, we had stated that Ingevity, we thought, would be cash flow-neutral for us up to the spin. That is the pattern that they will not actually generate any contribution to that overall goal. Their operating cash flow was -- will be offset by the capital expenditures that they have in the business. So again, rather than going through every individual assumption, what I would say is that we've reflected all the changes in the marketplace, commodity cost, productivity, and we feel good about the overall guidance.

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ward. And Steve, just -- Steve or Jim, one for you on containerboard. I get asked this frequently, that -- are containerboard prices, in your view, dictated by supply/demand or by input costs? Because investors often want to know, as input costs c
componenttext: Thanks, Ward. And Steve, just -- Steve or Jim, one for you on containerboard. I get asked this frequently, that -- are containerboard prices, in your view, dictated by supply/demand or by input costs? Because investors often want to know, as input costs change, how would one expect prices to change? I'm just hoping you could provide your view on that.

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Adam, the -- unfortunately, the answer is both. It's a market -- like input costs do have an input into it. If I had to pick one over the other, it would be supply and demand. And I think the evidence over time would support that.
componenttext: Adam, the -- unfortunately, the answer is both. It's a market -- like input costs do have an input into it. If I had to pick one over the other, it would be supply and demand. And I think the evidence over time would support that.

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just one last one. Ward, back to the input cost issue. For how much longer do you expect year-over-year declines in your input costs? I know you said they'd be up sequentially, but year-on-year?
componenttext: And just one last one. Ward, back to the input cost issue. For how much longer do you expect year-over-year declines in your input costs? I know you said they'd be up sequentially, but year-on-year?

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So if you look at our bridge, Adam, and -- for the first quarter, we actually had net deflation, if you look at the commodity deflation, and it was actually greater than our wage and other cost inflation. We're at parity in Q2. And as we start to loo
componenttext: Yes. So if you look at our bridge, Adam, and -- for the first quarter, we actually had net deflation, if you look at the commodity deflation, and it was actually greater than our wage and other cost inflation. We're at parity in Q2. And as we start to look at the second half of the year, I actually think you're going to see a little bit of net inflation on a year-over-year basis as we go through -- as we exit Q3 and Q4.

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: On input costs as well as on wage and other, you mean?
componenttext: On input costs as well as on wage and other, you mean?

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll still have some -- no, that -- what I was referring to was the net of wage and input costs. I think we will continue to have some year-over-year benefits, but it's going to start to moderate.
componenttext: We'll still have some -- no, that -- what I was referring to was the net of wage and input costs. I think we will continue to have some year-over-year benefits, but it's going to start to moderate.

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question that we do have comes from the line of Scott Gaffner from Barclays.
componenttext: The next question that we do have comes from the line of Scott Gaffner from Barclays.

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, the first question I had was for either you or Jim. It really is around the addition of the EVOL machines that you've done over the past couple of years. Because I think in your prepared remarks, you'd talked about the number of months that you'd o
componenttext: Steve, the first question I had was for either you or Jim. It really is around the addition of the EVOL machines that you've done over the past couple of years. Because I think in your prepared remarks, you'd talked about the number of months that you'd outgrown the industry, but my question is really around, how does adding the EVOL machines change your mix of business? I mean, I would think it would move towards more longer-run businesses or longer-run boxes, but maybe it frees up those other machines that you have to do more customized work. But any color you can give around that would be appreciated.

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Scott, this is Jim. The EVOL is just incredible, incredible piece of equipment. And it really does not change our mix of business at all. It simply makes a better box. If you pulled a box coming off an EVOL compared to one coming off of a 20-year-old flex
componenttext: Scott, this is Jim. The EVOL is just incredible, incredible piece of equipment. And it really does not change our mix of business at all. It simply makes a better box. If you pulled a box coming off an EVOL compared to one coming off of a 20-year-old flexo folder gluer, it is clearly a better product. It runs much faster, requires less labor to operate, has quicker setups, better precision, better print quality. It just improves our capability to be a quality box supplier to all of our customers.

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And as you've added these machines, I mean, where do we stand as far as the potential for box plant footprint rationalization?
componenttext: Okay. And as you've added these machines, I mean, where do we stand as far as the potential for box plant footprint rationalization?

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: We did a -- with the Smurfit acquisition, I think we took out, if I remember it correctly, 28 plants through consolidation. We're at a good footprint now. I think the EVOLs, when we looked at the -- just the machines that we had in each of the box plants,
componenttext: We did a -- with the Smurfit acquisition, I think we took out, if I remember it correctly, 28 plants through consolidation. We're at a good footprint now. I think the EVOLs, when we looked at the -- just the machines that we had in each of the box plants, we needed to invest in flexo folder gluers. And so the -- each of these EVOL projects, when they go into the plant, they will displace 2, 3 or 4 flexo folder gluers, and then there'll be some benefit to the economics of the plant as a result of that. But the better box attribute is pretty significant. Because where we've put these EVOLs in, I think it has a uplifting impact on the performance of the entire plant. I think it just helps most every dimension of the plant. But just specifically with respect to the footprint, we're comfortable with where we are now, because the EVOLs is less of a -- let's say, a capacity increase than it is a efficiency investment.

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. And Steve, just last one for me. You mentioned bolt-on acquisitions. How should we think about sizing within a bolt-on? What does that mean for you? And do you have enough management bandwidth with all of your -- all the integration that you're
componenttext: All right. And Steve, just last one for me. You mentioned bolt-on acquisitions. How should we think about sizing within a bolt-on? What does that mean for you? And do you have enough management bandwidth with all of your -- all the integration that you're doing? I mean, you've done a few bolt-ons since the merger. Any color you could provide would be great.

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. The transactions SP Fiber, Cenveo and Gondi would be in the range of what I would characterize as a bolt-on. I think, with respect to the management, where I've -- I think we're in great shape because the -- if you were -- would've told me, wit
componenttext: Yes, sure. The transactions SP Fiber, Cenveo and Gondi would be in the range of what I would characterize as a bolt-on. I think, with respect to the management, where I've -- I think we're in great shape because the -- if you were -- would've told me, with the merger, we'd be able to go through and do the work that we've done on the 3 acquisitions. And it is living inside the world, it is difficult to describe the work that has to be done to spin a company. And we are -- I just -- just our support functions are doing fantastic. And each quarter, I will tell you, as we prepare for the conference calls, we're getting better and better at getting the books closed each and every month, each and every quarter. So I think we have the bandwidth to invest the time we need to in order to improve our business, and where opportunities are there, take advantage of those.

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question that we do have comes from the line of Mark Connelly of CLSA.
componenttext: The next question that we do have comes from the line of Mark Connelly of CLSA.

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, how do you square the strong results in home, health and beauty with the continued mediocrity in merchandising display? It seems to me that after the big pullback in merchandising display, the 2 should be moving in the same direction. Is there just
componenttext: Steve, how do you square the strong results in home, health and beauty with the continued mediocrity in merchandising display? It seems to me that after the big pullback in merchandising display, the 2 should be moving in the same direction. Is there just something different happening in stores and this is going to be the new normal?

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think there are 2 different situations. So I'm not sure how well they are connected. Home, health and beauty, the management team has just, I think, performed exceptionally well, and they're doing the fundamentals of what they need to do in order to be
componenttext: I think there are 2 different situations. So I'm not sure how well they are connected. Home, health and beauty, the management team has just, I think, performed exceptionally well, and they're doing the fundamentals of what they need to do in order to be successful in that business. And the display business has -- I think the Wal-Mart effect had an impact on primary demand for displays. I think that's bottomed. And then I think we're in the process of taking actions. We need to align our cost structure with -- I think that -- I think it -- I'm not sure what the new normal is in promotion, but I think the -- I think we feel our business needs to adapt to the changing marketplace. And then, I'll add that the display business is important for us as we develop relationships with customers because it is a promotional business that works with our customers to help them sell more product. I think it broadens the relationships that we have. And I think that cast a very positive light on the rest of our businesses.

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So it sounds like you're saying that home, health and beauty is outperforming consumer spending just with your internal progress maybe?
componenttext: So it sounds like you're saying that home, health and beauty is outperforming consumer spending just with your internal progress maybe?

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, correct. Go ahead.
componenttext: Yes, correct. Go ahead.

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just one more question. Working capital is seeing some of the biggest swings we've ever seen from WestRock or its predecessors, and obviously, you've got a lot of stuff going on, but is that just a one-off? Or is there something different happening in the
componenttext: Just one more question. Working capital is seeing some of the biggest swings we've ever seen from WestRock or its predecessors, and obviously, you've got a lot of stuff going on, but is that just a one-off? Or is there something different happening in the way you manage working capital?

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, it's -- our working capital assumptions for the full year that we had embedded in our guidance -- cash flow guidance back after the first quarter are still intact. The receivable increase in -- as you look from quarter-to-quarter, really was based on
componenttext: No, it's -- our working capital assumptions for the full year that we had embedded in our guidance -- cash flow guidance back after the first quarter are still intact. The receivable increase in -- as you look from quarter-to-quarter, really was based on the timing of some collections that we had at the end of last quarter plus the -- some increased sales. So it is -- and we are managing our inventory levels to the planning scenarios that we had both in our corrugated business and consumer business. So again, the full year assumption of what we would get from working capital is still intact.

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. But these "$100 million up, $150 million down" swings are not going to go away?
componenttext: Okay. But these "$100 million up, $150 million down" swings are not going to go away?

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wouldn't say from quarter-to-quarter, I'm talking about the outlook for the year.
componenttext: I wouldn't say from quarter-to-quarter, I'm talking about the outlook for the year.

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question that we do have comes from the line of Chris Manuel from Wells Fargo Securities.
componenttext: The next question that we do have comes from the line of Chris Manuel from Wells Fargo Securities.

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of topics I wanted to go at. I mean, first, just a couple of housekeeping questions. Help me with the -- this kind of ties into the last question, but your $950 million to $1 billion free cash flow guidance, what's the CapEx number you've got emb
componenttext: A couple of topics I wanted to go at. I mean, first, just a couple of housekeeping questions. Help me with the -- this kind of ties into the last question, but your $950 million to $1 billion free cash flow guidance, what's the CapEx number you've got embedded in there? What is your change in working capital number that you've got embedded in there this year? And I think you may have given this D&A earlier, but if you did, I missed writing it down. Could you just remind us of that, too?

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so I would refer you to the assumptions that we gave last quarter. We're not updating every individual assumption. I do believe, for CapEx spending, we will be on the low end of the range. We gave a range of $825 million to $850 million. I think the
componenttext: Yes, so I would refer you to the assumptions that we gave last quarter. We're not updating every individual assumption. I do believe, for CapEx spending, we will be on the low end of the range. We gave a range of $825 million to $850 million. I think the best place to refer you to for the D&A is the exhibit that has our business excluding Ingevity. As you look at the Q2, I think it showed that the quarterly run rate for D&A excluding Ingevity was just over $270 million. And you can use that as you start to think forward with some additional capital expenditures as we exit the year. We did not go through line by line all the other assumptions, but the pension and postretirement funding is consistent with what we said in January. I actually think the operating cash flow range is also consistent. Cash taxes may be a little bit higher as we look -- I had said that the cash taxes would be in the -- tax rate for the year would be in the mid-, high 20s. I think it'll be just above 30% as we exit the year.

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. Let's see. So I wanted to -- if I could switch gears for a second. Reading through kind of some of the slides and prepared comments, it sounds like you really didn't feel much of an impact from the cuts in box prices or things of tha
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. Let's see. So I wanted to -- if I could switch gears for a second. Reading through kind of some of the slides and prepared comments, it sounds like you really didn't feel much of an impact from the cuts in box prices or things of that nature. It doesn't sound like you're anticipating seeing a lot as the year goes on. I mean, can you maybe give us some color as to how or why? Is some of that, that you have contracts maybe that are annual contracts? Is some of that maybe that it just didn't fit within caps collars? Or if price were to move another $10 and maybe then hit $25 cumulative, does that trigger something? How does that work?

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Chris, we did say our box prices were stable. I think going forward, we have a host of relationships with each of our customers, and we're just reluctant to talk about forward pricing. And so I think what we've done is we've said, whatever pricing im
componenttext: Yes, Chris, we did say our box prices were stable. I think going forward, we have a host of relationships with each of our customers, and we're just reluctant to talk about forward pricing. And so I think what we've done is we've said, whatever pricing impact we're expect to experience is embedded in the cash flow guidance that we give.

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Chip Dillon from Vertical Research Partners.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Chip Dillon from Vertical Research Partners.

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think this is -- the first one is more for Jim on the export situation. We saw yesterday that the largest producer in Europe announced a substantial EUR 40 per metric ton price increase. And I didn't know if you had seen the conditions in Europe get bet
componenttext: I think this is -- the first one is more for Jim on the export situation. We saw yesterday that the largest producer in Europe announced a substantial EUR 40 per metric ton price increase. And I didn't know if you had seen the conditions in Europe get better in the last few weeks that might have led them to make that move.

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Chip, I can't really comment on what another company is doing, but I read the pubs, and we're aware of discussions with our customers, but I can't comment on what another company is doing.
componenttext: Chip, I can't really comment on what another company is doing, but I read the pubs, and we're aware of discussions with our customers, but I can't comment on what another company is doing.

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Or whether you're seeing better conditions there?
componenttext: Or whether you're seeing better conditions there?

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, as I shared in my earlier comments, we're seeing currencies improve a little bit, and global demand is solid and growing. Our customer demand is firm. But beyond that, I really can't comment on forward pricing.
componenttext: Well, as I shared in my earlier comments, we're seeing currencies improve a little bit, and global demand is solid and growing. Our customer demand is firm. But beyond that, I really can't comment on forward pricing.

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got you. And the second question is having to do with the EVOLs and the whole concept of the sheet feeding step. And I'm just wondering, have you, or is it possible to find opportunities to, let's say, go to an independent box customer that you might be s
componenttext: Got you. And the second question is having to do with the EVOLs and the whole concept of the sheet feeding step. And I'm just wondering, have you, or is it possible to find opportunities to, let's say, go to an independent box customer that you might be selling board to and actually convince them that it might be a win-win for you to maybe redirect board, say, from the export market into your own sheet feeder and then to sell them sheets? In other words, is that something that we could see in the future, where the independents basically just do the cutting and folding and not do the sheeting aspect of it?

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, that is, today, part of our business. We sell containerboard in 3 channels. One is to our most important channel, which is our domestic box system, which includes a portfolio of sheet feeders and full-scale corrugated box plants. And so we sell shee
componenttext: Well, that is, today, part of our business. We sell containerboard in 3 channels. One is to our most important channel, which is our domestic box system, which includes a portfolio of sheet feeders and full-scale corrugated box plants. And so we sell sheets to independents and we sell, in some cases, boxes to independents that they do other work on them. So it's -- there's a mix of things that we do domestically and in addition to our other 2 channels of our export customers and our North American independent base. So all 3 of those channels are important, and we try to look for customer opportunities to provide them with something that helps them to win in their markets.

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got you. And last one quickly is I know that when I think of the whole situation with the SP tuck-in, in Coshocton and Uncasville that maybe an indirect return is the $25 million you're saving on the closure half. But I noticed that Dublin, you said last
componenttext: Got you. And last one quickly is I know that when I think of the whole situation with the SP tuck-in, in Coshocton and Uncasville that maybe an indirect return is the $25 million you're saving on the closure half. But I noticed that Dublin, you said last quarter, had lost $7 million, I believe, in the first fiscal quarter. Has that turned positive? And can you give us a sort of an idea of how well that mill is doing?

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Remember, last quarter, we had the Newberg loss. But Dublin is actually -- it's EBITDA positive.
componenttext: Remember, last quarter, we had the Newberg loss. But Dublin is actually -- it's EBITDA positive.

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and it's operating quite well. We're very pleased with its performance. Volumes are up, costs are going down. We've committed to significant synergies with that addition, and we're on track to meet those synergies. So we're really pleased with how th
componenttext: Yes, and it's operating quite well. We're very pleased with its performance. Volumes are up, costs are going down. We've committed to significant synergies with that addition, and we're on track to meet those synergies. So we're really pleased with how that asset has improved our portfolio.

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm sorry, you're right. It was Newberg you said. My apologies.
componenttext: I'm sorry, you're right. It was Newberg you said. My apologies.

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question that we do have comes from the line of Philip Ng of Jefferies.
componenttext: The next question that we do have comes from the line of Philip Ng of Jefferies.

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Last quarter, you guided to building 90,000 tons of inventory ahead of some plant shutdowns and a heavy downtime period. How should we think about the cadence going into 3Q? And a competitor also mentioned that they need -- actually need to hold less inve
componenttext: Last quarter, you guided to building 90,000 tons of inventory ahead of some plant shutdowns and a heavy downtime period. How should we think about the cadence going into 3Q? And a competitor also mentioned that they need -- actually need to hold less inventory with the transportation volume that's improving. Are you seeing that dynamic play out?

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Philip, thank you. We did share last time, and historically, we've given color as to our inventory being managed to ensure that we can give excellent customer service and on-time delivery for our internal box plants and our external customers. And because
componenttext: Philip, thank you. We did share last time, and historically, we've given color as to our inventory being managed to ensure that we can give excellent customer service and on-time delivery for our internal box plants and our external customers. And because of the heavy major maintenance downtime load this quarter, next quarter, we said we would build inventories that peaked in January. And since January, we've seen a decline of about 40,000 tons February and March. And we would expect to further reduce inventories pretty significantly by the end of our fiscal year in the September quarter. And to your point, we, over the last couple of years, have increased inventories in part due to the somewhat eroding supply chain and the rail and truck logistics channels. And we're, frankly, seeing that improve right now. And together with all of the work that our internal supply chain team has done, it's giving us the opportunity to further reduce our inventories going forward.

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Would you be able to quantify the sequential decline from fiscal Q2 to fiscal 3Q?
componenttext: Okay. Would you be able to quantify the sequential decline from fiscal Q2 to fiscal 3Q?

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think you're talking about Bob Beckler, who's retiring. And since you asked, I really appreciated the opportunity to get to know Bob over the past year. He's a quality person who worked for the company for a long time. And I'm obviously, supportive and
componenttext: I think you're talking about Bob Beckler, who's retiring. And since you asked, I really appreciated the opportunity to get to know Bob over the past year. He's a quality person who worked for the company for a long time. And I'm obviously, supportive and wishing him the best going forward. The current organization is, I think, well structured. I think we're -- I think somebody asked a question earlier about cross-selling. And that requires, use the word, nimble to -- communication across the company. And we need the leaders of the converting businesses and the paper businesses to both manage their business, which is there primary responsibility, but, where there's opportunity and we have significant opportunity, we need each one of those leaders to work across the packaging grades on an integrated basis or on an integrated basis with the paper grades to meet the needs of our customers. And I'm very pleased, very excited with the organization we have in place and optimistic about improving the results that we have as we implement our strategy.

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016

componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. If I look at your impact on price mix for your consumer segment, the sequential change was pretty modest. I know one of your competitors were talking about some weakness in some of the commodity grades in plate stock. And now, obviously, PPW cut prices for SBS somewhat recently. Are you surprised by some of those moves? And you talked about how backlogs have improved a bit, and I just wanted to see if you've seen increased competition from some of the European producers on the FPB [ph] front.

It's Friday, so I hope you have a nice weekend, and we look forward to speaking with you in the coming weeks. Thank you very much.

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016

componenttext: Welcome to the WestRock Fiscal 2016 Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] The call is being recorded. If you have any objections, please disconnect at this time. Now I'll turn the meeting over to your host, Mr. Steve Voorhees. Sir, you may now begin.

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Regina. Welcome to our fiscal 2016 second quarter earnings call. I'm Steve Voorhees, Chief Executive Officer. I'm joined this morning by Ward Dickson, Chief Financial Officer; and Jim Porter, President of our Paper Solutions business. During
componenttext:
Thank you, Regina. Welcome to our fiscal 2016 second quarter earnings call. I'm Steve Voorhees, Chief Executive Officer. I'm joined this morning by Ward Dickson, Chief Financial Officer; and Jim Porter, President of our Paper Solutions business. 
During the course of the call, we will make forward-looking statements involving our plans, expectations, estimates and beliefs related to future events. These statements may involve a number of risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those that we discuss during the call. We describe these risks and uncertainties in our filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission and include our 10-K for the fiscal year ending September 30, 2015, and our 10-Q for the period ending December 31, 2015. 
We will refer to non-GAAP financial measures during the call. We've provided reconciliations of these non-GAAP measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measures in the appendix of the slide presentation, which is available on our website. 
Before Ward and I discuss our quarterly results in detail, I want to take a moment to underscore the reasons why WestRock is a compelling value-creation opportunity. WestRock holds #1 or #2 positions in attractive paper and packaging markets. We're providing differentiated, tailored packaging solutions that help our customers win in the marketplace. Our strategy is sound, and we're achieving the objectives that we outlined when we created WestRock. We've already delivered $350 million or over 1/3 of our $1 billion synergy and performance improvement target in the past 9 months. We expect to be at an annualized run rate of $450 million to $500 million by the end of our fiscal year in September. 
We've added to the strength of our business, most recently through the formation of our joint venture with Grupo Gondi, the leading paper and packaging company in Mexico. And with the separation of Ingevity over the next 2 weeks, we will remove a noncore business from our portfolio. 
We manage our business to generate long-term cash flow, and we're maintaining our free cash flow guidance of $950 million to $1 billion for fiscal 2016. After adjusting for the separation of Ingevity, this would provide an attractive 10% free cash flow yield at our current share price. 
We're returning our free cash flow to stockholders through our $1.50 per share annual dividend that we plan to maintain after the separation of Ingevity. We're continuing our balanced capital allocation strategy that includes paying a very attractive dividend, reinvesting in our businesses, pursuing bolt-on acquisitions and share repurchases with our 2.25 to 2.5x leverage ratio target. All told, we're executing well on our strategy, and this is reflected in our results for the quarter.
WestRock sales for the March quarter were $3.7 billion, an adjusted earnings per share were  $0.61. We performed well, both commercially and operationally. Over the last 12 months, our Credit Agreement EBITDA margin was 17.4%. We generated adjusted free cash flow of $81 million in the quarter and a total of $432 million fiscal year-to-date. 
The impact of our synergies and performance improvements is being reflected in our reported financial results. The March quarter, productivity improvements increased EBITDA by $103 million year-over-year. 
We repurchased 3.7 million shares in the March quarter at an average price of $39. About half of these purchases were in January at a price of $43 per share. The other half of these purchases were in February and March at an average price of $35 per share. Since July 1, with the inception of WestRock, we've repurchased 11.2 million shares, and we've returned $856 million in capital to stockholders through dividends and share repurchases. 
In the corrugated industry, domestic end-use markets are flat to slightly up. Operating rates have continued to be in the mid-90s with declining inventories overall, and we're headed into the seasonally stronger time of the year. 
Our Corrugated Packaging business continues to improve with good operational and commercial execution. E-commerce, dairy and produce markets were strong for us in the quarter, with some softness in beverage, retail and bakery. 
Corrugated Packaging net sales in the quarter were $1.9 billion with EBITDA of $316 million. North American corrugated EBITDA margins of 17.5% increased by 20 basis points over the prior year. Total segment shipments in the quarter were 2.2 million tons, an increase of 5% over last year in large part to the increased kraft bag volumes at our mill in Dublin, Georgia. 
We continue to balance our supply with customer demand. The majority of the 30,000 tons of economic downtime that we took this quarter was medium downtime in January in advance of the final closure date at Uncasville. Our mills system was in balance during February and March. We've taken 35,000 tons of maintenance and economic downtime so far in April. 10,000 tons of the 35,000 has been economic downtime. 
While our shipments of containerboard to the domestic independent market declined by 8,000 tons sequentially, our average price per ton for this portfolio of sales to this market increased by between $1 and $2 per ton sequentially. This was principally due to the positive mix change where we sold an increasing proportion of liner and white top liner.
Export demand remained solid, although pricing remains very competitive due to the strength of the U.S. dollar and the availability of supply from Brazil, Russia and Finland. We exported 304,000 tons, 18,000 tons more than last year, while our mix of export business was consistent with 62% going to Latin America and the rest going to a combination of Europe, the Middle East and Asia. Our portfolio of export pricing declined $43 per ton compared to last year and was down $18 per ton sequentially. 
Turning to our North American box business. Our box pricing was stable, both compared to last year and sequentially. Our domestic box shipments were slightly up on an absolute basis and down 1% on a same-day basis as compared to last year. Last year was a very strong quarter for WestRock and is, therefore, a very tough comparison. We're experiencing similar pricing and volume trends so far this quarter. 
We feel good about the demand environment and see positive momentum with the commercial opportunities we have and how we're competing and winning in the marketplace. We're improving operationally as a result of our productivity programs and our ongoing capital investment to upgrade our capabilities. 
We're now installing the 21st of 30 EVOLs, a project that started 2 years ago that we expect to complete by the middle of fiscal year '17. We've grown our volumes in excess of the industry in 13 of the last 15 months and continue to be confident in our ability to profitably grow our box business. 
In Brazil, our performance remained strong despite challenges the country is facing. Our combined corrugated box and container board shipments increased by 13%. We're capitalizing on strong mill performance and weak local currency to profitably export linerboard to offset the impact of a contracting domestic box market. 
Now turning to our Consumer Packaging business. Favorable financial performance year-over-year was driven by strong operational and commercial performance, and we continue to realize merger synergy benefits. 
Consumer Packaging net sales for the quarter were $1.6 billion and EBITDA was $224 million, up from the $181 million in the prior year quarter. We delivered $58 million in productivity improvements year-over-year, reflecting the great progress that we're making in integrating our Consumer Packaging businesses and realizing the synergies and performance improvements available to us. 
Industry backlogs for all of our consumer board grades stabilized during the quarter. We exited the quarter with backlogs ranging from 2 to 4 weeks, and are now moving from the 3- to 5-week range.
In SBS, our shipments increase 50,000 tons in the second quarter. This was fueled by solid growth in tobacco, food service, the on-boarding of the Carolina brand business and additional internal demand from our folding carton plants. 
Tobacco. We're continuing to have success in business development with China premium tobacco brands. We see solid growth in food service cup, driven by the ongoing conversion of foam cups to more sustainable paper cups. 
In commercial print, we are successful in working with our merchant partners to capitalize on the strength of our expanded offering of SBS for commercial print. This offering now includes both the Carolina and Tango brands. We're pleased with the integration of the Carolina brand, and we manufactured 12,000 tons of this product in the quarter. We expect the Carolina tons that we manufacture to increase to an annual rate in excess of 150,000 tons during the June quarter. 
Our Covington and Demopolis mills performed so well that we needed to balance supply with demand in our SBS system. As a result, we produced 31,000 tons more pulp, primarily at Evadale. Pulp prices were $73 per ton lower than last year. This is reflected in the pulp price/mix shown on the bridge. 
More broadly, in the paperboard markets, we're seeing limited penetration from European and Asian competitors. Pricing was stable in our core markets, with some discounting in more commodity portions of the food service plate and folding carton markets. The recent published price reductions covering SBS, CRB and URB in Pulp & Paper Week will have limited impact in fiscal year '16. This limited impact is reflected in our cash flow guidance. 
The SBS price decrease applies only to general folding carton markets to less than 50% of our total SBS volume. The folding carton markets remained challenged by soft primary demand for processed, frozen and dry foods. This is consistent with the ongoing consumer preference for fresh foods and the shrinking center of the supermarket. With this backdrop, our folding carton team performed exceedingly well during the quarter and is benefiting from our differentiated strategy. 
We're now on-boarding new folding customers that were previously only box customers of WestRock, and we've secured new business for our SBS, CRB and CNK systems. Folding carton volumes grew by 6% in the quarter and 2% excluding the impact of the Cenveo acquisition. Integration of the Cenveo facilities into our folding carton business has been successful. The business is performing at expectations.
In our beverage business we've achieved gains in global beer and sparkling water markets that offset the continued weakness in traditional carbonated soft drink demand, primarily in North America. We are growing with customers that have packaging needs that correspond well with our strategy and capabilities, including craft brewers, new product introductions and paperboard multipacks in Latin America and China. 
Home, health and beauty had a very strong quarter, with EBITDA margins of more than 18%, driven by positive sales mix, especially in Europe, continued cost focus and a record productivity quarter for the business. 
In merchandising displays, customer promotional activity has stabilized, and we're entering a seasonally stronger time of the year. We're taking action to balance our capacity with current market demand, which will improve our cost structure and improve our margins. We have tremendous capabilities in our display business, and over the past several months, we've received 31 industry awards for work we performed to support companies such as: Procter & Gamble, Pfizer, Johnson & Johnson, Colgate, Coca-Cola and Newell Brands. 
We're nearing completion of our review of our Land and Development portfolio. Working with the team in Charleston, we've accelerated the monetization of some projects. That's reflected in a significant increase in our sales under contract figures. 
The original plan for this year had modestly negative cash flows and current plans have positive pretax cash flows for the year. We'll share more detail with you in the upcoming quarters on our progress in monetizing specific projects within our portfolio. 
The separation of Ingevity is expected to occur on May 15. The Ingevity management team, led by Michael Wilson, will be on their equity road show over the next 2 weeks. As part of the separation, WestRock will receive a distribution of $518 million and retain approximately $438 million in cash after expenses that we can use for general corporate purchases -- purposes. Ingevity has the right team and strategy in place. I'm looking forward to following Ingevity's successes as an independent company.
As a result of the separation, WestRock's Credit Agreement EBITDA will decline by the amount generated by Ingevity or about $200 million in EBITDA on a trailing basis. After adjusting for this, WestRock's leverage ratio post separation will be in the 2.35 to 2.4x range, within our target. 
We've outlined WestRock's results for the quarter both with and without Ingevity, and these numbers should help you in your modeling. Ingevity contributed $0.08 in adjusted EPS in the quarter. The June 2016 quarter, will reflect the 6 weeks of Ingevity operations as discontinued operations.
We closed on our new joint venture in Mexico with Grupo Gondi on April 1. We believe that Gondi is the premier operator in the market. Based on their recent performance, we expect the joint venture to generate annual sales of more than $750 million and EBITDA margins in excess of 20%. We're currently supplying the joint venture with containerboard at a rate of 250,000 tons per year. Importantly, the $175 million that we've contributed to the joint venture will remain in the joint venture and be available to support its growth. As an example, Gondi has just started production on a new state-of-the-art 120,000-metric-ton box plant in Nava. This plant is adjacent to the new Constellation Brands brewery. This joint venture accelerates our ability to win in the growing Mexican packaging market and gives both WestRock and Gondi many new growth opportunities. 
Now I'll turn the call over to Ward.

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: As Steve indicated, we are executing very well on our synergy and performance improvement objective, with strong results across our entire company. We exited the March quarter with an annualized run rate of savings of $350 million. We continue to realize
componenttext:
As Steve indicated, we are executing very well on our synergy and performance improvement objective, with strong results across our entire company. We exited the March quarter with an annualized run rate of savings of $350 million. We continue to realize procurement and logistics savings, and the expanded scale we now have enables us to be more efficient overall. We can balance our system over this larger footprint, producing the right products in the right locations to better serve our customers and maximize efficiency.
In addition, work is continuing to streamline our businesses and corporate functions across our company. We expect to be in the $450 million to $500 million run rate range by this September, and we remain on track to achieve our $1 billion goal by the end of FY '18. Adjusted segment EBITDA increased $29 million due primarily to the $103 million in productivity, commodity input cost deflation of $37 million and the flow-through of these into our businesses. The negative pulp price and mix impact across our corrugated and consumer businesses was $23 million. Natural gas was the biggest input cost savings area with $21 million in lower cost compared to the prior year. 
Lower chemicals, freight, diesel, wood, fiber and other costs contributed an additional $16 million to income. The reduction in pension income is a noncash charge that negatively affects earnings. 
Before turning it back to Steve, I want to take a minute to discuss our cash flow, outlook and assumptions. We are maintaining our cash flow guidance for FY '16 of $950 million to $1 billion. As we think about our business for the third quarter, there are several key items to help you with your modeling. As a starting point. Our March adjusted EPS of $0.61 includes $0.08 of Ingevity. Using that adjusted base and looking sequentially, you should consider some of the following trends that will affect our earnings in the June quarter: we expect to see some seasonal volume increases, with negative price and mix across our businesses related to export markets and the PPW changes in both corrugated and consumer grades; we anticipate price inflation in some commodity categories, including natural gas and recycled fiber; our book tax rates are expected to be in the range of 34% to 36%. Net of any contribution from Ingevity, we expect an increase in adjusted earnings per share in the June quarter as compared to the March quarter. 
I will now turn the call back over to Steve.

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ward. We're enthusiastic about our strategy, our performance and our outlook. WestRock's a compelling value-creation opportunity. We have outstanding people and assets and a strategy to provide differentiated products and services that help our cu
componenttext:
Thanks, Ward. We're enthusiastic about our strategy, our performance and our outlook. WestRock's a compelling value-creation opportunity. We have outstanding people and assets and a strategy to provide differentiated products and services that help our customers win in their markets. We're delivering on the objectives we set out when we created WestRock, and we're well on our way to achieving our synergy and performance improvement target that contributed to over $100 million in productivity gains in the quarter. We've added to the strength of our business and our growth prospects through the formation of our joint venture with Grupo Gondi, the leading paper and packaging company in Mexico. 
With the separation of Ingevity next month, we'll remove a noncore business from our portfolio. 
We're generating attractive free cash flow returns, have the opportunity to grow this cash flow over time through execution of our strategy. We're returning a significant portion of our cash flow to stockholders through dividends and share repurchases. 
Our strategy, execution and results to date position us well to create significant long-term value for investors. 
And now with that, I'd like to open the call for your questions.

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of George Staphos from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of George Staphos from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I had 2 questions to start and I'll turn it over. First of all, can you talk, at all, about how volumes in corrugated and also in folding cartons progressed over the quarter that just concluded? Were things stronger coming out of the quarter? That would b
componenttext: I had 2 questions to start and I'll turn it over. First of all, can you talk, at all, about how volumes in corrugated and also in folding cartons progressed over the quarter that just concluded? Were things stronger coming out of the quarter? That would be our expectation. And what are you seeing, early days, obviously, in the fiscal third quarter in terms of volumes? And then, my other question, Steve, you provided a little bit of color or commentary anyway about boxboard price declines in Pulp & Paper Week and how it's having a relatively limited effect on your results for this year. How much is that is -- if -- to the extent that you can comment, driven by the contractual legs that you have in your business? How much of it is driven by the fact that it only affects general purpose, and that's not where all of your business is? Any additional clarity there would be helpful.

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so I'm going to start with the second question, then Jim can talk about the first question. The second question. CRB and URB, the PPW changes will impact those. As you would imagine, in consumer markets, that takes a little bit longer to just pass th
componenttext: Yes, so I'm going to start with the second question, then Jim can talk about the first question. The second question. CRB and URB, the PPW changes will impact those. As you would imagine, in consumer markets, that takes a little bit longer to just pass through the system. Then on SBS, I didn't include it in the comments, but like about half of our volumes would be affected by PPW that would go to the pulp and paper [ph] markets, and the other half would be just much less sensitive to that. And again, the consumer packaging markets, just how -- the contractual process is much more delayed than you'd experience on corrugated.

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016

componenttext: Sure. And just on that half that is affected by PPW, that's bleached board, that's also lagged more than we would see, obviously, in -- sorry, corrugated markets, is that correct?

componenttext: Yes. Exactly. Yes. Okay, I'm going to -- yes, I'll let Jim comment on the volumes that we experienced through the quarter.

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So box volumes previous quarter and current quarter. So first of all, I couldn't be more excited about how our Corrugated Packaging business is operating. Just made tremendous improvement from a culture and quality service innovation and satisfying our cu
componenttext: So box volumes previous quarter and current quarter. So first of all, I couldn't be more excited about how our Corrugated Packaging business is operating. Just made tremendous improvement from a culture and quality service innovation and satisfying our customers, which really is the foundation of the wins that we've been seeing. Really proud of the team. And that's allowed us to equal or exceed the industry performance in 13 out of the last 15 months. However, comps are getting a little tougher. The second quarter of '15, we were up 6.5% on a per-day basis. So this past quarter, we were virtually flat on an absolute basis -- or up slightly, that is, and down slightly on a per-day basis. So that is a little bit behind the industry. But we're -- we've got a very strong pipeline of new opportunities, and we would expect to see some seasonal strengthening as we go into Q3. And so therefore, we would expect to be relatively flat with another difficult quarter last year because we were up 4.5%. And -- but I think the climate is improving, and I'm confident in our team's ability to drive innovation and wins for our customers.

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two questions. First, hoping to get, if possible, some sort of sense of the pace you might anticipate on the share repurchase, whether the $150 million or so that we saw in the prior quarter, is that the type of quarterly rate? Because that would tie in,
componenttext: Two questions. First, hoping to get, if possible, some sort of sense of the pace you might anticipate on the share repurchase, whether the $150 million or so that we saw in the prior quarter, is that the type of quarterly rate? Because that would tie in, I guess, to if you take your free cash flow and divide it by 4 and subtract your dividend, that sort of is kind of the number you come up with. Or are there other parts to the equation that could potentially make that accelerate? And then second, unrelatedly, you -- I think if you look in your presentation, your corrugated shipments were up about 100,000 tons this year versus last year, and I think box shipments were pretty flat. And I thought you basically only talked about a small increase in exports and actually a decrease in domestic. So I'm just trying to foot all that information.

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark, I'm going to let Ward respond to the footing. But I think, on the share repurchases, I think we've been consistent in our balanced capital allocation strategy. I think in the 9 months since the merger, we've allocated a total of $1.9 billion of capi
componenttext: Mark, I'm going to let Ward respond to the footing. But I think, on the share repurchases, I think we've been consistent in our balanced capital allocation strategy. I think in the 9 months since the merger, we've allocated a total of $1.9 billion of capital. And I'll just go through the math on that, which is $645 million to capital investments, $380 million to acquisitions. Then we've returned $850 million to shareholders. $290 million of that's been in dividends and $567 million has been through share repurchase. We're within our target leverage range. And I think you should expect us to maintain our balanced allocation strategy going forward. How that fits from quarter to quarter, I think it's premature to comment on that right now.

headline: WestRock Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
