headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Both of those segments that -- well said, demand is solid however, backlogs have retreated somewhat in the beverage business as we all know is seasonally strengthening somewhat below prior years, but it's still a solid market for us. Clearly, the craft br
componenttext: Both of those segments that -- well said, demand is solid however, backlogs have retreated somewhat in the beverage business as we all know is seasonally strengthening somewhat below prior years, but it's still a solid market for us. Clearly, the craft brewers is a growth segment. And so we will yes, match our supply with demand, and that's the landscape in the CNK area. CRB backlogs in the 2- to 3-week range and certainly, its competitive in the true board segments of the market, but we like our portfolio, we have a very strong customer base and I think we will succeed in those markets.

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I guess, a question for Ward. I'm not sure if you're prepared to give too much color on '17, but with input cost rising a bit, some sort of jump pricing, offset by synergies and I guess, CapEx is looking a lighter than we baked in. Is that $950
componenttext: Okay. And I guess, a question for Ward. I'm not sure if you're prepared to give too much color on '17, but with input cost rising a bit, some sort of jump pricing, offset by synergies and I guess, CapEx is looking a lighter than we baked in. Is that $950 million, $2 billion type free cash flow threshold kind of sustainable when we think about 2017?

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're in the early stages of doing our fiscal year 2017 plan. We're not prepared to give guidance for 2017. We did give what our ongoing CapEx would be as we move forward into 2017. We feel really good about the runway that we have related to the performa
componenttext: We're in the early stages of doing our fiscal year 2017 plan. We're not prepared to give guidance for 2017. We did give what our ongoing CapEx would be as we move forward into 2017. We feel really good about the runway that we have related to the performance improvements in synergy targets. We will have inflationary pressures just like the rest of our peers in this segment. We will -- as we put the plan together though, we also have to assess what we think the opportunities are going to be from a volume and price point of view. So we're not prepared to give 2017 cash flow guidance, but we are piercing through the high end of our range for 2016.

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then just last one for me. Now that you guys have spun off Ingevity, should we expect buybacks to tick up? And just want to get your thoughts what you're seeing on the M&A pipeline side. I mean, there's obviously been a few bucks
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then just last one for me. Now that you guys have spun off Ingevity, should we expect buybacks to tick up? And just want to get your thoughts what you're seeing on the M&A pipeline side. I mean, there's obviously been a few bucks transactions in the marketplace for your integration value. It wouldn't be a bad thing for you, guys. Just wanted some thoughts in terms of capital deployment for the next year or 2.

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Philip, we're going to continue to implement our balanced capital allocation strategy. As far as stock buybacks, we brought back about $50 million this quarter, that's a $200 million run rate, which is in line with where our cash flow generation is. As fa
componenttext: Philip, we're going to continue to implement our balanced capital allocation strategy. As far as stock buybacks, we brought back about $50 million this quarter, that's a $200 million run rate, which is in line with where our cash flow generation is. As far as the acquisition, we continue to look at acquisitions and like you should expect us to continue look at acquisitions and take advantage of the opportunities that we see to improve our business. It's part of our strategy.

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Chip Dillon of Vertical Research.
componenttext: Our next question is from Chip Dillon of Vertical Research.

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question is on the land fill situation. I know that when Plum Creek did the deal with U.S. Vaco about 3 years ago, the all in value of the land imply around were I think $530 million. And it looks like if I have to separate, you're expecting $600 mi
componenttext: First question is on the land fill situation. I know that when Plum Creek did the deal with U.S. Vaco about 3 years ago, the all in value of the land imply around were I think $530 million. And it looks like if I have to separate, you're expecting $600 million more on the top of that $75 million, I think you just got if I got that right. And so does that sort of a fair representation of kind of how much that land value has gone up over those 3 years? So the all-in value might be closer to $700 million? Or am I -- are there's still more lands in addition to the 68,000 acres?

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: That is a tough question for me to look back that far. What I can tell you is I -- we looked back and presented to the board last week a look back of the total proceeds of the Land and Development operation. And I found an investor presentation that was d
componenttext: That is a tough question for me to look back that far. What I can tell you is I -- we looked back and presented to the board last week a look back of the total proceeds of the Land and Development operation. And I found an investor presentation that was done by MeadWestvaco team in 2011 and they projected what the gross proceeds are going to be a across all of the whole things. And we looked at the sales today from 2011 to now and what we think we're going to realize, we're actually in the higher end up the range that the projected back in 2011. So we feel good about the progress. We feel very good about the accelerated monetization strategy that we have, and we have confidence that we have and we're  going to be able to generate the $600 million in gross proceeds from the $275 million to $300 million of after-tax cash flows to WestRock.

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And as you -- let say that to you continue to get a little bit better than the step up basis. That I would assume that as each quarters you sell land, and you get some above your basis, you would just continue to report that the sort of ongoing earn
componenttext: Okay. And as you -- let say that to you continue to get a little bit better than the step up basis. That I would assume that as each quarters you sell land, and you get some above your basis, you would just continue to report that the sort of ongoing earnings just so there could be a little bit of lumpiness like we saw this quarter? Is that something we should expect? And nothing major, but I would imagine that could be -- could it be a $10 million or $15 million one quarter, 0 the next?

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Exactly. Because remember, we valued each project within the portfolio, and we feel very confident about the aggregate that we will exceed the purchase price, original purchase price that was done and the merger accounting, but we could have some ups and
componenttext: Exactly. Because remember, we valued each project within the portfolio, and we feel very confident about the aggregate that we will exceed the purchase price, original purchase price that was done and the merger accounting, but we could have some ups and downs on the individual projects. And that would cost some earnings contribution and volatility from quarter-to-quarter.

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just last question just on the Containerboard business. Are you happy now in the sense of where your inventory should now down to. Do you feel like there's more reduction required? And then, I guess, just flipping it around, how do you thin
componenttext: Okay. And then just last question just on the Containerboard business. Are you happy now in the sense of where your inventory should now down to. Do you feel like there's more reduction required? And then, I guess, just flipping it around, how do you think about the industry now on a cost perspective? It would seem like even globally that we had seen cost basically moving down for the last 2, 3 years but now it looks like suddenly there up meaningfully especially outside the U.S. on the fiber side. And here, not only on the OCC side as well, but on that gas. Is that sort of change the way you think the business dynamics look at least next year and the year after versus what we saw in the past?

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, Chip, this is Jim. I'll take that one. First of all, in our inventories as we've -- I shared on previous calls, we manage our inventories at a very granular level and the whole purpose of our inventory is to make sure that we are able to pro
componenttext: Good morning, Chip, this is Jim. I'll take that one. First of all, in our inventories as we've -- I shared on previous calls, we manage our inventories at a very granular level and the whole purpose of our inventory is to make sure that we are able to provide our customers on time delivery and using the best way freight. Also said that coming out of our heavy outage period this past couple of quarters, we would be reducing inventories this quarter, and that's exactly what we did. Frankly, from the February peak, we were down 191,000 tons and quarter-over-quarter, 152, so that's a substantial drop in inventories as we said we would. Where we are currently? I think we like our position. The logistics network and our supply chain capabilities have improved dramatically, rail cart availability, truck freight availability, I think leads us to the point where we pleased currently. There will always be some pluses and minuses and maybe over time, a small incremental further reduction. So I hope that gives you color on that front. On the cost, there's no question that we're facing some headwinds on natural gas and fiber, and you have normal inflation. However, we also have a nice pipeline of productivity. So we think overall, our cost structure in our North American containerboard mill system is one that we have opportunities to further improve. The competitiveness globally, which I think you were implying is all currency-related and certainly, we can't control that. So I hope that helped your question, Chip.

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from the line of Mark Wilde of Bank of Montral.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from the line of Mark Wilde of Bank of Montral.

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions. The first one. Steve, you talked about the interest in kind of more acquisitions going forward. I wondered if you could just help give us kind of thoughts about where we might see that take place. I know there are questions about ju
componenttext: A couple of questions. The first one. Steve, you talked about the interest in kind of more acquisitions going forward. I wondered if you could just help give us kind of thoughts about where we might see that take place. I know there are questions about just from a regulatory standpoint how much bigger you could get in the boxboard business and maybe in the Containerboard business North America versus say, doing more things in Latin America or maybe in Europe or elsewhere.

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I think we start by looking at acquisitions as we want to do those that improve our business. I think we do see opportunities in our North American corrugated and consumer packaging businesses, I think Cenveo was a relatively small transaction. SP F
componenttext: Sure. I think we start by looking at acquisitions as we want to do those that improve our business. I think we do see opportunities in our North American corrugated and consumer packaging businesses, I think Cenveo was a relatively small transaction. SP Fiber would fit into that. I know you're very familiar with Gondi, Mark. I think Latin America fits very well with our company. We have a great business in Brazil. We'd like to invest more in that. We export 60% of our containerboard to Latin America, so that's a very natural place for us to grow. So I think that would remain, I think, outside the U.S. primary focus. We do have strong operations in Europe and Asia, and I think those we would look at as well. But the opportunity has to fit our business and has to make our business better.

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. The following question I had, Steve, was just back in the SBS is market. You mentioned specifically that you weren't seeing a lot of pressure from Asian and European SBS. I assume that, that was coming into the U.S. And I just wondered if you could
componenttext: Okay. The following question I had, Steve, was just back in the SBS is market. You mentioned specifically that you weren't seeing a lot of pressure from Asian and European SBS. I assume that, that was coming into the U.S. And I just wondered if you could talk about your export business because when I look at the trade data so far this year, all the SBS grades are down pretty sure.

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'm going to let Jim respond to that, Mark.
componenttext: Yes, I'm going to let Jim respond to that, Mark.

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, Mark. As you know, our portfolio of paperboard grades is very focused on the premium end of the marketplace where we're serving the most demanding market segments in tobacco and commercial print, liquid packaging and specialty polycoated app
componenttext: Good morning, Mark. As you know, our portfolio of paperboard grades is very focused on the premium end of the marketplace where we're serving the most demanding market segments in tobacco and commercial print, liquid packaging and specialty polycoated applications. And so in North America, we compete very well, and that's the reason Steve's remarks has remarks that we've seen negligible penetration into our markets competing against our premium grades. In the international markets, we used those products in exactly the same way, and we have excellent customers in literally all the regions in the world that value our premium substrates, and we've seen very consistent demand for those products and we'll  see so going forward.

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: If I can just add, Mark. I'd add one. I've gone to Europe and Asia and talked to our sales force. They are incredibly talented at taking the needs of the customers and translating it into the specific quality of paper that they need. That is just remarkab
componenttext: If I can just add, Mark. I'd add one. I've gone to Europe and Asia and talked to our sales force. They are incredibly talented at taking the needs of the customers and translating it into the specific quality of paper that they need. That is just remarkable to me to see what they do. And when you look at the overall volumes that we export, it ends up being a -- I think more of a -- it's a differentiated business but more an issue business because we're taking our technology and talent and just serving the precise needs of our customers. So it's on point to our strategy.

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Mark Connelly of CLSA.
componenttext: Our next question is from Mark Connelly of CLSA.

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Scott Liebman in for Mark. Just a quick question for you. Is WestRock still being selective in meal reinvestment that it makes on the containerboard side similar to Rock-Tenn and how they were. And I'm curious as whether your selective reinvestmen
componenttext: This is Scott Liebman in for Mark. Just a quick question for you. Is WestRock still being selective in meal reinvestment that it makes on the containerboard side similar to Rock-Tenn and how they were. And I'm curious as whether your selective reinvestment to strengthen some of the mills but not others has achieved what you wanted thus far? And would you say you're closer to a steady-state? Are you whether -- whether you still selectively reinvesting with a view to further rationalize the number of mills as one of your competitors has done pretty successfully in the recent years?

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, Scott. We have a very rigorous capital investment process within both our mill and our packaging operations. And I don't think it has changed. You referenced Rock-Tenn to the present, I don't think there's been any systemic change. We deploy
componenttext: Good morning, Scott. We have a very rigorous capital investment process within both our mill and our packaging operations. And I don't think it has changed. You referenced Rock-Tenn to the present, I don't think there's been any systemic change. We deploy capital to ensure that safety and environmental strength of each of our assets and then we deploy capital to maintain our assets in a highly efficient way and most of all, we try to tap into the creative opportunities to make our businesses better, and it's a very rigorous process that we would see continuing.

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Helpful. And then just one follow on. When you did the SP Fiber deal, you said you expected significant synergies and for the deal to be accretive in the second half of this year. And you've obviously changed the footprint there since the transaction was
componenttext: Helpful. And then just one follow on. When you did the SP Fiber deal, you said you expected significant synergies and for the deal to be accretive in the second half of this year. And you've obviously changed the footprint there since the transaction was made. Was that part of the original plan, and do you still think that SP will be accretive in the second half? And just over a the transaction are you getting the benefits that you expected?

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We are getting the benefits we expected. Newberg was not a significant contributor to the overall economics of the transaction so Dublin is the asset that fits very well into our system. We did come up with a -- for Dublin, if you look at the -- say the p
componenttext: We are getting the benefits we expected. Newberg was not a significant contributor to the overall economics of the transaction so Dublin is the asset that fits very well into our system. We did come up with a -- for Dublin, if you look at the -- say the productivity improvements that we expected over the first 3 years, our goal at the time we announced the transaction is $41 million. We're now, after less than 1 year, we're at $40 million. So we're not quite what we achieved, but we're kind of we're  effectively that. And we have line of sight to $46 million and more. We took our board there last week and the millwork rate -- frankly, people looked better on production is on track. It's a good fit in our system. We're selling a new product for us, in recycled kraft bag and that worked very well. Our productivity programs are in place and the mill continues to fit really well in our system. So this is -- right now, it's worked out I think better than we anticipated at the time we announced the transaction.

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Anthony Pettinari of Citi.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Anthony Pettinari of Citi.

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could talk a little bit about market conditions in Brazil. Your box shipments declined in the quarter for you and the industry. Are you seeing any civilization or maybe improvement there in terms of local demand or do you expect it
componenttext: I was wondering if you could talk a little bit about market conditions in Brazil. Your box shipments declined in the quarter for you and the industry. Are you seeing any civilization or maybe improvement there in terms of local demand or do you expect it in the second half? And then to the extent that you can, can you talk a bit about the price increase that was announced there?

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, Anthony. Brazil is, first of all, an incredible asset for us. The forest land, the Trs Barras mill are really state-of-the-art and our integrated packaging portfolio is great business for us and is performing extremely well. We're all well
componenttext: Good morning, Anthony. Brazil is, first of all, an incredible asset for us. The forest land, the Trs Barras mill are really state-of-the-art and our integrated packaging portfolio is great business for us and is performing extremely well. We're all well aware of the political and economic challenges in Brazil and I don't know that I could necessarily predict the trend line going forward on that whole thing, but I would say, it will improve over time, I'm not just not sure the pace of that. Relative to our ability to compete, I think we have superior assets and the quality and capability of both our containerboard and the products coming out of our converting system are winning in the marketplace. And so as the economy improves, we're going to win. Now the beauty is we also have a very low-cost mill that's able to toggle between domestic consumption and export, so you've seen our export shipments increase over time. So net-net, I love our position in Brazil.

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just kind of following up on that I mean it seems like there's a lot of local producers there who might be much higher costs, CC prices have come up pretty sharply there. When you think about [indiscernible] market position in Brazil over t
componenttext: Okay. And then just kind of following up on that I mean it seems like there's a lot of local producers there who might be much higher costs, CC prices have come up pretty sharply there. When you think about [indiscernible] market position in Brazil over this very deep recession, have you been gaining share? Have there been smaller local guys who have dropped out? Any kind of color you can give on the market dynamics there may be in the last  year, 1.5 years?

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't know that I can speak to our competitors falling out. I just know I love our position. I think we have premium -- a premium version product coming out of the state-of-the-art mill that's vertically-integrated great packaging system and a forest re
componenttext: I don't know that I can speak to our competitors falling out. I just know I love our position. I think we have premium -- a premium version product coming out of the state-of-the-art mill that's vertically-integrated great packaging system and a forest resource that makes us very low cost. So I like our position.

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Scott Gaffner of Barclays.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Scott Gaffner of Barclays.

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016

componenttext: Steve, just to go back, the follow up question on this new business pipeline, has there been any change in the way that you approach the sales team? Are we up against easy comps over last year? Anything you could talk about the go-to-market strategy that would have any consequence and that would be great. I know the reason I asked is you go from the minings, too, in the quarter to plus 1.7% in July that seems to be a pretty big inflection point.

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we worked into the core comments that over the past year, this fiscal year, volumes are up slightly. We do not focus on, call it, quarter-to-quarter or month-to-month changes in our volumes. I know the investment community does, so we in turn
componenttext: Yes, I think we worked into the core comments that over the past year, this fiscal year, volumes are up slightly. We do not focus on, call it, quarter-to-quarter or month-to-month changes in our volumes. I know the investment community does, so we in turn have to focus on it. But I think we're focusing on building a company that is very profitable and generates long-term cash flows. So we are very focused in container, but we have a very structured way to go to market. So if you come to work at WestRock, you go through certain training, and you go to market in a very consistent way and then we're in the process of say rolling that out, broader -- more fully across WestRock, and we're in a position to do that. And I just came across something that Gallup, they have an email that they send out periodically that covers just all sorts of different topics. They sent one out yesterday and their conclusion was, they find most companies can double their revenue by simply selling more to the existing customer base. And I just repeat that because that's really on point to what we're doing. So most of our customers will buy folded carton to buy boxes, and we're taking sales force, and we're going to market to identify those customers we can go to and have value to team. And so I think that's a long-winded answer to your question, but I'm very pleased with what we're doing, and we're building that capability over the long term and our volumes will go up or down from quarter-to-quarter, but I think if you look at the overall portfolio of business we're generating, it's a very attractive portfolio of business. And I think I'm going to go on because we're supplementing that with capital. And so just for -- in container, I think we've been very clear about the investment we're doing with respect to the EVOLs. And as far as our capital budget process I talked about earlier, we go back and look at our all our capitals as to whether it does what we thought it was going to do, at least in container, as far this process, we will be at $80 million in capital projects in our box business and a lot of them are EVOLs. There were other projects as well. That actual was within 1% of what we thought it was going to be. The actual returns, we estimate it at 15% after tax. The actuals were 20%. So they were well in excess of what we thought whether we made the investment. So we have for us our business to go to market in a way which is very different for us and then back that up with the investment in capital and talent to make the business, I think we'll create a lot value in the long term by doing that.

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016

componenttext: Adam, I'll start with the second one first. So we had capital investments from our specialty chemicals business of approximately $45 million during the period of time that they were part of WestRock, part of the spin. So that's your reference point [indiscernible]. If I go back and a look at the free cash flow guidance that we gave earlier in the year, a lot of things changed. We had pricing changes in the marketplace, we had inflationary pressures. If I were to give you the reference point of what -- why we're going to generate that the higher cash flow come out the higher end of the range, I think earnings are better. I think our working capital source that we talked about it at that point in time is actually lower. The other cash items such as cash taxes, I think they're very consistent with the assumption that we laid out back in earlier in the year and then CapEx is clearly on the lower end of the range that we had identified at the beginning of the year. I think we'll even come in just below the $825 million that we have described. So again, I think it's a earnings, working capital is not as big of use as we described back then you could the remaining balance sheet items are fairly consistent and then lower CapEx.

Now I'll turn the meeting over to your host, Mr. Matthew Tractenberg. Sir, you may begin.

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Nicole. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to our fiscal 2016 third quarter earnings call. My name is Matt Tractenberg, I'm WestRock's new Vice President of Investor Relations, and I'm excited to be here. I'm joined this morning by Steve V
componenttext:
Thank you, Nicole. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to our fiscal 2016 third quarter earnings call. 
My name is Matt Tractenberg, I'm WestRock's new Vice President of Investor Relations, and I'm excited to be here. 
I'm joined this morning by Steve Voorhees, WestRock's Chief Executive Officer; Ward Dickson, our Chief Financial Officer; and Jim Porter, President of our Paper Solutions business.  
During the course of today's call, we will make forward-looking statements involving our plans, expectations, estimates and beliefs related to future events. These statements may involve a number of risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those that we discuss during the call. We describe these risks and uncertainties in our filings with the SEC, including our 10-K for the fiscal year ending September 30, 2015. 
Additionally, we will be referencing adjusted or non-GAAP financial measures during the call. We've provided reconciliations of these non-GAAP measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measures in the appendix of this slide presentation. The slide presentation is available on our website. 
So with that said, I'll turn the call over to you, Steve.

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Matt. Good morning. Thanks for joining our call. For those of you who have not yet met Matt, Matt joined WestRock in May. He has 10 years of Investor Relations experience. I'm very happy Matt's decided to join our team here at WestRock. I want
componenttext:
Thanks, Matt. Good morning. Thanks for joining our call. 
For those of you who have not yet met Matt, Matt joined WestRock in May. He has 10 years of Investor Relations experience. I'm very happy Matt's decided to join our team here at WestRock. 
I want to start by taking a moment to look back on the first year of WestRock. It's been an exciting year, one that has had many accomplishments. The merger has gone extremely well and now, at year-end, I'm pleased to report we've brought together a great team, created a great company with the size and scale to succeed in the marketplace and deliver attractive and increasing cash flows to investors. WestRock holds the #1 or 2 market share positions in attractive packaging markets while providing differentiated packaging solutions that help our customers win in the marketplace, and our broad portfolio of products and services is resonating well with customers. 
We're delivering on the expectations that we outlined at the outset of the merger. These expectations fall into 3 overall categories: cash flow, productivity and the use of our balanced capital allocation strategy to create long-term value. 
Beginning with cash flow. We manage our business to maximize our long-term cash flow returns and we executed well on this objective during the quarter. We generated operating cash flow of $532 million with $106 million coming from the reduction of inventory in our Corrugated and Consumer Packaging businesses. We expect that our full year fiscal 2016 adjusted free cash flow will exceed $1 billion. 
This was the upper end of our previously stated guidance. This highlights the strength of our business model, the capabilities of our team, our leadership position in the marketplace. It's worth pointing out that WestRock's stock continues to provide an attractive free cash flow yield of nearly 10% at the current share price. 
Next, productivity. Improving productivity requires us to mobilize our organization, getting literally hundreds of products defined and completed. WestRock's teams are getting a lot done to improve productivity. This is demonstrated by the $105 million of productivity benefits realized in our quarterly earnings and our annual, current annual run rate of synergies and performance improvements of $425 million. 
Our balanced capital allocation strategy includes paying an attractive dividend, reinvesting in our businesses, pursuing acquisitions that improve our business and repurchasing WestRock shares, all while keeping leverage within our targeted range of 2.25 to 2.5x EBITDA. 
Over the past year, in addition to the $1 billion we returned to stockholders, we invested $1.4 billion back into our business through more than $800 million in capital expenditures and approximately $600 million in acquisitions, including our joint venture with Grupo Gondi. 
This quarter, we successfully completed the separation of Ingevity. I'm pleased to see the stock perform well. WestRock shareholders who have held on to their Ingevity stock have over $6 per WestRock equivalent share of additional value. All told, we're executing well on our strategy and this is reflected in our results for the quarter. 
During the quarter, we performed well across our businesses. Sales for the June quarter were $3.6 billion and adjusted earnings per share were $0.71. Adjusted EBITDA for the quarter was $611 million or 17.3% of sales, driven by strong capture of our synergy and performance improvement opportunities. Adjusted EBITDA margins improved by 190 basis points in the Consumer Packaging segment versus the prior year. 
And we generated adjusted free cash flow of $373 million in the quarter. This brings our fiscal year-to-date free cash flow to slightly more than $800 million. 
And then how about this, over the last 12 months, we achieved more than $350 million in productivity benefits that positively impacted our income statement and cash flow. Our leverage ratio at quarter end was 2.33x. This is within our targeted range. We repurchased 1.2 million shares in the quarter, bringing the total to 12.5 million shares, almost 5% the outstanding shares over the past 12 months. 
Our Corrugated Packaging team executed very well in the quarter, with North American adjusted EBITDA margins of 18.3%. This is an increase of 80 basis points sequentially. 
Our North American box shipments declined by 2% on a per day basis from the very strong prior year quarter. Our fiscal year-to-date box shipments have increased over the last year. And in July, our box volumes have increased 1.7% on a per day basis over last year. 
Our backlogs are higher than last year, and I'm very encouraged by our new business pipeline that's up significantly over last year and as a leading indicator of volume growth. 
Our box prices declined $16 per ton from the prior year period as a result of the previously published Pulp & Paper Week containerboard price declines. Sequentially, third quarter box pricing declined by only $6 per ton. 
Shipments of domestic containerboard were about the same as last year, they are up slightly sequentially. Prices of domestic containerboard were flat sequentially. 
Current North American containerboard markets are healthy, with industry operating rates 95.6%. Industry daily box shipments increased by 1.5% in June over the prior year. Containerboard consumption increased 2.4% in June and industry inventory levels declined and are now down to 4 weeks of supply. 
Shipments of export containerboard decreased slightly from the prior year and increased slightly sequentially. Our mix of export business was unchanged with approximately 60% to Latin America and the rest split between Europe, the Middle East and Asia.  Export pricing declined only $2 per ton sequentially. 
The negative price mix across our box, domestic independent and export customers had a pretax impact of $41 million in the quarter as compared to last year. This unfavorable impact was directly offset by ongoing productivity improvement efforts. 
Sequential changes in pricing and mix reduced income by less than $15 million, which reflect very favorably on our disciplined approach to the market. 
We balanced our supply with our market demand by taking 72,000 tons of economic downtime in the quarter. 
In addition, we took 60,000 tons of maintenance downtime. 
The joint venture with Grupo Gondi, the premier operator in Mexico, is now complete. As a reminder, we hold 25% ownership interest in the partnership. Their exceptional team and exceptional assets provide us with a growth platform in a very attractive market. 
In the quarter, we shipped 67,000 tons of containerboard to the joint venture. We anticipate our shipments into Mexico will increase going forward, both from additional integration opportunities as well as from strong growth opportunities. 
We're reporting Gondi's result in the equity investment line on the income statement. For the 3 months from the June quarter, Gondi's sales were $188 million and EBITDA margins exceeded 20%. I would encourage you, for the purpose of valuation, to include our share of their EBITDA at an appropriate multiple. Based on our independent purchase price valuation as of the time of formation of the joint venture, this was an excess of $1 per share for WestRock's interest. 
Gondi's management is led by Eduardo Posada, and they've moved quickly to deploy additional capital available to them as a result of the joint venture. This includes the announcement of the acquisition of print folding carton business and the order of 11 new production lines from Boxton VHS that will used to upgrade existing Gondi plants and capitalize new plants. 
In Brazil, our performance remained strong despite the continued challenges the country faces. With EBITDA margins of almost 23%, our combined corrugated box and containerboard shipments increased by 5% compared to the prior year. 
Our year-to-date box volumes are tracking in the industry, down 2.3%, and we're implementing price increases to mitigate input cost inflation. 
The Trs Barras mill is running well, and we are capitalizing on strong mill performance and weak local currency to profitably export linerboard to offset the impact of the soft domestic box market. 
As we indicated on our last call, we expected inflation in natural gas recycled fiber prices during the third quarter to begin to have an impact. This played out as we anticipated, as seen in recycled cardboard prices, which were higher by $7 per ton. 
An increase in natural gas prices started to impact us this fourth quarter. The prices are still down as compared to last year. The average NYMEX natural gas price for the third quarter was $1.95, lower than the current strip of $2.82 for the second half of the calendar year. 
Overall, the Corrugated Packaging team navigated the market extremely well, offsetting price with productivity improvements and aggressively executing our commercial strategy. 
I'll now turn to our consumer packaging business. We drove meaningful adjusted EBITDA margin expansion of 190 basis points from the prior year period. This was on solid productivity and integration synergies. 
Consumer Packaging net sales for the quarter were $1.64 billion and adjusted EBITDA was $275 million. 
We're in process of integrating 250,000 tons per year in SBS volumes from both internalized consumption in the Carolina business. 
Pricing was stable in our core markets in the quarter as the published price reductions covering SBS, CRB and URB in Pulp & Paper Week had limited impact on our results at this point given our differentiated strategy portfolio and mix. 
We delivered $59 million in productivity improvements year-over-year, reflecting the great progress we're making in integrating our Consumer Packaging businesses and realizing the synergies and performance improvements across our expanded platform. 
Demand has been stable in our folding carton and beverage packaging grades as well as in our merchandising displays, home, health and beauty groups. 
In our consumer mills, industry backlogs improved during the second half of the quarter, particularly in SBS where we're now above prior year levels. We're entering the quarter with backlog of 5% -- of 5 weeks. 
Of note, we're continuing to see solid demand growth in hot and cold drink cups. In SBS, we're seeing limited penetration at this point from European and Asian competitors. CRB is the softest grade due to continuing pressures in the packaged food categories such as cereals, crackers and snacks. Our backlogs for CRB and CNK range from 2 to 3 weeks. 
Beverage had a strong quarter, posting improvements and profitability versus prior year due to productivity. We continue to achieve gains in global beer and sparkling water markets, which offset the continued weakness in traditional carbonated soft drink demand, primarily in North America. 
We continue to grow with customers to have packaging needs that correspond well with our strategy and capabilities, including craft brewers, new product introductions and paperboard multipacks in Latin America and China. 
Our folding carton team performed very well in the quarter and is executing on our differentiated strategy. Organic sales growth was up slightly as compared to a slight decline for the overall folding carton industry. 
Integration of the Cenveo facilities into our folding carton business has been successful. As part of the integration, we announced the closure of a former Cenveo facility in Jacksonville, Florida. This closure, as well as internalization of mill tons, is driving $12 million of current run rate synergies. We're projecting $17 million of total synergies associated with the Cenveo transaction, So it's $10 million more than originally projected. Using the acquisition price of $98 million, we paid 3x EBITDA after synergies. This is a terrific transaction for WestRock. 
Home, health and beauty results significantly exceeded the prior year, driven by strong sales execution on growth and mix improvement initiatives, cost containment and operating productivity. Adjusted EBITDA margins for the quarter were at a record for the business and were several hundred basis points higher than prior year. 
Revenue was 4% higher than prior year due to growth in North America, Europe and Brazil. 
In merchandising displays, customer promotional activity has stabilized and we're seeing year-over-year growth with many of our customers. Our cost actions had a positive impact on results. We're  seeing sequential adjusted EBITDA improvement the last 2 quarters. 
As part of our long-term strategy to balance capacity and investment with market demand, we announced the closure of our Chicago manufacturing facility in April. We anticipate the cost savings of that closure to have a positive impact in fiscal year '17. 
Now I'll turn the call over to Ward, who will talk about the progress we're making with our Land and Development business, our synergy capture and other financial topics. Ward?

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Steve. We made significant progress this quarter and completed a detailed review of projects and strategy within our Land and Development portfolio. Segment sales for the period were $42 million, and segment income was $10 million. We acceler
componenttext:
Thank you, Steve. We made significant progress this quarter and completed a detailed review of projects and strategy within our Land and Development portfolio. 
Segment sales for the period were $42 million, and segment income was $10 million. We accelerated the sale of the Walworth property and the $27 million in proceeds was more than expected. 
We have been engaged since January with our Charleston-based team and an outside real estate adviser on a project-by-project review to determine the best path forward to maximize value, accelerate cash flows, reduce development cost and risk. 
We now expect to complete the accelerated monetization of the portfolio within the next 24 to 30 months and realized gross sales proceeds of approximately $600 million. After distributing our partner's ownership interest and paying off project-specific debt, we expect to realize after-tax cash flows of approximately $275 million to $300 million, in line with original purchase price estimates. 
More than half of this cash flow should be realized by the end of fiscal 2017. The original book value in the merger accounting was approximately $400 million on a pretax basis. 
As Steve indicated, we continue to execute very well on our synergy and performance improvement objectives. We exited the June quarter at an annual run rate of $425 million. We have generated benefits from the optimization of our consumer mill system, including the internalization of the Carolina tons and the outside bleached board purchases for our folding carton operations. 
In addition, we are realizing savings from our footprint actions in both business segments. We continue to make capital investments that reduce costs such as our EVOL deployment and press upgrades in our converting operations. 
WestRock's size and scale has led to sourcing benefits across our raw material purchases. We expect to achieve a $500 million run rate by the end of the fiscal year, which is the upper end of our previous range, and we remain on track to achieve our $1 billion goal by the end of fiscal 2018. 
Adjusted segment EBITDA declined by $23 million. We had a $20 million unfavorable volume decline primarily within Consumer Packaging. The $39 million unfavorable impact of price and mix was due primarily to our Corrugated business. However, we benefited from commodity deflation as lower natural gas and wood prices more than offset increased recycled fiber cost. Labor cost inflation more than offset these lower energy and material costs. 
We remain committed to our ongoing productivity initiatives and expect them to continue to contribute meaningfully going forward. The small FX impact of only $4 million reflects our primarily U.S. dollar revenue base. 
And finally, pension income was lower by $18 million, a noncash impact reflecting our successful pension derisking plan. 
I'm pleased with the strong cash flow we've generated through the third quarter, which gives us confidence to say we will exceed our $1 billion adjusted free cash flow target for the fiscal 2016. 
We are a company that generates strong cash flow and believe that this metric is important when valuing WestRock. 
Some of the key business drivers for the fourth quarter are as follows: first, we anticipate inflation of input cost, including natural gas and recycled fiber, and we are planning major maintenance outages with our Consumer Packaging mill system that will have an approximately $11 million pretax income. 
Additionally, we recognized a $10 million pretax benefit during Q3 from our Walworth land sale, which sold for more than its stepped up value. We do not expect to repeat these gains in the fourth quarter and expect a sequential $10 million decline in Land and Development earnings. However, while these items will result in a sequential decline in adjusted earnings per share, we continue to work aggressively to capture commercial opportunities, while controlling costs. We have protected our significant overfunded status in our U.S. pension plans and that has paid off. We matched our investment strategy with our pension liability so the decline in interest rates has no impact on our overfunded status as our assets and liabilities move in tandem. We were overfunded by 107% against our GAAP liability, which translated to a $450 million overfunding as of July 15.  We do not expect to make any contributions to our U.S. qualified pension plan. 
Steve, I'll hand it back over to you for closing comments.

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ward. I'll flip back at the first year of WestRock. We've allocated $2.4 billion of capital. We've invested $841 million in capital expenditures. We expect to invest $800 million to $825 million during this fiscal year. This includes the Ingevity'
componenttext:
Thanks, Ward. I'll flip back at the first year of WestRock. We've allocated $2.4 billion of capital. We've invested $841 million in capital expenditures. We expect to invest $800 million to $825 million during this fiscal year. This includes the Ingevity's funding prior to the separation. 
While we completed our capital expenditure plans for fiscal 2017, we expect capital expenditures for the year to be in the range of $725 million to $750 million. We estimate our annual maintenance capital needs to be approximately $400 million to $450 million. 
We see numerous attractive return-generating opportunities providing between 15% and 25% unlevered after-tax returns on these investments. 
So over the past year, we've returned $1 billion or more than 40% to 2.4 billion stockholders in the form of dividends and stock repurchases. This return of capital to stockholders will continue to be an important part of our capital allocation strategy. 
We continue to see acquisitions as an important growth driver for WestRock. We have a proven core competency in making good acquisitions and driving fantastic results from them. 
This is an exciting time for WestRock. I want to thank all of our WestRock coworkers that have worked to achieve all that we could accomplish in the first year. 
If you look back, our accomplishments in the first year are significant. We've successfully integrated the companies, both culturally and operationally. We delivered more than $350 million in productivity benefits. We separated Ingevity, completed 2 acquisitions and formed our partnership with Gondi. That's just a partial list because, most importantly, we're building WestRock for the future. We're investing in developing key commercial and operational capabilities that will support our teams as we build upon our accomplishments. 
WestRock provides value-added innovative paper and packaging solutions that help our customers win in the marketplace. And we deliver attractive and increasing cash flows for our shareholders over the long term. 
That concludes our prepared remarks. We're now ready for questions.

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016

componenttext: My first question, can you talk a bit about your ability to replicate the productivity performance in Consumer in upcoming quarters? Your performance was better than our expectations, the model. Comparative factors may weigh against it or accelerate it, obviously, of the maintenance program -- or the maintenance outage of $11 million this coming quarter?

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: George, this is Ward. As I think of the synergies and performance improvements that we've had in consumer, you have a lot of the benefits related to the merger occurred in the segment we've done that very quickly. We have add the internalization of the Ca
componenttext: George, this is Ward. As I think of the synergies and performance improvements that we've had in consumer, you have a lot of the benefits related to the merger occurred in the segment we've done that very quickly. We have add the internalization of the Carolina tons, the internalization of our external folding carton tons, and we've done that on the front-end of the merger. So we will continue to have those benefits. We will continue to have the sourcing benefits that we are seeing across both segments flow through. We will start to achieve some of the synergies that -- and realized them related to the Cenveo acquisition and the internalization. We do have the headwind in the fourth quarter related to the downtime that we will taking across the consumer mill system. So we're making -- some of the synergies recorded to date were front-end loaded related to the internalization, but we're continuing to generate gains across both our converting operations and the mill system.

componenttext: Okay. So to conclude on that, until you lap this net -- this last 12 months, we can continue more or less at this pace, obviously, adjusted for whatever volume is going to bring you and also the quarter-to-quarter maintenance effects, would that be fair?
