headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jim?
componenttext: Jim?

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: George, we have just an incredible runway of opportunities in our Corrugated mill system to drive value. We got a big system and you've seen us make changes to our portfolio with the closure of 3 of our assets and the acquisition of Dublin, which has been
componenttext: George, we have just an incredible runway of opportunities in our Corrugated mill system to drive value. We got a big system and you've seen us make changes to our portfolio with the closure of 3 of our assets and the acquisition of Dublin, which has been a reset in our capability to move products around through our system and has improved our free cash flow within the portfolio. We also have substantial capital investments that are producing fruits. We have a supply chain system that is going through substantial improvement and modification. You've seen that evidenced by the dramatic drop in inventories that we posted this last quarter. So there's a nice runway of projects and our team, I think, is highly aligned and driven to create productivity.

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jim, do you think you can move down 1 quartile?
componenttext: Jim, do you think you can move down 1 quartile?

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's being a little specific, George. We have -- each mill has its own runway of opportunities, and we still have some movement between our assets. But certainly, that concept is what drives us.
componenttext: That's being a little specific, George. We have -- each mill has its own runway of opportunities, and we still have some movement between our assets. But certainly, that concept is what drives us.

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Mark Weintraub of Buckingham.
componenttext: Our next question is from Mark Weintraub of Buckingham.

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was hoping, if possible, to get a bit more color on the comment that you're very encouraged by the business pipeline and noting that that's a good indicator. I mean, one thing that -- a very good quarter, obviously. One thing, year-over-year volume was
componenttext: I was hoping, if possible, to get a bit more color on the comment that you're very encouraged by the business pipeline and noting that that's a good indicator. I mean, one thing that -- a very good quarter, obviously. One thing, year-over-year volume was still a negative for you, in what's been, not a great, but an okay environment. How close are we, do you think, to where that volume variable can start being a positive for you?

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark, I think on the pipeline, we have a very, I think, a structured approach to be able to go to market in container. So we measure backlogs, we measure pipelines and they have proven to be very reliable indicators of changes in volume over time. And lik
componenttext: Mark, I think on the pipeline, we have a very, I think, a structured approach to be able to go to market in container. So we measure backlogs, we measure pipelines and they have proven to be very reliable indicators of changes in volume over time. And like I reported, I was very encouraged by the business pipeline. That's because we aggregate the potential we have across our system and prioritize it. And I feel very good about our ability to grow volume from this front and have showed in the July results.

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you're hoping that basically volumes can start being a positive, assuming no macro -- negative macro developments?
componenttext: So you're hoping that basically volumes can start being a positive, assuming no macro -- negative macro developments?

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Exactly. And it was a positive in July.
componenttext: Exactly. And it was a positive in July.

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then -- and maybe somewhat relatedly, do you -- I think you said you shipped 60,000 tons of containerboard to Gondi in the just ended quarter. And I think that they shipped 211,000 tons of converted product. How much more are they buying from th
componenttext: Okay. And then -- and maybe somewhat relatedly, do you -- I think you said you shipped 60,000 tons of containerboard to Gondi in the just ended quarter. And I think that they shipped 211,000 tons of converted product. How much more are they buying from the outside? Or is most of the balance there board that is actually made at Gondi?

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jim?
componenttext: Jim?

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Gondi, we think, is just an extraordinary opportunity for us. Their assets in that marketplace is one that has substantial growth opportunity and partnering with them gives us an incredible pipeline to further integrate with them. They have approximate
componenttext: So Gondi, we think, is just an extraordinary opportunity for us. Their assets in that marketplace is one that has substantial growth opportunity and partnering with them gives us an incredible pipeline to further integrate with them. They have approximately 500,000 tons worth of manufacturing capability in the fiber base packaging grades in Mexico, and the balance is procured from others. Now there is local board that is procured, but a big benefit to Gondi is being able to tap into our very high-quality virgin substrate that gives them further capabilities to penetrate in the market they serve. So net-net-net, we see a big opportunity to both improve their capabilities as well as our vertical integration.

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So fair to say a little bit more on the integration from where it is, but then you grow with them. Is that sort of the way to think about it?
componenttext: So fair to say a little bit more on the integration from where it is, but then you grow with them. Is that sort of the way to think about it?

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark, that's exactly the way I think about it. We can get you the exact number offline.
componenttext: Mark, that's exactly the way I think about it. We can get you the exact number offline.

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Philip Ng of Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Philip Ng of Jefferies.

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, backlogs in CNK and CRB was a little weaker than I would have expected. You are taking low maintenance in fourth quarter, but are you planning to take a little economic downtime as well? And I just want to get some clarity on how order patterns a
componenttext: I guess, backlogs in CNK and CRB was a little weaker than I would have expected. You are taking low maintenance in fourth quarter, but are you planning to take a little economic downtime as well? And I just want to get some clarity on how order patterns are shaking out in that segment in July and August. Because I've heard that from the CPG guys had ratcheted back inventory late in the year.

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So your question centers on CNK and ...
componenttext: So your question centers on CNK and ...

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: CRB.
componenttext: CRB.

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And CRB?
componenttext: And CRB?

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Both of those segments that -- we'll say the demand is solid. However, backlogs have retreated somewhat. And the beverage business, as we all know, is seasonally strengthening somewhat below prior years, but it's still a solid market for us. Clearly, the
componenttext: Both of those segments that -- we'll say the demand is solid. However, backlogs have retreated somewhat. And the beverage business, as we all know, is seasonally strengthening somewhat below prior years, but it's still a solid market for us. Clearly, the craft brews is a growth segment. And so we will, yes, match our supply with demand and that's the landscape in the CNK area. CRB backlogs in the 2- to 3-week range and certainly, its competitive in the food board segments of the market. But we like our portfolio. We have a very strong customer base, and I think we will succeed in those markets.

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I guess, a question for Ward. I'm not sure if you're prepared to give too much color on '17, but with input costs rising a bit, some slippage on pricing, offset by synergies and, I guess, CapEx is looking a little lighter than we baked in. Is th
componenttext: Okay. And I guess, a question for Ward. I'm not sure if you're prepared to give too much color on '17, but with input costs rising a bit, some slippage on pricing, offset by synergies and, I guess, CapEx is looking a little lighter than we baked in. Is that $950 million, $2 billion type free cash flow threshold kind of sustainable when we think about 2017?

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're in the early stages of doing our fiscal year 2017 plan. We're not prepared to give guidance for 2017. We did give what our ongoing CapEx would be as we move forward into 2017. We feel really good about the runway that we have related to the performa
componenttext: We're in the early stages of doing our fiscal year 2017 plan. We're not prepared to give guidance for 2017. We did give what our ongoing CapEx would be as we move forward into 2017. We feel really good about the runway that we have related to the performance improvements in synergy targets. We will have inflationary pressures just like the rest of our peers in this segment. We will -- as we put the plan together though, we also have to assess what we think the opportunities are going to be from a volume and price point of view. So we're not prepared to give a 2017 cash flow guidance, but we are piercing through the high end of our range for 2016.

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then just last one for me. Now that you guys have spun off Ingevity, should we expect buybacks to tick up? And just want to get your thoughts on what you're seeing on the M&A pipeline side. I mean, there's obviously been a few bo
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then just last one for me. Now that you guys have spun off Ingevity, should we expect buybacks to tick up? And just want to get your thoughts on what you're seeing on the M&A pipeline side. I mean, there's obviously been a few box transactions in the marketplace for integration probably wouldn't be a bad thing for you guys. Just wanted some thoughts in terms of capital deployment the next year or 2.

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Philip, we're going to continue to implement our balanced capital allocation strategy. As far as stock buybacks, we bought back about $50 million this quarter, that's a $200 million run rate, which is in line with where our cash flow generation is. As far
componenttext: Philip, we're going to continue to implement our balanced capital allocation strategy. As far as stock buybacks, we bought back about $50 million this quarter, that's a $200 million run rate, which is in line with where our cash flow generation is. As far as the acquisition, we continue to look at acquisitions and I think you should expect us to continue to look at acquisitions and take advantage of the opportunities that we see to improve our business. It's part of our strategy.

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Chip Dillon of Vertical Research.
componenttext: Our next question is from Chip Dillon of Vertical Research.

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question is on the landfill situation. I know that when Plum Creek did the deal with MeadWestvaco about 3 years ago, the all-in value of their land they imply were around, I think, $530 million. And it looks like if I had to separate, you're expecti
componenttext: First question is on the landfill situation. I know that when Plum Creek did the deal with MeadWestvaco about 3 years ago, the all-in value of their land they imply were around, I think, $530 million. And it looks like if I had to separate, you're expecting $600 million more on the top of the $75 million I think you just got, if I got that right. And so does that -- is that sort of a fair representation of kind of how much that land value has gone up over those 3 years? So the all-in value might be closer to $700 million. Or am I not -- am I -- are there still more lands in addition to the 68,000 acres?

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: That is a tough question for me to look back that far. What I can tell you is I -- we looked back and presented to the board last week a look back of the total proceeds of the Land and Development operation. And I found an investor presentation that was d
componenttext: That is a tough question for me to look back that far. What I can tell you is I -- we looked back and presented to the board last week a look back of the total proceeds of the Land and Development operation. And I found an investor presentation that was done by MeadWestvaco team in 2011 and they projected what the gross proceeds are going to be across all of their holdings. And we looked at the sales to date from 2011 to now and what we think we're going to realize, we're actually on the higher end of the range that they projected back in 2011. So we feel good about the progress. We feel very good about the accelerated monetization strategy that we have. And we have confidence that we're going to be able to generate the $600 million in gross proceeds from the $275 million to $300 million of after-tax cash flows to WestRock.

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And as you -- let's say that to you continue to get a little bit better than the stepped up basis. That -- I would assume that as each quarter, as you sell land and you get some above your basis, you would just continue to report that as sort of ong
componenttext: Okay. And as you -- let's say that to you continue to get a little bit better than the stepped up basis. That -- I would assume that as each quarter, as you sell land and you get some above your basis, you would just continue to report that as sort of ongoing earnings just so there could be a little bit of lumpiness like we saw this quarter. Is that something we should expect? And nothing major, but I would imagine it could be -- could it be a $10 million or $15 million 1 quarter, 0 the next?

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Exactly. Because, remember, we valued each project within the portfolio and we feel very confident about the aggregate that we will exceed the purchase price, original purchase price that was done and the merger accounting, but we could have some ups and
componenttext: Exactly. Because, remember, we valued each project within the portfolio and we feel very confident about the aggregate that we will exceed the purchase price, original purchase price that was done and the merger accounting, but we could have some ups and downs on the individual projects. And that will cause some earnings contribution and volatility from quarter-to-quarter.

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just last question, just on the Containerboard business. Are you happy now in the sense of where your inventories are now down to? Do you feel like there's more reduction required? And then, I guess, flipping it around, how do you think abo
componenttext: Okay. And then just last question, just on the Containerboard business. Are you happy now in the sense of where your inventories are now down to? Do you feel like there's more reduction required? And then, I guess, flipping it around, how do you think about the industry now on a cost perspective? It would seem like even globally that we had seen costs basically moving down for the last 2, 3 years but now it looks like suddenly, they're up meaningfully especially outside the U.S. on the fiber side. And here, not only on the OCC side as well, but on nat gas. Does that sort of change the way you think the business dynamics look at least next year and the year after versus what we saw in the past?

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Jim. I'll take that one. So first of all, in our inventories, as we've -- I've shared on previous calls, we manage our inventories at a very granular level. And the whole purpose of our inventory is to make sure that we are able to provide our cus
componenttext: This is Jim. I'll take that one. So first of all, in our inventories, as we've -- I've shared on previous calls, we manage our inventories at a very granular level. And the whole purpose of our inventory is to make sure that we are able to provide our customers on-time delivery and using the best weight freight. Also said that coming out of our heavy outage period this past couple of quarters, we would be reducing inventories this quarter, and that's exactly what we did. Frankly, from the February peak, we were down 191,000 tons and quarter-over-quarter, 152,000. So that's a substantial drop in inventories as we said we would. Where we are currently? I think we like our position. The logistics network and our supply chain capabilities have improved dramatically. Railcar availability, truck freight availability, I think, leads us to the point where we're pretty pleased with where we are currently. There will always be some pluses and minuses and maybe over time, a small incremental further reduction. So I hope that gives you color on that front. Relative to cost, there's no question that we're facing some headwinds on natural gas and fiber and you have normal inflation. However, we also have a nice pipeline of productivity. So we think overall our cost structure in our North American containerboard mill system is one that we have opportunities to further improve. The competitiveness globally, which I think you were implying, is all currency related and certainly, we can't control that. So I hope that's germane to your question, Chip.

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from the line of Mark Wilde of Bank of Montral.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from the line of Mark Wilde of Bank of Montral.

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions. The first one, Steve, you talked about the interest in kind of more acquisitions going forward. I wondered if you could just help give us kind of thoughts about where we might see that take place. I know there are always questions a
componenttext: A couple of questions. The first one, Steve, you talked about the interest in kind of more acquisitions going forward. I wondered if you could just help give us kind of thoughts about where we might see that take place. I know there are always questions about just from a regulatory standpoint how much bigger you could get in the boxboard business and maybe in the containerboard business in North America versus, say, doing more things in Latin America or maybe over in Europe or elsewhere.

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I think we start looking at acquisitions as we want to do those that improve our business. I think we do see opportunities in our North American Corrugated and Consumer Packaging businesses. I think Cenveo was a relatively small transaction. SP Fibe
componenttext: Sure. I think we start looking at acquisitions as we want to do those that improve our business. I think we do see opportunities in our North American Corrugated and Consumer Packaging businesses. I think Cenveo was a relatively small transaction. SP Fiber would fit into that. I know you're very familiar with Gondi, Mark. I think Latin America fits very well with our company. We have a great business in Brazil. There's -- we'd like to invest more in that. We export 60% of our containerboard to Latin America, so that's a very natural place for us to grow. So I think that would remain, I think, outside the U.S., the primary focus. We do have strong operations in Europe and Asia, and I think those we would look at as well. But the opportunity has to fit our business and has to make our business better.

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. All right. The follow-on question I had, Steve, was just back in the SBS market. You mentioned specifically that you weren't seeing a lot of pressure from Asian and European SBS. I'd assume that, that was coming into the U.S. And I just wondered if
componenttext: Okay. All right. The follow-on question I had, Steve, was just back in the SBS market. You mentioned specifically that you weren't seeing a lot of pressure from Asian and European SBS. I'd assume that, that was coming into the U.S. And I just wondered if you could talk about your export business because when I look at the trade data so far this year, all the SBS grades are down pretty sharply.

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'm going to let Jim respond to that, Mark.
componenttext: Yes, I'm going to let Jim respond to that, Mark.

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: As you know, our portfolio of paperboard grades is very focused on the premium end of the marketplace where we're serving the most demanding market segments in tobacco and commercial print, liquid packaging and specialty poly-coated applications. And so i
componenttext: As you know, our portfolio of paperboard grades is very focused on the premium end of the marketplace where we're serving the most demanding market segments in tobacco and commercial print, liquid packaging and specialty poly-coated applications. And so in North America, we compete very well, and that's the reason Steve remarks -- has remarked that we've seen negligible penetration into our markets competing against our premium grades. In the international markets, we use those products in exactly the same way, and we have excellent customers in literally all the regions in the world that value our premium substrates. And we've seen very consistent demand for those products and would see so going forward.

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just, Mark, I'd add one. I've gone to Europe and Asia and talked to our sales force. They are incredibly talented at taking the needs of the customer and translating it into the specific quality of paper that they need. It is just -- it's remarkable t
componenttext: And just, Mark, I'd add one. I've gone to Europe and Asia and talked to our sales force. They are incredibly talented at taking the needs of the customer and translating it into the specific quality of paper that they need. It is just -- it's remarkable to me to see what they do. And when you look at the overall volumes that we export, it ends up being a -- I think more of a -- it's a differentiated business but it's more of a niche business because we're taking our technology and talent and just serving the precise needs of our customers. So it's on point to our strategy.

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Mark Connelly of CLSA.
componenttext: Our next question is from Mark Connelly of CLSA.

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Scott Liebman in for Mark. Just a quick question for you. Is WestRock still being as selective in mill reinvestment that it makes on the containerboard side similar to Rock-Tenn and how they were. And I'm curious as whether your selective reinvest
componenttext: This is Scott Liebman in for Mark. Just a quick question for you. Is WestRock still being as selective in mill reinvestment that it makes on the containerboard side similar to Rock-Tenn and how they were. And I'm curious as whether your selective reinvestment to strengthen some of the mills but not others has achieved what you wanted thus far. And would you say you're closer to a steady state? Are you -- whether -- or whether you're still selectively reinvesting with a view to further rationalize the number of mills as one of your big competitors has done pretty successfully in recent years?

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have a very rigorous capital investment process within both our mill and our packaging operations. And I don't think it's changed. You referenced Rock-Tenn to the present. I don't think there's been any systemic change. We deploy capital to ensure the
componenttext: We have a very rigorous capital investment process within both our mill and our packaging operations. And I don't think it's changed. You referenced Rock-Tenn to the present. I don't think there's been any systemic change. We deploy capital to ensure the safety and environmental strength of each of our assets and then we deploy capital to maintain our assets in a highly efficient way. And most of all, we try to tap into the creative opportunities to make our businesses better, and it's a very rigorous process that we would see continuing.

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Helpful, okay. And then just one follow-on. When you did the SP Fiber deal, you said you expected significant synergies and for the deal to be accretive in the second half of this year. And you've obviously changed the footprint there since the transactio
componenttext: Helpful, okay. And then just one follow-on. When you did the SP Fiber deal, you said you expected significant synergies and for the deal to be accretive in the second half of this year. And you've obviously changed the footprint there since the transaction was made. Was that part of the original plan? And do you still think that SP will be accretive in the second half? And just overall in that transaction, are you getting the benefits that you expected?

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We are getting the benefits we expected. Newberg was not a significant contributor to the overall economics of the transaction so Dublin is the asset that fits very well into our system. We did come up with a -- for Dublin, if you look at the -- say the p
componenttext: We are getting the benefits we expected. Newberg was not a significant contributor to the overall economics of the transaction so Dublin is the asset that fits very well into our system. We did come up with a -- for Dublin, if you look at the -- say the productivity improvements that we expected over the first 3 years, our goal at the time we announced the transaction was $41 million. We're now, after less than 1 year, we're at $40 million. So we're not quite at what we achieved, but we're kind of we're effectively there. Then we have line of sight to $46 million and more. We took our board there last week and the mill looked great. I think the people look better. The production is on track. It's a good fit in our system. We're selling a new product for us, in recycled kraft bag and that's worked very well. Our productivity programs are in place and the mill continues to fit very well in our system. So this is -- right now, it's worked out, I think, better than we anticipated at the time we announced the transaction.

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Anthony Pettinari of Citi.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Anthony Pettinari of Citi.

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could talk a little bit about market conditions in Brazil. Your box shipments declined in the quarter for you and the industry. Are you seeing any stabilization or maybe improvement there in terms of local demand? Or do you expect i
componenttext: I was wondering if you could talk a little bit about market conditions in Brazil. Your box shipments declined in the quarter for you and the industry. Are you seeing any stabilization or maybe improvement there in terms of local demand? Or do you expect it in the second half? And then to the extent that you can, can you talk a bit about the price increase that was announced there?

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Brazil is, first of all, an incredible asset for us. The forest land, the Trs Barras mill, that's really state-of-the-art and our integrated packaging portfolio is a great business for us and is performing extremely well. We're all well aware of the pol
componenttext: Brazil is, first of all, an incredible asset for us. The forest land, the Trs Barras mill, that's really state-of-the-art and our integrated packaging portfolio is a great business for us and is performing extremely well. We're all well aware of the political and economic challenges in Brazil and I don't know that I could necessarily predict the trend line going forward on that whole thing. But I would say, it will improve over time, I'm not just not sure the pace of that. Relative to our ability to compete, I think we have superior assets and the quality and capability of both our containerboard and the products coming out of our converting system are winning in the marketplace. And so as the economy improves, we're going to win. Now the beauty is we also have a very low-cost mill that's able to toggle between domestic consumption and export, so you've seen our export shipments increase over time. So net-net, I love our position in Brazil.

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just kind of following up on that. I mean, it seems like there's a lot of local producers there who might be much higher cost. CC prices have come up pretty sharply there. When you think about [indiscernible] market position within Brazil o
componenttext: Okay. And then just kind of following up on that. I mean, it seems like there's a lot of local producers there who might be much higher cost. CC prices have come up pretty sharply there. When you think about [indiscernible] market position within Brazil over this very deep recession, have you been gaining share? Have there been smaller local guys who have dropped out? Any kind of color you can give on the market dynamics there maybe over the last year to 1.5 years?

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't know that I can speak to our competitors falling out. I just know I love our position. I think we have premium -- a premium virgin product coming out of the state-of-the-art mill that's vertically integrated with a great packaging system and a for
componenttext: I don't know that I can speak to our competitors falling out. I just know I love our position. I think we have premium -- a premium virgin product coming out of the state-of-the-art mill that's vertically integrated with a great packaging system and a forest resource that makes us very low cost. So I like our position.

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Scott Gaffner of Barclays.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Scott Gaffner of Barclays.

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, you -- just to go back the follow-up question on this new business pipeline. Has there been any change in the way that you approach the sales team? Are we up against easy comps over last year? Anything you could talk about the go-to-market strategy
componenttext: Steve, you -- just to go back the follow-up question on this new business pipeline. Has there been any change in the way that you approach the sales team? Are we up against easy comps over last year? Anything you could talk about the go-to-market strategy that would have any consequence on that would be great. I know the reason I asked is because you go from the minus 2% in the quarter to plus 1.7% in July that seems to be a pretty big inflection point.

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we worked into the call comments that over the past year, this fiscal year, volumes are up slightly. We do not focus on, call it, quarter-to-quarter or month-to-month changes in our volumes. I know the investment community does, so we in turn
componenttext: Yes, I think we worked into the call comments that over the past year, this fiscal year, volumes are up slightly. We do not focus on, call it, quarter-to-quarter or month-to-month changes in our volumes. I know the investment community does, so we in turn have to focus on it. But I think we're focusing on building a company that is very profitable and generates long-term cash flows. So we are very focused in container. We have just a very structured way to go to market. So if you come to work at WestRock, you're going through certain training, and you go to market in a very consistent way. And then we're in the process of, I'd say, rolling that out broader, more fully across WestRock, and we're in a position to do that. And I just came across something that Gallup, they have an email that they send out periodically that covers just all sorts of different topics. They sent one out yesterday and their conclusion was, they find most companies can double their revenue by simply selling more to the existing customer base. And I just repeat that because that's really on point to what we're doing. So most of our customers will buy folding carton; will buy boxes, and we're taking sales force and we're going to market to identify those customers we can go to and add value to. And so I think that's a long-winded answer to your question, but I'm very pleased with what we're doing, and we're building that capability over the long term. And our volumes will go up or down from quarter-to-quarter, but I think if you look at the overall portfolio of business we're generating, it's a very attractive portfolio of business. And I think I'm going to go on because we're supplementing that with capital. And so just for -- in container, I think we've been very clear about the investment we're doing with respect to the EVOLs. And as far as our capital budget process we talked about earlier, we go back and look at all of our capital as to whether it does what we thought it was going to do. At least in container, as far as this process, we reviewed $80 million in capital projects in our box business and a lot of them were EVOLs but there were other projects as well. That actual cost was within 1% of what we thought it was going to be. The actual returns, we estimated at 15% after tax. The actuals were 20%. So they were well in excess of what we thought when we made the investment. So we have, I'll just say, a full-court press across our business to go to market in a way which is very appropriate for us and then back that up with the investment in capital and talent to make the business. I think we'll create a lot of value over the long term by doing that.

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ward, 2 questions for me. The first is a multipart question, if you don't mind, on free cash flow. So can you talk about what the source of the fiscal '16 free cash flow increase was? Was it working capital, CapEx, EBITDA or otherwise? And then -- can you
componenttext: Ward, 2 questions for me. The first is a multipart question, if you don't mind, on free cash flow. So can you talk about what the source of the fiscal '16 free cash flow increase was? Was it working capital, CapEx, EBITDA or otherwise? And then -- can you clarify what, Ward, what you're expecting working capital to contribute to free cash this year? And lastly, with respect to free cash, I think your initial fiscal '16 free cash guidance was $850 million, which included chemicals. Now, you're saying for next year, it will be $725 million to $750 million, obviously, excluding chemicals. Is -- how much of the difference is chemicals versus other?

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll start with the -- Adam, I'll start with the second one first. So we had capital investments from our Specialty Chemicals business of approximately $45 million during the period of time that they were part of WestRock prior to the spin. So that's your
componenttext: I'll start with the -- Adam, I'll start with the second one first. So we had capital investments from our Specialty Chemicals business of approximately $45 million during the period of time that they were part of WestRock prior to the spin. So that's your reference point and stretch point. If I go back and I look at the free cash flow guidance that we gave earlier in the year, a lot of things have changed. We've had pricing changes in the marketplace. We've had inflationary pressures. If I were to give you the reference points of what -- why we're going to generate the higher cash flow or come out on the higher end of the range, I think earnings are better. I think our working capital source that we talked about at that point in time is actually lower. The other cash items such as cash taxes, I think they're very consistent with the assumption that we laid out back in -- earlier in the year. And then CapEx is clearly on the lower end of the range that we had identified at the beginning of the year. I think we'll even come in just below the $825 million that we had described. So again, I think it's earnings. Working capital is not as big of a use as we described back then. The remaining balance sheet items are fairly consistent and then lower CapEx.

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016

componenttext: Just one on a sequential guidance. I know you called out the $10 million lower income from land. The, I think, $11 million of higher outages in consumer. You had higher input cost. You're flat to slightly down price mix. Can you give us any more sense of the magnitude of the sequential decline that you're expecting?

headline: WestRock Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016

We do have some residual price mix flow through from the PPW reductions that took place earlier in the year that does occur in Q4. But we're not giving specific EPS guidance for the fourth quarter.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Dexter. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to our Fiscal 2016 Fourth Quarter Earnings Call. My name is Matt Tractenberg, I'm WestRock's Vice President of Investor Relations. I'm joined this morning by Steve Voorhees, WestRock's Chief Executi
componenttext:
Thank you, Dexter. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to our Fiscal 2016 Fourth Quarter Earnings Call. My name is Matt Tractenberg, I'm WestRock's Vice President of Investor Relations. 
I'm joined this morning by Steve Voorhees, WestRock's Chief Executive Officer; Ward Dickson, our Chief Financial Officer; Jim Porter, President of Business Development in Latin America; Jeff Chalovich, President of Corrugated Packaging; and Bob Feeser, President of our Consumer Packaging segment. 
During the course of today's call, we will make forward-looking statements involving our plans, expectations, estimates and beliefs related to future events. These statements may involve a number of risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those we discuss during the call. We describe these risks and uncertainties in our filings with the SEC, including our 10-K for the fiscal year ending September 30, 2015. 
Additionally, we will be referencing adjusted or non-GAAP financial measures during the call. We provided reconciliations of these non-GAAP measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measures in the appendix of the slide presentation. The other -- slide presentation is available on our website. 
So with that said, I'll turn it over to you, Steve.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Matt. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining our call today. September marked the end of our first fiscal year at WestRock. We've had an exciting and productive year. We've made considerable progress in building WestRock into what we are
componenttext:
Thanks, Matt. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining our call today. 
September marked the end of our first fiscal year at WestRock. We've had an exciting and productive year. We've made considerable progress in building WestRock into what we are today. We're a $14 billion paper and packaging company. We hold waiting positions across a board set of markets. We're providing our customers with tailor-made solutions that help them win in their markets. We're executing our strategic plan in delivering excellent results. 
After only 5 quarters, we're already halfway toward our $1 billion, 3-year synergy and performance improvement target. Over the same 5 quarters, we delivered $444 million in productivity improvements. We manage our business to sustain and grow our cash flows over the long term. 
During fiscal '16, we delivered over $1 billion in adjusted free cash flow. We returned $716 million to stockholders through $381 million in dividends and $335 million in share repurchases. Today, we bought back 13.5 million shares or 5% of WestRock's outstanding shares. We improved our business by investing $588 million in 2 acquisitions and 1 joint venture. Our balance sheet is in great shape with a leverage ratio of 2.33x. 
On Friday, we announced a $0.10 per share increase to our annual dividend. The dividend increase underscores our confidence in our long-term cash flows. We have ample capacity to reinvest in our existing facilities. We have the flexibility to make acquisitions that improve our business and generate attractive returns. We will continue to purchase WestRock shares and expect to hold leverage within our targeted range of 2.25 to 2.5x. 
Sales for the quarter were $3.6 billion and adjusted EBITDA was $589 million for a margin of 16.3%. Adjusted earnings per share were $0.71. Productivity initiatives contributed $89 million to our income during the quarter. 
We transferred $2.5 billion  of pension assets and liabilities to a third party. This transaction significantly derisk our U.S. qualified pension plan. 
For the full year, sales were $14 billion and adjusted EBITDA was $2.3 billion for a margin of 16%. 
We achieved our productivity and cash flow objectives in fiscal '16 when we set the stage for very successful 2017. 
The Corrugated Packaging team delivered solid results in the quarter, including North American adjusted EBITDA margins of 18.2%. Adjusted EBITDA declined by $31 million from the prior year and was flat sequentially. 
As we said what happened on last quarter's call, the Pulp & Paper Week price reduction from earlier this year continues to flow through this quarter. This is true for both our box and domestic containerboard businesses. 
We reduced inventory by 143,000 tons from a year ago, and we reduced inventory 16,000 tons sequentially. We took 32,000 tons of maintenance downtime in the quarter. Most of this downtime was at our Stevenson mill, where we completed our capital project to convert to a new pulping process. This scheduled outage at the Stevenson mill reduced income by $10 million. 
We're communicated a $50 per ton price increase to our customers for domestic containerboard and Corrugated Packaging. Export pricing has improved in our largest markets, including Latin America, where pricing was up $8 per ton sequentially. Our system has been and continues to be tight with good demand, lower inventories and high operating margins.[ph] 
Within our box business, backlogs have strengthened, and our current pipeline in new business remains strong. Our differentiated strategy is earning us new business. 
In October, our box volumes were up 1.6% over last year on a daily basis. 
Turning to Hurricane Matthew. I'm pleased to report that our employees came through Hurricane Matthew with no injuries. We have had several employees and their families with damage to their homes and some of these employees are receiving support from the WestRock employee relief fund. The impact of Hurricane Matthew on our business has reduced production by 35,000 tons. We've reduced shipments to export markets to help meet our improving demand as well as address the lower production due to Hurricane Matthew. 
Grupo Gondi sales in the quarter were $180 million and EBITDA margins exceeded 20%. We shipped 55,000 tons of container board to the Grupo Gondi joint venture and we expect shipments to increase going forward as Gondi grows its business. 
Last week, Gondi completed the acquisition of Aluprint, a leading manufacturer of folding cartons in Mexico. This acquisition has additional capabilities for Gondi to serve customers in the growing Mexican packaging market. 
In Brazil, our team performed exceptionally well despite continued regional economic challenges. Box shipments per day were up by approximately 9% over the prior year and up 4% sequentially. EBITDA margins were 26.4%. Jim Porter is working with the team in Brazil and I expect that they will create attractive investment opportunities for WestRock over the next year. 
Jim continues to advise us on the North American Containerboard business as Jeff Chalovich has assumed the responsibility of waiting [ph] this business for WestRock. 
Jeff brings over 25 years of industry experience to WestRock. He joined Rock-Tenn in 2008 when we acquired Southern Container. He's been leading our $5 billion box business for the past 4 years. 
Over the same period, we've improved our North American Corrugated Packaging EBITDA margins from 13% to 18%. Jeff's leadership has driven much of this improvement, and we have more runway to increase margins. I'm looking forward to supporting our entire Corrugated Packaging team to deliver even better results through the execution of our differentiated strategy. 
Consumer packaging delivered improved earnings and margins in the quarter. Net sales were $1.6 billion and adjusted EBITDA was $268 million. We delivered $42 million in productivity improvements. This drove our 90 basis point increase in adjusted EBITDA margins. 
Folding carton revenue grew by 10% year-over-year, driven by the Cenveo Packaging acquisition and organic growth of 2% in our core North American business. We're making good progress on productivity initiatives across our converting businesses. 
Pricing and mix were favorable, primarily due to lower pulp volumes. This was partially offset by the flow through of previously published index reductions for SBS and CRB. Our SBS backlogs have strengthened and are currently at 5 weeks. We produced less pulp at our SBS mills in the quarter. This was a result of improved paperboard demand and planned maintenance outages at the Covington and Demopolis mills. 
We're seeing limited penetration from European and Asian board suppliers that's been targeting the U.S. market. 
Finally, sequentially, both our CRB and CNK backlogs have increased and both are approximately at 3 weeks. 
Bob Feeser leads our Consumer Packaging business. Bob's career started at Mead about 30 years ago. His known converting experience includes consumer, corrugated, domestic and international assignments. Bob has his broad set of experiences as any executive at WestRock. Bob's been instrumental in delivering more than $230 million in productivity improvements in the Consumer Packaging business. 
Our Consumer Packaging business is successful implementing our differentiated strategy. I look forward to supporting the business and their drive to improve margins. 
Home, health and beauty. Our home, health and beauty business has been performing extremely well over the past few years. Fiscal '16, our sales were $567 million. EBITDA was in excess of $100 million. Capital expenditures have been less than 5% of sales. The business has generated very strong cash flows that have grown that we expect to continue to grow over the next several years. The entire home, health and beauty organization deserves recognition for what they've accomplished since the merger and many years before the merger. 
While the business has fit well with WestRock's portfolio of packaging solutions, hopefully help here as [indiscernible] home, health and beauty are valued at higher multiples in WestRock overall. And in fact, our home, health and beauty business may fit even better with another company. 
Accordingly, our board has authorized us to evaluate strategic alternatives for the home, health and beauty business. These alternatives include the potential sale of the business during the first half of calendar 2017. In the event we sold the business for cash, we expect to use the sale proceeds consistent with our balance capital allocation strategy. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Ward.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Steve. We are making great progress on monetizing our Brand and Development portfolio. We completed the $13 million after-tax sale of a residential apartment complex during the quarter. As discussed on our previous call, we expect to realize 0.
componenttext:
Thank you, Steve. We are making great progress on monetizing our Brand and Development portfolio. We completed the $13 million after-tax sale of a residential apartment complex during the quarter. As discussed on our previous call, we expect to realize 0.5 of the $275 million to $300 million in net after-tax free cash flow during fiscal 2017. 
As Steve indicated, we continue to execute very well on our synergy and performance improvement objectives. We exited the September quarter at an annual run rate of $500 million. Fiscal 2016 productivity was driven by insourcing initiatives, procurement, actions to rationalize our footprint, return generating capital investments and merger-related synergies. We expect to achieve an $800 million run rate by the end of fiscal year 2017 and remain on track to achieve our $1 billion goal by the end of fiscal 2018. 
Fourth quarter adjusted segment EBITDA declined by $27 million, driven in part by unfavorable volume, the anticipated impact of price and mix and inflation of both input cost and labor. The impact of these 3 items was nearly offset by ongoing productivity improvements. 
On a full year basis, combined company adjusted EBITDA declined by $51 million, driven by lower volume and favorable pricing mix, wage and other input cost inflation. However, we were able to offset much of these items by delivering $384 million of productivity improvements. 
In summary, both the quarter and the full fiscal year were successful. And I'd like to thank all of our employees for making this happen. 
As we look back at the first 5 quarters of WestRock, we have allocated $2.8 billion of capital. We have invested over $1 billion in capital expenditures over the last 15 months and continue to see numerous attractive return-generating opportunities. 
We returned $1.14 billion or almost half of the total to stockholders in the form of dividends and stock repurchases. This return of cash to stockholders via dividends and share buybacks will continue to be an important part of our capital allocation strategy. 
In the first quarter, we expect sequential earnings will be lower, in line with seasonal -- with the seasonal pattern we experienced last year. I'd like to remind you that from Q4 fiscal 2015 to Q1 fiscal 2016, segment income declined by $88 million. We have outlined several of the drivers of the first quarter and full year on Slide 12. 
For Q1, we anticipate that pricing mix will be negative as the impact of the previously announced corrugated price increase will be more than offset by the flow through of the previously published consumer price decreases. 
The first quarter is typically our heaviest maintenance period, and we are planning 160,000 tons of downtime. Volumes will likely declined, driven by 4 less shipping days in our Container business. Consumer grades experienced seasonal softness in the first quarter as well. Inflation of input prices will continue in the period. And finally, Hurricane Matthew will negatively impact us by approximately $15 million to $20 million. These items should lead you to a first quarter adjusted EPS lower than what we delivered in the fourth quarter of fiscal 2016, but increasing steadily as we make our way through the year. 
For the full year fiscal 2017, we expect to deliver adjusted free cash flow of $1.2 billion, including approximately $150 million of land and development after-tax cash flow. We expect to invest approximately $750 million in CapEx. We also expect to realize significant productivity as well as meaningful inflation in some commodity categories, including natural gas, recycled fiber and certain chemicals. Both tax rates are estimated at 34% to 35%,  and cash tax rates are in the high 20s. 
Steve, I will hand it back to you for closing comments.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ward. I'm proud of the progress we've made in our first full year as WestRock. WestRock offers a comprehensive portfolio of paper and packaging products and services. This portfolio provides WestRock the opportunity to deliver winning solutions to
componenttext:
Thanks, Ward. I'm proud of the progress we've made in our first full year as WestRock. WestRock offers a comprehensive portfolio of paper and packaging products and services. This portfolio provides WestRock the opportunity to deliver winning solutions to our customers that help them win in their markets. We're doing just that. This is and will translate into great value for our customers, our employees and our stockholders. 
We exceeded our productivity and free cash flow targets in fiscal year '16, and we're looking forward to continued success in fiscal '17. Our cash flow is the foundation of our balanced capital allocation program, investing our business to capital improvements and acquisitions and returning value to stockholders in the form of dividends and share repurchases. 
And as important as anything else, we have a terrific team and strategy. We're looking forward to driving even greater value creation in the future. 
Matt, back to you.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Steve. [Operator Instructions] Dexter, please open the call for questions.
componenttext: Thanks, Steve. [Operator Instructions] Dexter, please open the call for questions.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And now our first question comes on the line of Mark Wilde of Bank of Montral.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And now our first question comes on the line of Mark Wilde of Bank of Montral.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Ward, I wondered if you could help us a little bit on the free cash flow guidance because it seems like between kind of CapEx down about $50 million, $150 million from land and development and $300 million from additional synergies, you've got more t
componenttext: Yes. Ward, I wondered if you could help us a little bit on the free cash flow guidance because it seems like between kind of CapEx down about $50 million, $150 million from land and development and $300 million from additional synergies, you've got more tailwind than your kind of current free cash guidance would suggest.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Let me walk you through the details of the $1.2 billion. I already highlighted 3 things. You're right, we do have the contribution of $150 million from land and development versus a small use from land and development in fiscal 2016. In earnings, we
componenttext: Sure. Let me walk you through the details of the $1.2 billion. I already highlighted 3 things. You're right, we do have the contribution of $150 million from land and development versus a small use from land and development in fiscal 2016. In earnings, we have modeled in the implementation of containerboard price increase. That's partially offset by the full year impact of the flow through of the previously announced PPW decreases in some of our consumer grades, along with a negative impact of input cost inflation. So if you take our current pricing for some of our key raw materials and you compare that to the average of those prices in 2016, you could easily model between $175 million and $200 million of inflation on a year-over-year basis. Our working capital and other balance sheet items include -- should be a source as we expand some of our payment terms with our vendors through our supply chain financing programs. The other thing that I would also call out is that we've got some noncash-related earnings. I think we highlighted at the equity and nonconsolidated affiliates, that's Gondi, and it's also the portion of our land and development holdings that are not -- where we don't have a consolidating interest. And we've highlighted that as a negative $6 million for the full year.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just if I could as a follow-on. Just on the -- on this containerboard pricing fronts, I know it's a sensitive issue. But I'm just curious, earlier in the year, there was a decline of about $15 in the linerboard price series in Pulp and Paper Wee
componenttext: Okay. And just if I could as a follow-on. Just on the -- on this containerboard pricing fronts, I know it's a sensitive issue. But I'm just curious, earlier in the year, there was a decline of about $15 in the linerboard price series in Pulp and Paper Week, and there was a lot talk that, that wasn't large enough to trigger any contract adjustments in the box business. So now with the containerboard price hike up much more than that, I'm just trying to figure out whether there's any kind of netting effect of the two.

componenttext: Jeff?

componenttext: Mark, so we had a multitude of contracts and trigger mechanisms literally in thousands of customers, over 15,000 customers, so we're not going to comment generally on that. We have communicated the $50 [ph] a ton price increase to our customer base. And we will report on future calls on the progress.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of George Staphos of Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of George Staphos of Bank of America.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: My first question, what I'll do is I'll piggyback off of Mark's question on pricing and again, recognizing it's not necessarily something you like to talk about in a public forum. Can you give us a little bit more color in terms of the aggregate pricing b
componenttext: My first question, what I'll do is I'll piggyback off of Mark's question on pricing and again, recognizing it's not necessarily something you like to talk about in a public forum. Can you give us a little bit more color in terms of the aggregate pricing benefit or actually reduction that you're thinking about in the fiscal first quarter? Directionally, we know containerboard is up. And we know you have the flow through on the consumer side that's negative. Is there a way to parse those? And if not, just aggregate those in terms of what we should be thinking about given today's pricing. That's my first question. Second question, a totally different topic on home, health and beauty. We're not terribly surprised by the announcement. We've thought this is a good business within the whole of WestRock. But in the past, Steve, you've talked about being a packaging company and dispensing system is being part of being a packaging company. Has there been anything that's changed in your view? Perhaps, it's just valuation multiples. Does that suggest now as a better time to look to explore the valuation arbitrages, if you will, on that business?

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: George, this [indiscernible]. It has fit well with us, and I think you answered the question by saying it's valuation multiples.
componenttext: George, this [indiscernible]. It has fit well with us, and I think you answered the question by saying it's valuation multiples.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016

componenttext: Do I get another one than? Just kidding.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016

componenttext: So George, on the first question on pricing sequentially from Q4 to Q1, we said down slightly with -- we will see some of the initial benefits of the containerboard price increase, but we will also see the flow through, the continued flow through of the PPW reductions on the consumer grades. And again, it'll be a small net negative between the two.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Adam Josephson of KeyBanc.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Adam Josephson of KeyBanc.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ward, one more on the guidance. I know Mark asked you about the cash flow guidance. Can you talk about the implied EBITDA guidance based on everything you laid out in that guidance slide? Or are you expecting full year EBITDA to be up or down relative to
componenttext: Ward, one more on the guidance. I know Mark asked you about the cash flow guidance. Can you talk about the implied EBITDA guidance based on everything you laid out in that guidance slide? Or are you expecting full year EBITDA to be up or down relative to the $227 million that you generated this year?

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: It should be up. The primary drivers of the EBITDA change -- we will continue at productivity. The productivity won't be as high as it was in this fiscal year because we have the benefit of some of the merger-related synergies in the first year. We will h
componenttext: It should be up. The primary drivers of the EBITDA change -- we will continue at productivity. The productivity won't be as high as it was in this fiscal year because we have the benefit of some of the merger-related synergies in the first year. We will have more pressure related to inflation and I size the input cost inflation, and I'd remind you of the $120 million to $125 million worth of labor inflation that we have on top of it. So we will be moving from a -- as you look at the full year FY '16 bridge, where the net commodity deflation and wage inflation was only a negative $50 million, it's going to be considerably more unfavorable on a year-over-year basis. Productivity will be -- you should expect productivity in the $325 million to $350 million range for next year. And then we will have the pricing flow through in containerboard, which will be partially offset by the full year impact of the PPW reductions on the consumer grades.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm curious as to your sense how the market -- the corrugated market is feeling and this price increases feeling relative to prior price increases that you have put through.
componenttext: I'm curious as to your sense how the market -- the corrugated market is feeling and this price increases feeling relative to prior price increases that you have put through.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jeff?
componenttext: Jeff?

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, so currently, the industry fundamentals are really solid. Box demand is up 2.3% year-over-year in September and 1.6% year-to-date on an absolute basis. Consumption is up 2.8%. AF&PA inventories are down 272,000 tons year-over-year September. And inv
componenttext: Mike, so currently, the industry fundamentals are really solid. Box demand is up 2.3% year-over-year in September and 1.6% year-to-date on an absolute basis. Consumption is up 2.8%. AF&PA inventories are down 272,000 tons year-over-year September. And inventories were sitting at 3.8 weeks. Operating rates are strong and high at 95.9%. And these were the highest we've seen since those times. So fundamentals are very good. Our system is extremely tight. We're having to repatriate tons out of the export market to meet our domestic demand and customers. Orders for our domestic containerboard are up and are solid, about 95,000 tons year-over-year and 24,000 tons sequentially. So we see the market fundamentals as strong and very good.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016

componenttext: And relative to prior increases, it's the -- the way it's going, does it feel very similar? And just as a tag on, Pulp & Paper Week could put out a piece this weekend suggesting that the export price increases, even to Latin America, were at least from their perspective not really get any traction. Do you disagree with that?

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016

componenttext: So the first part of that is, I think it's very similar from the last time from what I've recalled. The industry fundamentals are solid and I think that's what we're experiencing.

componenttext: Okay. Just to follow up just want to ask about the strength in corrugated organic growth, I think it was up 2%. headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Brian, this is Bob Feeser. We're seeing stable demand across many of our consumer grades. As Ward mentioned, we'll see the flowthrough on the published SBS and CRB reductions. But our demand is holding up well. We would expect to see normal seasonality in
componenttext: Brian, this is Bob Feeser. We're seeing stable demand across many of our consumer grades. As Ward mentioned, we'll see the flowthrough on the published SBS and CRB reductions. But our demand is holding up well. We would expect to see normal seasonality in the December quarter. As we announced, our backlogs for SBS have improved to 5 weeks and CRB and CNK have improved to 3 weeks. So demands holding up well. CRB is probably one area that's a bit more pressured. But overall, we're looking at a normal first quarter.

componenttext: I want to talk about the $800 million in performance improvements. The incremental $300 million from the $500 million you already got. Can you just talk about how difficult or different it will be to achieve those versus the initial $500 million?

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Debbie, Ward will take that one.
componenttext: Debbie, Ward will take that one.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: What we recognized so far, we've certainly have had the benefits of the merger-related synergies, the reduction and the duplicate quarter costs, but I also highlighted the fact that we have internalized close to 250,000 tons in our consumer system. So as
componenttext: What we recognized so far, we've certainly have had the benefits of the merger-related synergies, the reduction and the duplicate quarter costs, but I also highlighted the fact that we have internalized close to 250,000 tons in our consumer system. So as we start to lap those benefits and move into FY '17, the role of procurement organization will continue to generate 1/3 of the -- of those savings during FY '17. We still have about half o f the remaining SG&A reductions, which are related to IT projects that will also occur during FY '17. Capital investments in our system to return-generating capital investments will play a larger role and then we will also get the full year benefit of some of the footprint actions that we have made across both systems. So we will transition away from merger-related synergies related to the internalization and then will be more focused on capital and investments that were in return-generating projects, procurements and then just the other ongoing performance improvement programs that we have across the whole company.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016

componenttext: Okay. Are these more skewed towards consumer or corrugated?

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016

componenttext: In the fiscal -- in fiscal 2016, it was more skewed to consumer because of the internalization opportunities that we had as a result of the merger. As we move into fiscal 2017, it will be more balanced between the 2 businesses.

componenttext: Debbie, that was just raw materials. And what I simply did was I took current prices for some of our key commodities and compared it to the average for 2016. And then on top of that, you should anticipate that we would have the normal wage and benefit inflation that I've highlighted in the $125 million a year range.

componenttext: Yes. I would say that it was a bit of a surprise, although, again, we continue to see the fundamentals in CRB a little bit more challenging with the dry food market, which is well published in terms of weaker demand in some of the processed foods, dry foods, in particular. I think that is what's primarily contributing to a little bit of weaker environment in CRB.

Just curious to get your thoughts what's driving the resiliency, and other market that got stand out and are you starting to see some initiatives you've made on the commercial front lead -- flowing more fully right now?

componenttext: Yes, I think that's a fair representation. We are seeing our Ag market is up year-over-year. We have strong dairy. Some of our retail e-commerce is significantly up for us. Food service packaging business, which is our pizza business and accompanying businesses that go with the pizza. So some of our client shelves and things that we ship with that is up year-over-year so our demands and backlogs are going very good go into the season. And we're seeing some of the commercial efforts that we've worked on payoff. And really driving the differentiated solutions, and we have the most comprehensive portfolio of paper and packaging products and driving solutions with innovation is really paying off with our customers.

componenttext: Okay, Philip, I'm just going to add -- tuck on to Jeff's comment. We formed an enterprise solutions group and their job is to connect our customers to the full breadth of their product and service offerings, whether it's corrugated or consumer. We're in the early stages of doing this and very well received by our customers and we're recognizing new business opportunities from that. I think we put out a release on those 1 month or 2 ago. Craig Gunckel leads the group and Craig got 20 years of experience with us and he has long track record of delivering sales growth across several of our businesses, so there's going to be -- those are very important time for our company over the long term.

componenttext: Steve, I've just got one question. You said you saw about 2% organic growth in folding carton. Do you think that is a sustainable growth rate? And when you think about your willingness to acquire any opportunities, what do you think is a realistic topline opportunity for folding carton over the next couple of years?

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark, I'm going to let Bob answer that.
componenttext: Mark, I'm going to let Bob answer that.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, Mark. We really like our position in folding carton. As we indicated, we saw 10% growth in the fourth quarter, driven by the Cenveo acquisition, but also the 2% organic growth. And we really believe that we're outpacing the industry in terms of overa
componenttext: Hey, Mark. We really like our position in folding carton. As we indicated, we saw 10% growth in the fourth quarter, driven by the Cenveo acquisition, but also the 2% organic growth. And we really believe that we're outpacing the industry in terms of overall growth that's flat to down. We've got a solid growth pipeline overall, but we're executing against. It's a very well run business. We're driving good productivity improvements, and we're continuing to make good investments in creating more capabilities in that business. So we feel quite good about how we're positioned in folding carton.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then Mark, I'll add that the business --- the majority of the business is food and beverage, and those trends have affected folding carton. I think our business, where we're integrated across all the paper grades, we have the opportunity to, I think g
componenttext: And then Mark, I'll add that the business --- the majority of the business is food and beverage, and those trends have affected folding carton. I think our business, where we're integrated across all the paper grades, we have the opportunity to, I think grow organically probably faster than the industry because of the breadth of offering we have in folding carton. We can offer CRB, SBS and CNK.

componenttext: I wanted to kind of come back to -- probably at least the least favorite topic this morning, that price-oriented stuff. But I heard you very carefully on a couple of 4, 5 instances as far as you communicated with your customers $50 a ton price increase. As I want to kind of dive to that a little. As you sit today at the beginning here of November, are you -- you've communicated with your customers are you, in fact, billing and receiving payments back for what you put through? And the traditionally, that would equate to something, I don't know, 8%, 10% range as we think downstream products? Are you in fact communicated with them in billing and receiving for that as well?

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016

componenttext: So we went to the market unboxed with a 10% and 12% communicated increase. And well we announced and communicated with our customers the $50 on October 1 and board and began billing the $50 a ton increase on October 1.

componenttext: Okay, that's very helpful. Second question I want to ask was -- it kind of comes back around to integration levels in the export, that type of stuff. So I think I heard you mentioned earlier, Jeff, that you were repatriating some board. But I was kind of thinking the integration rates were in the mid- to upper-60s. Can you kind of help me with where you sit today or maybe what you're talking about there? And then when we're thinking about those export markets, that's -- there have been some price announced there. It hasn't seemed to gain a lot of traction. Do you think that, that's something that over the next -- call it, 6 to 12 months, we can see export prices come up as well?

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So we are in the upper 60s integration level. And if you look at some of the JVs we have, where we have paper agreements we're into the low-70s. And so we look -- continue our channel mix and help to increase that integration. Export is a part of ou
componenttext: Sure. So we are in the upper 60s integration level. And if you look at some of the JVs we have, where we have paper agreements we're into the low-70s. And so we look -- continue our channel mix and help to increase that integration. Export is a part of our channels. We all repatriating paper and bringing at the domestic product because of the strong demand we have in our box and domestic markets. We will and have communicated with our customers in the export markets. We did note that some of our prices are larger, it is up. And again, we are communicating directly with them on pricing.
