I would now like to turn the call over to your host, to Matt Tractenberg. Sir, you may begin.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Dexter. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to our Fiscal 2016 Fourth Quarter Earnings Call. My name is Matt Tractenberg, I'm WestRock's Vice President of Investor Relations. I'm joined this morning by Steve Voorhees, WestRock's Chief Executi
componenttext:
Thank you, Dexter. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to our Fiscal 2016 Fourth Quarter Earnings Call. My name is Matt Tractenberg, I'm WestRock's Vice President of Investor Relations. 
I'm joined this morning by Steve Voorhees, WestRock's Chief Executive Officer; Ward Dickson, our Chief Financial Officer; Jim Porter, President of Business Development in Latin America; Jeff Chalovich, President of Corrugated Packaging; and Bob Feeser, President of our Consumer Packaging segment. 
During the course of today's call, we will make forward-looking statements involving our plans, expectations, estimates and beliefs related to future events. These statements may involve a number of risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those we discuss during the call. We describe these risks and uncertainties in our filings with the SEC, including our 10-K for the fiscal year ending September 30, 2015. 
Additionally, we will be referencing adjusted or non-GAAP financial measures during the call. We provided reconciliations of these non-GAAP measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measures in the appendix of the slide presentation. The other -- slide presentation is available on our website. 
So with that said, I'll turn it over to you, Steve.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Matt. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining our call today. September marked the end of our first fiscal year at WestRock. We've had an exciting and productive year. We've made considerable progress in building WestRock into what we are
componenttext:
Thanks, Matt. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining our call today. 
September marked the end of our first fiscal year at WestRock. We've had an exciting and productive year. We've made considerable progress in building WestRock into what we are today. We're a $14 billion paper and packaging company. We hold waiting positions across a board set of markets. We're providing our customers with tailor-made solutions that help them win in their markets. We're executing our strategic plan in delivering excellent results. 
After only 5 quarters, we're already halfway toward our $1 billion, 3-year synergy and performance improvement target. Over the same 5 quarters, we delivered $444 million in productivity improvements. We manage our business to sustain and grow our cash flows over the long term. 
During fiscal '16, we delivered over $1 billion in adjusted free cash flow. We returned $716 million to stockholders through $381 million in dividends and $335 million in share repurchases. Today, we bought back 13.5 million shares or 5% of WestRock's outstanding shares. We improved our business by investing $588 million in 2 acquisitions and 1 joint venture. Our balance sheet is in great shape with a leverage ratio of 2.33x. 
On Friday, we announced a $0.10 per share increase to our annual dividend. The dividend increase underscores our confidence in our long-term cash flows. We have ample capacity to reinvest in our existing facilities. We have the flexibility to make acquisitions that improve our business and generate attractive returns. We will continue to purchase WestRock shares and expect to hold leverage within our targeted range of 2.25 to 2.5x. 
Sales for the quarter were $3.6 billion and adjusted EBITDA was $589 million for a margin of 16.3%. Adjusted earnings per share were $0.71. Productivity initiatives contributed $89 million to our income during the quarter. 
We transferred $2.5 billion  of pension assets and liabilities to a third party. This transaction significantly derisks our U.S. qualified pension plan. 
For the full year, sales were $14 billion and adjusted EBITDA was $2.3 billion for a margin of 16%. 
We achieved our productivity and cash flow objectives in fiscal '16 when we set the stage for very successful 2017. 
The Corrugated Packaging team delivered solid results in the quarter, including North American adjusted EBITDA margins of 18.2%. Adjusted EBITDA declined by $31 million from the prior year and was flat sequentially. 
As we said what happened on last quarter's call, the Pulp & Paper Week price reduction from earlier this year continues to flow through this quarter. This is true for both our box and domestic containerboard businesses. 
We reduced inventory by 143,000 tons from a year ago, and we reduced inventory 16,000 tons sequentially. We took 32,000 tons of maintenance downtime in the quarter. Most of this downtime was at our Stevenson mill, where we completed our capital project to convert to a new pulping process. This scheduled outage at the Stevenson mill reduced income by $10 million. 
We're communicated a $50 per ton price increase to our customers for domestic containerboard and Corrugated Packaging. Export pricing has improved in our largest markets, including Latin America, where pricing was up $8 per ton sequentially. Our system has been and continues to be tight with good demand, low inventories and high operating rates.
Within our box business, backlogs have strengthened, and our current pipeline in new business remains strong. Our differentiated strategy is earning us new business. 
In October, our box volumes were up 1.6% over last year on a daily basis. 
Turning to Hurricane Matthew. I'm pleased to report that our employees came through Hurricane Matthew with no injuries. We have had several employees and their families with damage to their homes and some of these employees are receiving support from the WestRock employee relief fund. The impact of Hurricane Matthew on our business has reduced production by 35,000 tons. We've reduced shipments to export markets to help meet our improving demand as well as address the lower production due to Hurricane Matthew. 
Grupo Gondi sales in the quarter were $180 million and EBITDA margins exceeded 20%. We shipped 55,000 tons of container board to the Grupo Gondi joint venture and we expect shipments to increase going forward as Gondi grows its business. Last week, Gondi completed the acquisition of Aluprint, a leading manufacturer of folding cartons in Mexico. This acquisition has additional capabilities for Gondi to serve customers in the growing Mexican packaging market. 
In Brazil, our team performed exceptionally well despite continued regional economic challenges. Box shipments per day were up by approximately 9% over the prior year and up 4% sequentially. EBITDA margins were 26.4%. Jim Porter is working with the team in Brazil and I expect that they will create attractive investment opportunities for WestRock over the next year. 
Jim continues to advise us on the North American Containerboard business as Jeff Chalovich has assumed the responsibility of leading this business for WestRock. 
Jeff brings over 25 years of industry experience to WestRock. He joined Rock-Tenn in 2008 when we acquired Southern Container. He's been leading our $5 billion box business for the past 4 years. 
Over the same period, we've improved our North American Corrugated Packaging EBITDA margins from 13% to 18%. Jeff's leadership has driven much of this improvement, and we have more runway to increase margins. I'm looking forward to supporting our entire Corrugated Packaging team to deliver even better results through the execution of our differentiated strategy. 
Consumer packaging delivered improved earnings and margins in the quarter. Net sales were $1.6 billion and adjusted EBITDA was $268 million. We delivered $42 million in productivity improvements. This drove our 90 basis point increase in adjusted EBITDA margins. 
Folding carton revenue grew by 10% year-over-year, driven by the Cenveo Packaging acquisition and organic growth of 2% in our core North American business. We're making good progress on productivity initiatives across our converting businesses. 
Pricing and mix were favorable, primarily due to lower pulp volumes. This was partially offset by the flow through of previously published index reductions for SBS and CRB. Our SBS backlogs have strengthened and are currently at 5 weeks. We produced less pulp at our SBS mills in the quarter. This was a result of improved paperboard demand and planned maintenance outages at the Covington and Demopolis mills. 
We're seeing limited penetration from European and Asian board suppliers that's been targeting the U.S. market. 
Finally, sequentially, both our CRB and CNK backlogs have increased and both are approximately at 3 weeks. 
Bob Feeser leads our Consumer Packaging business. Bob's career started at Mead about 30 years ago. His known converting experience includes consumer, corrugated, domestic and international assignments. Bob has as broad a set of experiences as any executive at WestRock. Bob's been instrumental in delivering more than $230 million in productivity improvements in the Consumer Packaging business. 
Our Consumer Packaging business is successful implementing our differentiated strategy. I look forward to supporting the business and their drive to improve margins. 
Home, health and beauty. Our home, health and beauty business has been performing extremely well over the past few years. Fiscal '16, our sales were $567 million. EBITDA was in excess of $100 million. Capital expenditures have been less than 5% of sales. The business has generated very strong cash flows that have grown and that we expect to continue to grow over the next several years. The entire home, health and beauty organization deserves recognition for what they've accomplished since the merger and many years before the merger. 
While the business has fit well with WestRock's portfolio of packaging solutions, publically held peers within home, health and beauty are valued at higher multiples in WestRock overall. And in fact, our home, health and beauty business may fit even better with another company. 
Accordingly, our board has authorized us to evaluate strategic alternatives for the home, health and beauty business. These alternatives include the potential sale of the business during the first half of calendar 2017. In the event we sell the business for cash, we expect to use the sale proceeds consistent with our balance capital allocation strategy. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Ward.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Steve. We are making great progress on monetizing our land and development portfolio. We completed the $13 million after-tax sale of a residential apartment complex during the quarter. As discussed on our previous call, we expect to realize 0.5
componenttext:
Thank you, Steve. We are making great progress on monetizing our land and development portfolio. We completed the $13 million after-tax sale of a residential apartment complex during the quarter. As discussed on our previous call, we expect to realize 0.5 of the $275 million to $300 million in net after-tax free cash flow during fiscal 2017. 
As Steve indicated, we continue to execute very well on our synergy and performance improvement objectives. We exited the September quarter at an annual run rate of $500 million. Fiscal 2016 productivity was driven by insourcing initiatives, procurement, actions to rationalize our footprint, return generating capital investments and merger-related synergies. We expect to achieve an $800 million run rate by the end of fiscal year 2017 and remain on track to achieve our $1 billion goal by the end of fiscal 2018. 
Fourth quarter adjusted segment EBITDA declined by $27 million, driven in part by unfavorable volume, the anticipated impact of price and mix and inflation of both input cost and labor. The impact of these 3 items was nearly offset by ongoing productivity improvements. 
On a full year basis, the combined company adjusted EBITDA declined by $51 million, driven by lower volume and favorable pricing mix, wage and other input cost inflation. However, we were able to offset much of these items by delivering $384 million of productivity improvements. 
In summary, both the quarter and the full fiscal year were successful. And I'd like to thank all of our employees for making this happen. 
As we look back at the first 5 quarters of WestRock, we have allocated $2.8 billion of capital. We have invested over $1 billion in capital expenditures over the last 15 months and continue to see numerous attractive return-generating opportunities. 
We returned $1.14 billion or almost half of the total to stockholders in the form of dividends and stock repurchases. This return of cash to stockholders via dividends and share buybacks will continue to be an important part of our capital allocation strategy. 
In the first quarter, we expect sequential earnings will be lower, in line with seasonal -- with the seasonal pattern we experienced last year. I'd like to remind you that from Q4 fiscal 2015 to Q1 fiscal 2016, segment income declined by $88 million. We have outlined several of the drivers of the first quarter and full year on Slide 12. 
For Q1, we anticipate that pricing mix will be negative as the impact of the previously announced corrugated price increase will be more than offset by the flow through of the previously published consumer price decreases. 
The first quarter is typically our heaviest maintenance period, and we are planning 160,000 tons of downtime. Volumes will likely decline, driven by 4 less shipping days in our Container business. Consumer grades experience seasonal softness in the first quarter as well. Inflation of input prices will continue in the period. And finally, Hurricane Matthew will negatively impact us by approximately $15 million to $20 million. These items should lead you to a first quarter adjusted EPS lower than what we delivered in the fourth quarter of fiscal 2016, but increasing steadily as we make our way through the year. 
For the full year fiscal 2017, we expect to deliver adjusted free cash flow of $1.2 billion, including approximately $150 million of land and development after-tax cash flow. We expect to invest approximately $750 million in CapEx. We also expect to realize significant productivity as well as meaningful inflation in some commodity categories, including natural gas, recycled fiber and certain chemicals. Both tax rates are estimated at 34% to 35%, and cash tax rates are in the high 20s. 
Steve, I will hand it back to you for closing comments.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ward. I'm proud of the progress we've made in our first full year as WestRock. WestRock offers a comprehensive portfolio of paper and packaging products and services. This portfolio provides WestRock the opportunity to deliver winning solutions to
componenttext:
Thanks, Ward. I'm proud of the progress we've made in our first full year as WestRock. WestRock offers a comprehensive portfolio of paper and packaging products and services. This portfolio provides WestRock the opportunity to deliver winning solutions to our customers that help them win in their markets. We're doing just that. This is and will translate into great value for our customers, our employees and our stockholders. 
We exceeded our productivity and free cash flow targets in fiscal year '16, and we're looking forward to continued success in fiscal '17. Our cash flow is the foundation of our balanced capital allocation program, investing our business to capital improvements and acquisitions and returning value to stockholders in the form of dividends and share repurchases. 
And as important as anything else, we have a terrific team and strategy. We're looking forward to driving even greater value creation in the future. 
Matt, back to you.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Steve. [Operator Instructions] Dexter, please open the call for questions.
componenttext: Thanks, Steve. [Operator Instructions] Dexter, please open the call for questions.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Ward, I wondered if you could help us a little bit on the free cash flow guidance because it seems like between kind of CapEx down about $50 million, $150 million from land and development and $300 million from additional synergies, you've got more t
componenttext: Yes. Ward, I wondered if you could help us a little bit on the free cash flow guidance because it seems like between kind of CapEx down about $50 million, $150 million from land and development and $300 million from additional synergies, you've got more tailwind than your kind of current free cash guidance would suggest.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Let me walk you through the details of the $1.2 billion. I'll  already highlight 3 things. You're right, we do have the contribution of $150 million from land and development versus a small use from land and development in fiscal 2016. In earnings,
componenttext: Sure. Let me walk you through the details of the $1.2 billion. I'll  already highlight 3 things. You're right, we do have the contribution of $150 million from land and development versus a small use from land and development in fiscal 2016. In earnings, we have modeled in the implementation of containerboard price increase. That's partially offset by the full year impact of the flow through of the previously announced PPW decreases in some of our consumer grades, along with a negative impact of input cost inflation. So if you take our current pricing for some of our key raw materials and you compare that to the average of those prices in 2016, you could easily model between $175 million and $200 million of inflation on a year-over-year basis. Our working capital and other balance sheet items include -- should be a source as we expand some of our payment terms with our vendors through our supply chain financing programs. The other thing that I would also call out is that we've got some noncash-related earnings. I think we highlighted at the equity and nonconsolidated affiliates, that's Gondi, and it's also the portion of our land and development holdings that are not -- where we don't have a consolidating interest. And we've highlighted that as a negative $6 million for the full year.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just if I could as a follow-on. Just on the -- on this containerboard pricing front, I know it's a sensitive issue. But I'm just curious, earlier in the year, there was a decline of about $15 in the linerboard price series in Pulp and Paper Week
componenttext: Okay. And just if I could as a follow-on. Just on the -- on this containerboard pricing front, I know it's a sensitive issue. But I'm just curious, earlier in the year, there was a decline of about $15 in the linerboard price series in Pulp and Paper Week, and there was a lot talk that, that wasn't large enough to trigger any contract adjustments in the box business. So now with the containerboard price hike up much more than that, I'm just trying to figure out whether there's any kind of netting effect of the two.

componenttext: Mark, so we have a multitude of contracts and trigger mechanisms literally in thousands of customers, over 15,000 customers, so we're not going to comment generally on that. We have communicated the $50 a ton price increase to our customer base. And we will report in future calls on the progress.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of George Staphos of Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of George Staphos of Bank of America.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: My first question, what I'll do is I'll piggyback off of Mark's question on pricing and again, recognizing it's not necessarily something you like to talk about in a public forum. Can you give us a little bit more color in terms of the aggregate pricing b
componenttext: My first question, what I'll do is I'll piggyback off of Mark's question on pricing and again, recognizing it's not necessarily something you like to talk about in a public forum. Can you give us a little bit more color in terms of the aggregate pricing benefit or actually reduction that you're thinking about in the fiscal first quarter? Directionally, we know containerboard is up. And we know you have the flow through on the consumer side that's negative. Is there a way to parse those? And if not, just aggregate those in terms of what we should be thinking about given today's pricing. That's my first question. Second question, a totally different topic on home, health and beauty. We're not terribly surprised by the announcement. We've thought this is a good business within the whole of WestRock. But in the past, Steve, you've talked about being a packaging company and dispensing systems as being part of being a packaging company. Has there been anything that's changed in your view? Perhaps, it's just valuation multiples. Does that suggest now as a better time to look to explore the valuation arbitrage, if you will, on that business?

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: George, this is something that has fit well with us, and I think you answered the question by saying it's valuation multiples.
componenttext: George, this is something that has fit well with us, and I think you answered the question by saying it's valuation multiples.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Do I get another one than? Just kidding.
componenttext: Do I get another one than? Just kidding.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016

componenttext: Yes. Ward, take the first question.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: So George, on the first question on pricing sequentially from Q4 to Q1, we said down slightly with -- we will see some of the initial benefits of the containerboard price increase, but we will also see the flow through, the continued flow through of the P
componenttext: So George, on the first question on pricing sequentially from Q4 to Q1, we said down slightly with -- we will see some of the initial benefits of the containerboard price increase, but we will also see the flow through, the continued flow through of the PPW reductions on the consumer grades. And again, it'll be a small net negative between the two.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Adam Josephson of KeyBanc.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Adam Josephson of KeyBanc.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ward, one more on the guidance. I know Mark asked you about the cash flow guidance. Can you talk about the implied EBITDA guidance based on everything you laid out in that guidance slide? Or are you expecting full year EBITDA to be up or down relative to
componenttext: Ward, one more on the guidance. I know Mark asked you about the cash flow guidance. Can you talk about the implied EBITDA guidance based on everything you laid out in that guidance slide? Or are you expecting full year EBITDA to be up or down relative to the $227 million that you generated this year?

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: It should be up. The primary drivers of the EBITDA change -- we will continue at productivity. The productivity won't be as high as it was in this fiscal year because we have the benefit of some of the merger-related synergies in the first year. We will h
componenttext: It should be up. The primary drivers of the EBITDA change -- we will continue at productivity. The productivity won't be as high as it was in this fiscal year because we have the benefit of some of the merger-related synergies in the first year. We will have more pressure related to inflation and I sized the input cost inflation, and I'd remind you of the $120 million to $125 million worth of labor inflation that we have on top of it. So we will be moving from a -- as you look at the full year FY '16 bridge, where the net commodity deflation and wage inflation was only a negative $50 million, it's going to be considerably more unfavorable on a year-over-year basis. Productivity will be -- you should expect productivity in the $325 million to $350 million range for next year. And then we will have the pricing flow through in containerboard, which will be partially offset by the full year impact of the PPW reductions on the consumer grades.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just as a follow-on, I assume home, health and beauty is in your full year cash flow and EBITDA cash flow guidance.
componenttext: Okay. And just as a follow-on, I assume home, health and beauty is in your full year cash flow and EBITDA cash flow guidance.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: It is and it's -- again, I would reference some of the key facts that Steve gave you. It's approximately just north of $100 million worth of EBITDA. Their CapEx is approximately 5% of sales. And so we estimate that the cash flow for -- free cash flow for
componenttext: It is and it's -- again, I would reference some of the key facts that Steve gave you. It's approximately just north of $100 million worth of EBITDA. Their CapEx is approximately 5% of sales. And so we estimate that the cash flow for -- free cash flow for the full year is around $60 million.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that's included in the $1.2 billion.
componenttext: And that's included in the $1.2 billion.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's included in the $1.2 billion. I would highlight, as you look at FY '17 versus FY '16, we also had a small source less than $30 million ultimately from Ingevity in 2016 that was included in the full year number. And so that obviously doesn't recur a
componenttext: That's included in the $1.2 billion. I would highlight, as you look at FY '17 versus FY '16, we also had a small source less than $30 million ultimately from Ingevity in 2016 that was included in the full year number. And so that obviously doesn't recur and shows that the underlying free cash flow of the business increases year-over-year.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Mark Weintraub of Buckingham Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Mark Weintraub of Buckingham Research.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm curious as to your sense how the market -- the corrugated market is feeling and this price increases feeling relative to prior price increases that you have put through.
componenttext: I'm curious as to your sense how the market -- the corrugated market is feeling and this price increases feeling relative to prior price increases that you have put through.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jeff?
componenttext: Jeff?

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, so currently, the industry fundamentals are really solid. Box demand is up 2.3% year-over-year in September and 1.6% year-to-date on an absolute basis. Consumption is up 2.8%. AF&PA inventories are down 272,000 tons year-over-year September. And inv
componenttext: Mike, so currently, the industry fundamentals are really solid. Box demand is up 2.3% year-over-year in September and 1.6% year-to-date on an absolute basis. Consumption is up 2.8%. AF&PA inventories are down 272,000 tons year-over-year September. And inventories are sitting at 3.8 weeks. Operating rates are strong and high at 95.9%. And these were the highest we've seen since those times. So fundamentals are very good. Our system is extremely tight. We're having to repatriate tons out of the export market to meet our domestic demand and customers. Orders for our domestic containerboard are up and are solid, about 95,000 tons year-over-year and 24,000 tons sequentially. So we see the market fundamentals as strong and very good.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: And relative to prior increases, is the way it's going, does it feel very similar? And just as a tag on, Pulp & Paper Week could put out a piece this weekend suggesting that the export price increases, even to Latin America, were at least in their -- from
componenttext: And relative to prior increases, is the way it's going, does it feel very similar? And just as a tag on, Pulp & Paper Week could put out a piece this weekend suggesting that the export price increases, even to Latin America, were at least in their -- from their perspective not really getting any traction. Would -- do you disagree with that?

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the first part of that is I think it's very similar from the last time from what I've recalled. The industry fundamentals are solid and I think that's what we're experiencing.
componenttext: So the first part of that is I think it's very similar from the last time from what I've recalled. The industry fundamentals are solid and I think that's what we're experiencing.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016

componenttext: And then on the export question.

componenttext: I'm sorry. What was the export question?

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Pulp & Paper Week put out an article this weekend suggesting that the price increases since the export market hadn't really been gaining traction. I did note you said that your prices were up $8 versus the prior quarter. is with- but the current initiativ
componenttext: Pulp & Paper Week put out an article this weekend suggesting that the price increases since the export market hadn't really been gaining traction. I did note you said that your prices were up $8 versus the prior quarter. is with- but the current initiative, do you disagree with that assessment? Do you still feel that you have a good chance of getting traction on those price increases into the export markets?

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016

componenttext: Just want to follow up on the potential sale of the home, health and beauty. Just wondering if what will be the priorities for uses of cash there. And maybe as a -- as part of that, you could just address the M&A landscape as you see it these days and what part of the portfolio you'd want to be reinvesting at this point.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Whatever pricings we get, we'll insert into our balanced capital allocation strategy. and we'll look at the relative merits of the alternatives we have at that time. I think the M&A landscape is -- I think we have good deal flow across and our -- an
componenttext: Sure. Whatever pricings we get, we'll insert into our balanced capital allocation strategy. and we'll look at the relative merits of the alternatives we have at that time. I think the M&A landscape is -- I think we have good deal flow across and our -- and across all of our businesses, so both in consumer and corrugated. And so we're -- that's where we are.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Just as a follow-up. Just wanted to ask about the strength in the corrugated organic growth. I think it was up 2%. If you can just dig into which grade and applications you're seeing the most strength in and how you kind of view inventories in that
componenttext: Okay. Just as a follow-up. Just wanted to ask about the strength in the corrugated organic growth. I think it was up 2%. If you can just dig into which grade and applications you're seeing the most strength in and how you kind of view inventories in that part of the business and just kind of the outlook for demand heading into fiscal '17.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Bob?
componenttext: Yes, Bob?

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Brian, this is Bob Feeser. We're seeing stable demand across many of our consumer grades. As Ward mentioned, we will see the flow-through on the published SBS and CRB reductions. But our demand is holding up well. We would expect to see normal seasonality
componenttext: Brian, this is Bob Feeser. We're seeing stable demand across many of our consumer grades. As Ward mentioned, we will see the flow-through on the published SBS and CRB reductions. But our demand is holding up well. We would expect to see normal seasonality in the December quarter. As we announced, our backlogs for SBS have improved to 5 weeks, and CRB and CNK have improved to 3 weeks. So demand is holding up well. CRB is probably one area that's a bit more pressured. But overall, we're looking at a normal first quarter.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Debbie Jones of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Debbie Jones of Deutsche Bank.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to talk about the $800 million in performance improvements, the incremental $300 million from the $500 million you've already got. Can you just talk about how difficult or different it will be to achieve those versus the initial $500 million?
componenttext: I wanted to talk about the $800 million in performance improvements, the incremental $300 million from the $500 million you've already got. Can you just talk about how difficult or different it will be to achieve those versus the initial $500 million?

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Debbie, Ward will take that one.
componenttext: Debbie, Ward will take that one.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: What we've recognized so far, we've certainly have had the benefits of the merger-related synergies, the reduction and the duplicate quarter costs. But I also highlighted the fact that we have internalized close to 250,000 tons on that -- in our consumer
componenttext: What we've recognized so far, we've certainly have had the benefits of the merger-related synergies, the reduction and the duplicate quarter costs. But I also highlighted the fact that we have internalized close to 250,000 tons on that -- in our consumer system. So as we start to lap those benefits and move into FY '17, the role of the procurement organization will continue to generate 1/3 of the -- of those savings during FY '17. We still have about half of the remaining SG&A reductions, which are related to IT projects that will also occur during FY '17. Capital investments in our system to return-generating capital investments will play a larger role. And then we will also get the full year benefit of some of the footprint actions that we have made across both systems. So we will transition away from the merger-related synergies related to the internalization, and then there will be more focused on capital and investments that were in return-generating projects, procurement and then just the other ongoing performance improvement programs that we have across the whole company.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Are these more skewed towards consumer or corrugated?
componenttext: Okay. Are these more skewed towards consumer or corrugated?

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: In the  -- in fiscal 2016, it was more skewed to consumer because of the internalization opportunities that we had as a result of the merger. As we move into fiscal 2017, it will be more balanced between the 2 businesses.
componenttext: In the  -- in fiscal 2016, it was more skewed to consumer because of the internalization opportunities that we had as a result of the merger. As we move into fiscal 2017, it will be more balanced between the 2 businesses.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And just one more on this -- the inflationary range, you called out $175 million to $200 million. Is that just from raw material? Or does that also include general cost inflation?

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: That was -- Debbie, that was just raw materials. And what I simply did was I took current prices for some of our key commodities and compared it to the average for 2016. And then on top of that, you should anticipate that we would have the normal wage and
componenttext: That was -- Debbie, that was just raw materials. And what I simply did was I took current prices for some of our key commodities and compared it to the average for 2016. And then on top of that, you should anticipate that we would have the normal wage and benefit inflation that I've highlighted in the $125 million a year range.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016

componenttext: In your guidance, you indicated you were planning downtime in consumer packaging in 1Q and 3Q. And I was wondering if it's possible to say which grades you're taking that downtime. And then just zooming in on CRB, we saw the price cut in September. What drove that? And what's driven maybe a little bit more of a weaker environment in CRB in your eyes?

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Bob?
componenttext: Yes, Bob?

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Anthony, the downtime that we've highlighted is maintenance downtime related just to normal mill outages that we have both in the first quarter as well as the third quarter.
componenttext: Yes. Anthony, the downtime that we've highlighted is maintenance downtime related just to normal mill outages that we have both in the first quarter as well as the third quarter.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So that -- is that spread across all 3 grades?
componenttext: Okay. So that -- is that spread across all 3 grades?

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: It is -- well, yes, it's spread between -- primarily, what you're seeing is SBS and CNK, a little bit in the CRB business. But it's mostly SBS and CNK.
componenttext: It is -- well, yes, it's spread between -- primarily, what you're seeing is SBS and CNK, a little bit in the CRB business. But it's mostly SBS and CNK.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then in terms of CRB and the price decline in September, did that surprise you? And is there a reason that CRB seems a little bit weaker than the other 2 grades? At least, from the outside, it looks that way.
componenttext: Okay. And then in terms of CRB and the price decline in September, did that surprise you? And is there a reason that CRB seems a little bit weaker than the other 2 grades? At least, from the outside, it looks that way.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I would say that it was a bit of a surprise. Although, again, we continue to see the fundamentals in CRB a little bit more challenging with the dry food market, which is well published in terms of weaker demand in some of the processed foods, dry foo
componenttext: Yes. I would say that it was a bit of a surprise. Although, again, we continue to see the fundamentals in CRB a little bit more challenging with the dry food market, which is well published in terms of weaker demand in some of the processed foods, dry foods, in particular. I think that is what's primarily contributing to a little bit of a weaker environment in CRB.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Box shipments in North America held up pretty well and it seems like things have picked up a bit in October. Just curious to get your thoughts what's driving the resiliency. Any other markets that's got really stand out? And are you starting to see some o
componenttext: Box shipments in North America held up pretty well and it seems like things have picked up a bit in October. Just curious to get your thoughts what's driving the resiliency. Any other markets that's got really stand out? And are you starting to see some of the initiatives that you've made on the commercial front lead flowing through more fully right now?

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that's a fair representation. We are seeing our ag market is up year-over-year. We have strong dairy. Some of our retail e-commerce is significantly up for us. Food service packaging business, which is our pizza business and accompanying busi
componenttext: Yes, I think that's a fair representation. We are seeing our ag market is up year-over-year. We have strong dairy. Some of our retail e-commerce is significantly up for us. Food service packaging business, which is our pizza business and accompanying businesses that go with the pizza, so some of our clam shells and things that we ship with that, are up year-over-year. So our demands and backlogs are going very good going into the season. And we are seeing some of the commercial efforts that we've worked on pay off and really driving the differentiated solutions. And we have the most comprehensive portfolio of paper and packaging products. And driving solutions with innovation is really paying off with our customers.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Phil -- go ahead, Phil.
componenttext: And Phil -- go ahead, Phil.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016

componenttext: Okay, Philip, I was just going to add--tack on to Jeff's comment. We've formed an enterprise solutions group, and their job is to connect our customers to the full breadth of our -- to our product and service offerings, whether it's corrugated or consumer. We're in the early stages of doing this. It's been very well received by our customers, and we're recognizing new business opportunities from that. I think we had put out a release on those a month or 2 ago. Craig Gunckel leads the group. And Craig's got 20 years of experience with us and he has a long track record of delivering sales growth across several of our businesses. So there's going to be -- those are very important time for our company over the long term.

componenttext: It's balanced. The portfolio fits very well together. And we're able to go to our customers agnostically between consumer and corrugated different paper grades to put together a tailor-made solution for their needs. So it -- our portfolio really fits well together.

componenttext: I'm just going to tell you that are what we track on our backlogs in box are really 5 and 10 days rolling. And so we see the backlog's building on our 5. headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016

componenttext: Steve, I've just got one question. You said you saw about 2% organic growth in folding carton. Do you think that is a sustainable growth rate? And when you think about your willingness to acquire any opportunities, what do you think is a realistic top line opportunity for folding carton over the next couple of years?

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark, I'm going to let Bob answer that.
componenttext: Mark, I'm going to let Bob answer that.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark, we really like our position in folding carton. As we indicated, we saw 10% growth in the fourth quarter driven by the Cenveo acquisition, but also the 2% organic growth. And we really believe that we're outpacing the industry in terms of overall gro
componenttext: Mark, we really like our position in folding carton. As we indicated, we saw 10% growth in the fourth quarter driven by the Cenveo acquisition, but also the 2% organic growth. And we really believe that we're outpacing the industry in terms of overall growth that's flat to down. We've got a solid growth pipeline overall that we're executing against. It's a very well run business. We're driving good productivity improvements. And we're continuing to make good investments in creating more capabilities in that business. So we feel quite good about how we're positioned in folding carton.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then Mark, I'll add that the business is --- the majority of the business is food and beverage. And those trends have affected folding carton. I think our business, where we're integrated across all of our paper grades, we have the opportunity to, I t
componenttext: And then Mark, I'll add that the business is --- the majority of the business is food and beverage. And those trends have affected folding carton. I think our business, where we're integrated across all of our paper grades, we have the opportunity to, I think, grow organically probably faster than the industry because of the breadth of offering we have in folding carton. We can offer CRB, SBS and CNK.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Chris Manuel of Wells Fargo Securities.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to kind of come back to, probably your least favorite topic event this morning, that's price-oriented stuff. But I've heard you very carefully on a couple 4, 5 instances thus far. So you've communicated with your customers a $50 ton price increas
componenttext: I wanted to kind of come back to, probably your least favorite topic event this morning, that's price-oriented stuff. But I've heard you very carefully on a couple 4, 5 instances thus far. So you've communicated with your customers a $50 ton price increase. So I just wanted to kind of dive in to that a little. As you sit today in the beginning here of November, are you -- you've communicated with customers. Are you, in fact, billing and receiving payments back for what you put through? And then traditionally, that would equate to somethingin a, I don't know, 8%, 10% range. As we think of downstream products, have you, in fact, communicated with them in billing and receiving for that as well?

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we went to the market on box with a 10% and 12% communicated increase. And well, we announced and communicated with our customers the $50 on October 1 in board and began billing the $50 a ton increase on October 1.
componenttext: So we went to the market on box with a 10% and 12% communicated increase. And well, we announced and communicated with our customers the $50 on October 1 in board and began billing the $50 a ton increase on October 1.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's very helpful. Second question I want to ask was, it kind of comes back around to integration levels and on export and that type of stuff. So I think I heard you mentioned earlier, Jeff, that you were repatriating some board. But I was kind of
componenttext: Okay, that's very helpful. Second question I want to ask was, it kind of comes back around to integration levels and on export and that type of stuff. So I think I heard you mentioned earlier, Jeff, that you were repatriating some board. But I was kind of thinking your integration rates were in the mid- upper-60s. Can you kind of help me with where you sit today or maybe what you're talking about there? And then when we're thinking about those export markets, that's -- there've been some price announced there. It hasn't seemed to gain a lot of traction. Do you think that, that's something that over the next, call it, 6 to 12 months, we could see export prices come up as well?

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So we are in the upper 60s integration level. And if you look at some of the JVs we have, where we have paper agreements, we're into the low-70s. And so we look -- continuing our channel mix and how to increase that integration. Export is a part of
componenttext: Sure. So we are in the upper 60s integration level. And if you look at some of the JVs we have, where we have paper agreements, we're into the low-70s. And so we look -- continuing our channel mix and how to increase that integration. Export is a part of our channels. We are repatriating paper and bringing it to the domestic market because of the strong demand we have in our box and domestic markets. We will and have communicated with our customers in the export markets. We did note that some of our prices in our large areas is up. And again, we are communicating directly with them on pricing.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Chip Dillon of Vertical Research Partners.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Chip Dillon of Vertical Research Partners.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question has to do with -- you mentioned in the slides the strategic options you're looking out for home, health and beauty. And if I kind of interpolate from preacquisition, it would seem like the EBITDA there is probably in the range of $130 milli
componenttext: First question has to do with -- you mentioned in the slides the strategic options you're looking out for home, health and beauty. And if I kind of interpolate from preacquisition, it would seem like the EBITDA there is probably in the range of $130 million or so and maybe revenues to $750 million, $800 million. Is that the rough ballpark as we think about what the prospects are for that business?

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: We said $500 and some odd million of sales and EBITDA over $100 million. When -- with the merger, they have some folding carton business that we have integrated into our folding carton business, so that would account for the difference.
componenttext: We said $500 and some odd million of sales and EBITDA over $100 million. When -- with the merger, they have some folding carton business that we have integrated into our folding carton business, so that would account for the difference.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And what [indiscernible] you've had -- you're missing some sales, but not much EBITDA it sounds like. And then a second question just looking at the industry in general. It's been almost a record period, 3.5 years since we saw corrug
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And what [indiscernible] you've had -- you're missing some sales, but not much EBITDA it sounds like. And then a second question just looking at the industry in general. It's been almost a record period, 3.5 years since we saw corrugated prices move up in North America. And one thing I seem to recall in the past is when you've had a long period of time, unless whether it's your box plant managers looking at it on their own P&L level or your independent customers, we've had a long time where they have not had the opportunity to offset naturally rising cost like health care cost or the fact that people might get paid a little more every year. And so my question is, should we read into the announced box price increase, I think you mentioned 10% to 12%, some opportunity to capture some of those-- to offset some of those cost increases, so that if I'm an independent player, I might actually see my realizations go up more than $50 because, obviously, if I'm paying $50 more for board, I need more than that to offset these other costs?

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So I can't really speak to what the independents and others will do. I can speak to -- we have a very rigorous process of how we manage our business and how we increase prices, track that and implement that. And whether it's during a time we've anno
componenttext: Sure. So I can't really speak to what the independents and others will do. I can speak to -- we have a very rigorous process of how we manage our business and how we increase prices, track that and implement that. And whether it's during a time we've announced with our customers an increase or just the normal course of business, we look to drive margins through other areas of our business, and that's through board grade optimizations, that's through efficiency gains. And so that's something we do as a matter of course with our customers. And we add value to them and help them drive total cost of use out of the system and improve our margins across our system.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Gail Glazerman of Roe Equity Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Gail Glazerman of Roe Equity Research.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: I want to touch on containerboard inventories. Your 143,000 drop was quite significant relative to the industry decline of 272,000. And I know going all the way back to your investor meeting in 2013, you talked about carrying more inventory than 4 weeks.
componenttext: I want to touch on containerboard inventories. Your 143,000 drop was quite significant relative to the industry decline of 272,000. And I know going all the way back to your investor meeting in 2013, you talked about carrying more inventory than 4 weeks. And at one point, you had spotted a number that was much higher than the industry level. And I just want to know has that changed. And can you give any sense the way your current inventories are after that decline relative to the $3.8 million to the industry?

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Jim Porter. I'll take that one. You've heard correctly. We've put a lot of energy over the last few years investing in our supply chain processes and people to drive better systems and capabilities to match our customer requirements. That's the on
componenttext: This is Jim Porter. I'll take that one. You've heard correctly. We've put a lot of energy over the last few years investing in our supply chain processes and people to drive better systems and capabilities to match our customer requirements. That's the only reason we have inventory is to ensure we've got the right products available on time for all of our channels. And so you saw us early in our journey increasing inventories, but you've now seen them steadily decline. And I believe that's really the success of the implementations that we've had within our systems. Our system, currently, it is in balance.  Now it was somewhat ganged by the Hurricane Matthew. So we're, frankly, a little below where we should be at this point in time. And then you also see us needing to increase inventories slightly as we focus on next quarter's maintenance downtime. But we've managed inventories at a very granular level and the trend line downward, I think, is a result of those initiatives.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's great. Just one last question. The cost that you've estimated to the storm, how confident are you in that? Is everything kind of back up and running? Or are there any kind of risk in terms of operations, logistics, fiber supply beyond, obviou
componenttext: Okay, that's great. Just one last question. The cost that you've estimated to the storm, how confident are you in that? Is everything kind of back up and running? Or are there any kind of risk in terms of operations, logistics, fiber supply beyond, obviously, the comments on inventory?

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. so we -- Gail, this is Ward. We tried to capture all of those factors when we gave you the range of the estimate. I would say 50% of that cost that we identified was related to the lost production and 50% of it was actually related to the additional
componenttext: Yes. so we -- Gail, this is Ward. We tried to capture all of those factors when we gave you the range of the estimate. I would say 50% of that cost that we identified was related to the lost production and 50% of it was actually related to the additional maintenance repair and some scrappage cost that we had in the quarter.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of George Staphos of Bank of America.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of George Staphos of Bank of America.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two questions, one kind of bigger picture, the other one more modeling related. On the latter, can you give us an update on what your thoughts for interest expense might be next year, both cash and book, if there's any differences? And then we just came b
componenttext: Two questions, one kind of bigger picture, the other one more modeling related. On the latter, can you give us an update on what your thoughts for interest expense might be next year, both cash and book, if there's any differences? And then we just came back from a conference where there was a lot of discussion on lightweight high-performance grades in containerboard. Can you remind us what your position is on that? And how SP Fiber helps you there? And ultimately, over time, what percent of the market you think that might be able to represent?

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: George, this is Ward. I'll give you the interest -- the answer to the interest question. I would model about $225 million of net interest. That's the interest expense less the interest income. And booking cash are virtually the same.
componenttext: George, this is Ward. I'll give you the interest -- the answer to the interest question. I would model about $225 million of net interest. That's the interest expense less the interest income. And booking cash are virtually the same.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: So on the question of lightweight -- this is Jim Porter. I think we've all seen a trend of lighter basis weights over the last several decades. Largely though, in the U.S. markets, those have been in the, I would say, the middleweight grades transitioning
componenttext: So on the question of lightweight -- this is Jim Porter. I think we've all seen a trend of lighter basis weights over the last several decades. Largely though, in the U.S. markets, those have been in the, I would say, the middleweight grades transitioning from 69 and 42 down into the 33s and 35s. When we think about lightweight of sub 26 pounds, that really has been largely unchanged. It was 5% to 6% 30 years ago. And frankly, today, it's about the same. Now with that said, the Dublin mill has added some significant flexibility for us, as we're able to go down really into the micro basis weights of 70 GSM or a 14-pound board that we do have applications for in our Corrugated business. Some of the specialty food products grades, we now have the ability to integrate that with our own paper supply. So we're quite excited about the future of that particular segment of the market.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Jim implied in your answer is just you've got the capability, but the fact that it's not really changed all that much tells you that the demand thus far domestically is -- it's growing, but not significantly. So would that be fair?
componenttext: So Jim implied in your answer is just you've got the capability, but the fact that it's not really changed all that much tells you that the demand thus far domestically is -- it's growing, but not significantly. So would that be fair?

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that's exactly right.
componenttext: I think that's exactly right.

headline: WestRock Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: And at this time, there are no questions. I'll turn it back to you, speakers.
componenttext: And at this time, there are no questions. I'll turn it back to you, speakers.

componenttext: Matt?

If you have questions following the call, the IR team is happy to help you. You could find our contact on today's earnings release. We look forward to speaking with you in the coming weeks. Have a great day, everyone.
